Title: Comment from Paul Risenhoover
Comment: The US Constitution declares that treaties pursuant thereto are supreme Law of the land, and the US Japan Peace Treaty specifically refers to Formosa, as the legal name of the island in English, not Taiwan. The rule should recognize this fact.  Moreover the ICAO Chicago Convention defines airspace territory to include areas under protection, such as Formosa by the directives to INDOPACOM, USPACFLT, and Seventh Fleet, and Kadena USMC Air and USAF.  https://history.state.gov/historicaldocuments/frus1952-54v14p2/d595. In this event, the Ryukyus [Page 1325]would be considered as being under the protection of the United States within the meaning of the Chicago Convention,11 and thus would be considered to be territory of the United States. https://history.state.gov/historicaldocuments/frus1951v06p1/d611  Lot 54D423  Memorandum by the Consultant to the Secretary (Dulles) secret [Washington,] June 27, 1951. Memorandum re Ryukyus 1  1. The United States does not itself desire to acquire sovereignty, for the reason, among other things, that the United States seeks scrupulously to conform to its January 1, 1942 declaration that it seeks no aggrandizement, territorial or other.  2. If Japan renounces sovereignty in favor of no one, this would create a chaotic international situation, particularly if, as is possible, the United Nations does not approve the trusteeship agreement we shall propose. It might then be claimed  a) that sovereignty was vested in the inhabitants, who could hereafter assert, perhaps with United Nations backing, a right to oust the United States; b) that the victors in the war over Japan, including the U.S.S.R., have an inchoate right to sovereignty of these islands renounced by Japan in favor of no one in particular; c) that the United Nations is entitled to deal, in its own way, with the islands and their inhabitants; d) that the United States has, by a subterfuge, actually acquired the sovereignty.  [Page 1153] The grant by Japan to the United States of continuing full powers over the islands might, however, be impaired if Japan itself renouncesin vacuumits sovereignty. We would have a grantor which, itself, had no title.  https://history.state.gov/historicaldocuments/frus1955-57v02/d282  Even the juridical position of Taiwan is in doubt. The United States also has an interest in [Page 620]Taiwan which we got away from Japan. Japan has merely renounced sovereignty over Taiwan which has not been disposed of by the peace treaty and not ceded to anyone. Consequently the United States also could assert a legal claim until Taiwan is disposed of by some means. We cannot, therefore, admit that the disposition of Taiwan is merely an internal problem. https://history.state.gov/historicaldocuments/frus1955-57v02/d322  While the juridical status of Taiwan is in limbo, certainly the Chinese Nationalists have the best right to it of anyone.  Viz: https://history.state.gov/search?q=taiwan+AND+%22right+of+conquest%22&within=documents&sort-by=relevance  https://history.state.gov/search?q=formosa+AND+%22principal+victor%22&within=documents&sort-by=relevance  https://history.state.gov/search?q=formosa+AND+%22article+73%22&within=documents&sort-by=relevance  https://history.state.gov/search?q=formosa+AND+%22article+107%22&within=documents&sort-by=relevance  https://history.state.gov/search?q=formosa+AND+wards&within=documents&sort-by=relevance  https://history.state.gov/historicaldocuments/frus1946v08/d163

Title: Comment from Tim Daniel

Title: Comment from Sara Lefebvre
Comment: The so-called "privatization process" has not been transparent and is being manipulated by wealthy people who do not have the best interests of the city of St Louis and the airport in mind. This is basically a money/influence grab and should not be allowed to continue in this manner. Also, privatization has not been shown to work.

Title: Comment from Firaz Mohideen
Comment:
Dear Mr. Martin, 

I am writing to enthusiastically endorse Boutique Airs EAS proposal for Massena Airport. Boutique Air, SkyWest, and Cape Air have pitched their offers to the Massena Town Council, who overwhelmingly supported the current carrier, Boutique Air, due to its reliability and convenience, proposed route and schedule, and enplanements over the past 2 years. However, I understand there is pressure from the Ogdensburg Bridge and Port Authority to select SkyWest instead. My reasons for endorsing Massena Town Councils selection are listed below.

1. Boutique Air currently provides three daily round-trip flights to Boston. I live in Potsdam, NY with my wife and 2 daughters, while I work in Cambridge, MA and fly this route weekly- leaving Massena Monday morning and returning Friday evening.

a. The flights are in comfortable pressurized cabins, leave Massena on-time regularly, there are no change or cancellation fees, and customer service is excellent.

b. The schedule enables a 9 AM Massena departure and a same day 9 PM return, especially useful to patients receiving treatment in Boston.

c. Boutique Air has a United Airlines code-share and interline agreement and uses a United Airlines gate at Boston-Logan International Airport, which enables seamless ticket reservations and transfers from Massena to hundreds of domestic and foreign destinations. Early next year Boutique Air will have an interline agreement with American Airlines (which uses the same Logan Airport terminal) as well.

d. Boutique Air rents a hangar at Massena airport and plans on setting up a Massena maintenance facility, which will significantly contribute to its economy.

2. SkyWests proposal is contingent upon their bids approved for Massena and Ogdensburg airports to Washington Dulles and Chicago OHare.

a. If SkyWest is selected for both airports, there will be no flights from New Yorks North Country to Boston, which will be a tremendous loss to the community. These flights are used by hundreds of passengers weekly, including patients to Boston hospitals and medical centers, students to the numerous colleges and universities in Boston and Cambridge, and professionals to the thriving New England metropolis.

b. A 6:30 pm Chicago OHare arrival makes it extremely difficult to connect to the desired destination, and a 11:30 pm Massena return would require this small, regional airport to operate until midnight.

c. SkyWest flies 50-seat jets, which, to fly at full capacity, require 100 passengers on average to leave Massena and Ogdensburg daily. This is extremely unlikely, given that current enplanements are 30 passengers per day on average. The remaining 70 seats are likely to be filled by travelers from Canada, and it seems unreasonable that our federal tax dollars should subsidize Canadian passengers.

d. The proposed SkyWest schedule is extremely inconvenient for Massena passengers. All Massena departures will stop in Ogdensburg, where passengers will likely have to deplane, re-board, before flying to Dulles or OHare. Massena passengers will have an hour added to all flights except those returning from Dulles. It would be far for efficient to make a 20-minute drive to Ogdensburg, where direct flights are available to both hubs, rendering Massena EAS worthless.

The SkyWest proposal appears to be a $ 6 million federal subsidy for Ogdensburg Essential Air Service to Washington and Chicago, with a Massena shuttle service. I strongly feel Boutique Air is best for Massena and implore you to heed the recommendation of Massenas elected officials and select Boutique Air for Massenas Essential Air Service.

Thank you for your consideration and should you have further questions or need more details, please do not hesitate to contact me by email at firazmoh@gmail.com or on my cell phone at 917-392-9043.

Sincerely,
Firaz Mohideen,
Potsdam, NY

Please find a PDF of the above letter and feel free to share with whomever you deem necessary.

Title: Comment from Philip Smith
Comment:
I do not support Skywest for Ogdensburg. If Skywest is awarded the contract it could become the airline servicing Massena. Boutique Air flies from Massena to Boston and Cape Air flies from Ogdensburg to Albany & Boston. EAS is for passengers in small towns not for giving our Canadians flights to Dulles and Chicago. 

Massena board has selected Boutique Air and submitted the proposal to DOT.

If Skywest is selected, then both Boutique Air to Boston flights and Cape Air flights from Ogdensburg to Albany will all be gone. You will have a big plane with a very limited flight schedule--and an especially poor schedule in Massena.

The Ogdensburg Bridge and Port Authority, which runs the airport in Ogdensburg, endorsed SkyWest's proposal of single daily roundtrip flights to Chicago and Washington D.C. from both airports. 
The Ogdensburg Bridge and Port Authority did not consult with the Massena Town Board, nor did they hear from any of the airlines proposing service (Boutique, Cape Air). Despite their best intentions, this is not a very good way to go about such an important matter, the process was in stark contrast to the public meetings that took place in Massena with all the airlines. 
Ogdensburg Bridge and Port Authority Director Wade Davis, five presidents of colleges and universities in the North Country, including St. Lawrence University President William L. Fox and Clarkson University President Anthony G. Collins, Congresswoman Elise Stefanik, State Senator Patty Ritchie, and Assemblywoman Addie Jenne  (Jenne later withdrew her support) all expressed their support for SkyWest in letters to the DOT. The Metropolitan Washington Airports Authority is throwing its weight behind an Ogdensburg Bridge and Port Authority
The Ogdensburg Airport Board have also asked for a variety of organizations and schools to support them in this decision, but they don't seem to have talked with many (or any) of the passengers (that's you!). This is not good especially since they held zero public meetings about this nor did they invite the airlines to come and give public presentations the way that Massena did. It is not clear that anyone other than the Ogdensburg Port Authority (Airport) had much of a say in their recommendation.

Essential Air Service program has now become another political, business self-center-interest instead of being selected for and by the North Country residents- the users of this service. Another example of political and businesses pushing for Skywest without considering the North Country community for input. All of these groups of people and politicians are saying what is good for the North Country; Massena Village board did due diligence by hold public meetings and the public voiced that Boutique was the best choice for Massena. 

Congress established the Essential Air Service (EAS) program to ensure that small communities that were served by certificated air carriers before deregulation would continue to receive scheduled passenger service, with subsidies if necessary.

Title: Comment from Donna Landrigan
Comment: Please keep Boutique Airlines in Alliance Nebraska.

Title: Comment from Rebecca Stoddard
Comment:
It has come to our attention that the City of Alliance is considering switching their Air Carrier to Denver Air Connection. 

We would like to request that you consider keeping the current airline Boutique Air.  
Often times when we have new workers arrive from South Africa we have them fly into Alliance. 
We have been extremely pleased with Boutiques services since they arrived in Alliance. 
They are reliable airline carrier with an impeccable safety record. 
The pilots are always polite and do a fabulous job with customer service. 
Not to mention that the planes are incredibly comfortable and their safety records are much higher than the out of production Metroliners used by Denver Air Connection. 
It also seems that Shawn Simpson, the CEO of Boutique, is willing to work with the city on whichever flight schedule accommodates citizens the best. I admire Shawns humility in expressing that he made a mistake in the past with communication and would like an opportunity to do a better job going forward. 

We appreciate your consideration.

Title: Comment from Cynthia Welling
Comment:
This email is intended to show my familys support of continuing Boutique Air services in Alliance NE.  We live in Marsland and I travel often for work.  The Boutique flights that we have taken were excellent, on time and the people were great to deal with. 

Thank you.

Title: Comment from Christine Anonymous
Comment: Please do not allow the change of airline services in Alliance, Nebraska. I have flown Boutique Air several times and I have always been pleased with the service. I feel safe aboard the planes they have.  I do not understand why the Alliance City Council wants a different carrier to service our area. Maybe someone is getting a kick-back? Dont know but it seems strange to me!

Title: Comment from Holly Heath
Comment: I ask that you keep Boutique Air in Alliance, Ne. They have provided excellent service. They have also recognized the need for overnight service in Alliance that had the equipment to deal with weather issues. I was on the selection committee as a former airline employee. They have the correct aircraft for our community and the pilot availability. I know our city recommended another airline but still feel Boutique is the best provider for our community.

Title: Comment from Hannah Raudsepp
Comment:
To Whom it May Concern: 

My family and I are residents of Grant County, NE. I am writing to strongly voice my support of keeping Boutique Air in service at the Alliance, NE airport, especially considering new safety concerns that have come to light with alternative Key Lime Air and the Metroliner airplanes they operate. 

Since 2001, the Metroliner aircraft has had 10x the accidents, 5x the fatal accidents, and 2.6x the fatalities than the Pilatus aircraft that Boutique Air operates. 

My husband commutes for work often using Boutique Air, and myself and several of my family members who are frequent flyers are so happy that Boutique operates out of Alliance. It is vitally important to small communities such as ours.

However, if the switch was made to Key Lime Air, frankly the drive to Denver is too easy to risk flying on a Metroliner, and I expect we would opt for the safer option of forgoing a flight on Key Lime rather than take the risk. 

Sincerely,

Hannah R.

Title: Comment from Stevi Buskirk
Comment: I would like to keep Boutique Air flying out of AIA. I am in support of AIA keeping Boutique airlines.

Title: Comment from Mary Lou Colwell
Comment: Please keep Boutique Airlines in Alliance, Nebraska.  Their planes are safe and I have had tremendous service flying with them.

Title: Comment from William Combs
Comment:
Evening, writing regards to Boutique airlines. We have used this air service since it first came into the area and have always been pleased with the schedule and fares. We have flown out of Chadron and alliance. I have read the proposed changes and not impressed by my findings. I propose that the carrier stays the same. Thanking you for your consideration.  
William combs.

Title: Comment from J. Buchheit
Comment: Please consider that Boutique Air is our very best choice for air service in Alliance, Ne. Not only the best for safety but service and dependability is a large concern. In rural Nebraska we have very little access to air service in and out of our community, as a person who travels to the East coast several times a year find it difficult to connect to large airports to make my travels enjoyable.  But with Boutique there dependability has far out surpassed other air lines that have serviced this area. In my opinion they are the best and only choice for us. Thank you. A frequent flier in a rural location. J. Buchheit

Title: Comment from Justin Moody
Comment:
I write this email in strong support of Boutique Air.  Having owned a dental practice in Alliance for nearly 15 years I am very familiar with the community and the airport.  I refused to fly out of there when Great Lakes was there due to their poor performance.  I fly into Alliance 2 times every month and have never had an incident which kept me from making my connections or getting me to Alliance on time to see patients.  The company that you propose uses an old plane that has a poor safety record and if they in deed get the bid I will begin to fly into Scottsbluff and rent a car.  Please reconsider your decision to not renew with Boutique Air.

Sincerely,


Justin D. Moody DDS

Title: Comment from Nancy Edelman
Comment:
I would like to voice my concern about using Denver Air Connection over Boutique Air for servicing Chadron and Alliance, NE. I have always been completely satisfied with Boutique, their service and price, and don't want to see any changes. With their expanded schedule, I believe they are the best company for the job. They also fly newer and safer aircraft than Denver Air Connection.
Thank you.

Title: Comment from Gladys Criss
Comment:
City of Alliance is recommending a different airlines to be our community airlines.
Boutique airline has been a great upgrade from previous (Great Lakes airline) and I believe
should be given further consideration as our Alliance community airlines.

Thank you and sincerely,
Gladys Criss
City of Alliance resident

Title: Comment from Richard McGrath
Comment:
Hello, As a frequent flyer of Boutique Air from Denver to Alliance and return. I am concerned that the airport and city want to replace them with a competitor who uses an inferior aircraft with a poor safety record to shuttle passengers? I would urge them to place safety above scheduling or politics, please reconsider replacing Boutique Air with Denver Air. Give Boutique the opportunity to address any concerns the airport and city have.
Best Regards, Rick McGrath

Title: Comment from Chadwick D Smith
Comment: As a member of the Alliance community I am pleased that the Alliance City Council is always looking at upgrading services. Denver Air Connection is another example of this. I believe in the process and I am sure the DOT will pick the best option for our community. I am fully behind the change to an operator that has clearly shown long term success in both cargo, charter and scheduled air service. I do not believe that Alliance would intentionally pick a substandard carrier and am looking forward to utilizing their service to connect to Denver and beyond.

Title: Comment from Donna Smith
Comment: I received an email from Boutique Air bringing to light the safety issues with the aircraft that Denver Air Connection plans on flying to Alliance. I trust that the Alliance City Council and the DOT will make the best decision for our community. Accident statistics can be presented to paint whatever picture you want. I know that many factors come into play during accident investigations, type of aircraft being only one of them.

Title: Comment from josh oleary
Comment: As a resident of alliance I'm pleased our city is able to have flights to/from Denver.  I travel for work quite often and a air service that's on time is very much appreciated.

Title: Comment from Audree Dross
Comment:
Below is an email I sent to the Alluance, NE City Counsel regarding Boutique Air.

Hello,

Im writing to express my feelings on switching carriers that fly into the Alliance Airport.  

First & foremost,  Boutique air has some of the safest airplanes among their fleet.  Much safer than the airplanes that will be used if we were to change carriers.  I fly them very often & always feel very safe knowing their fleet is very safe & has the track record to prove it.

Boutique has agreed to change to better accommodate flight schedules.  I am retired so their schedule is fine with me but if they are ready & willing to listen and change their schedules, I think they should be heard.

I was one of their passengers that was affected by their flight schedule problems last year & I was not happy about it, but moving forward, I believe that they have learned by their mistakes & are willing, in the future to communicate better with their customers, if anything like this should happen again.  

I understand that City Counsel did not have the information regarding the safety of Boutiques planes compared to the planes that will be used by the new carrier but now that they do have this very critical information I hope that this change will be considered.

Thank you for your time & consideration on this very important issue.

Sincerely,

Audree Dross

Title: Comment from DeAnn Bearheels
Comment: I am in strong support of keeping Boutique Airlines.  I fly several times a year to Denver out of Chadron and this is one of the smoothest flights and most comfortable for me.  Please keep Boutique Airlines.  I believe this would be detrimental to the city of Chadron.  Thank you.

Title: Comment from Barb Kniss
Comment:
I have used Boutique Air to fly from Alliance, Nebraska to Denver several times.  I have always been happy with their service and safety.
Please keep Boutique Air.

Title: Comment from Brett Dietrich
Comment:
Hello

I am writing to offer my support to keep Boutique Airlines flying in and out of Alliance.

I am a former Alliance native currently living in Kansas City, MO. It is generally a 9 hour drive for me to get to Alliance to see my parents and relatives when I want to visit. I fly to Denver and then take Boutique Air from Denver to Alliance. This has made the trip much shorter and much more enjoyable.

They offer fantastic service, a comfortable flight and I feel very safe when flying with them.

I use the service 2-3 times a year to see my parents who are now in their 80s. With them not able to travel, I am making the trek more often and will be flying even more in the future.

Compared to others, I know I am not an Alliance frequent flyer, but I do know a quality airline and Boutique is one of them. They have an outstanding safety record and with them adding more flights to their schedule in May, it will give me more options for flying out more often. 

I know there is a new airline in the mix for the Alliance regional service. From what I have read, their safety record and aircraft age do not touch Boutique Air's modern planes.

I know you consider many factors when making decisions that affect the city of Alliance. I hope you will also consider those of us who have flown Boutique Air and believe it is the best choice for the city.

Sincerely,

Brett Dietrich

Title: Comment from Tessa Swarthout
Comment:
Hello-
Im writing on concerns to Alliance changing contracts with their airline service provider. Its as if theyve trying to wreck a good thing thats going right now. Did they make any requests to Boutique for the changes they needed made before just tossing them to the curb? Ive flown many times and enjoyed the dependability and consistency/on time departures Boutique has offered over the years. Their customer service is incredible, helpful and friendly and I am fully confident in having my elderly grandpa fly alone with them, knowing if he were to need assistance- the Boutique staff and pilots would be kind, friendly and happy to help.

Im not alone in my desire to keep Boutique Air for the airline of the panhandle. Previous airlines were prohibitive in cost to use and they were not reliable enough to count on for other travel plans and flights out of Denver. 

I appreciate your time and consideration in keeping Boutique Air as the air service provider for Alliance Nebraska.

Title: Comment from Kayla Wintz
Comment:
I am writing to you about keeping Boutique Air at the Alliance Nebraska Airport.  I have flown with Boutique Air many times since they have started servicing the Alliance area and I have never had any problems or concerns about me and my luggage getting to Denver where I usually fly to.  The ticket agents and pilots are always helpful, friendly and always considerate.  Flight times are for the most part very easy to work with connecting flights.  I flew Great Lakes when they were servicing Alliance and several times had my flight cancelled because the plane wasn't "full".  On one of my flights with Boutique I was the only passenger!   I've only had one flight cancelled by Boutique due to mechanical problems and the agents were very instrumental in getting the 5 of us that were to fly that afternoon to Denver by renting us a van with a full tank of gas.  
     I am concerned about the safety record of Denver Air Coaches type of plane they operate.  I know at anytime things can go wrong and accidents happen, but I like the fact that Boutique has a very safe safety record!
     My connecting flights in Denver are with American and Boutique has a baggage agreement with them and United.  I understand that Denver Air only has an agreement with United, which means going to baggage claim, rechecking your luggage and then going back through security for your connecting flight.  Most of my flights are to visit my daughter and her family and I fly American every time and will continue to do so in the future.
     I thank you for taking the time to read my comments.  I just wanted to let you know I'll be flying with Boutique as long as they service our surrounding area.

Title: Comment from Carolina Echeverri
Comment: I believe this topic is crucial in the United States, especially since this is such a large nation. Hence, there are concerns in terms of trafficking, because it could happen to any of us. It is a transnational issue that requires multilateral cooperation that has to be coordinated with local and international agencies. It takes a lot of work and dedication to decrease the number of victims in human trafficking. I am mostly concerned with this topic, as it affects mostly South Florida, which is where I live. Border patrol should focus more on these kinds of issues, as it could happen to anyone and everyone, and the government has the responsibility to protect its citizens.

Title: Comment from Anonymous

Title: Comment from Anonymous
Comment: I recommend if the operator operates in, on or around Public Lands any and all information be made available to the public. Further: Commercial operations should be prohibited on Public Lands.

Title: Comment from Jackie Yafanaro
Comment: This has been going on since the 90s. Im 32 years old. I was on a plane twice my entire life. The first time I was on a plane the airline destroyed my chair so badly (new chair I might add) I had to go back to where I purchased the chair and have them fix what the airline broke. I watched them from my window, the literally grabbed it and through it on like it was trash being tossed on a garbage truck. We knew it would be broken by the time we landed but there was nothing we could do. I literally watched as they treated the thing that I cherish the most be destroyed right in front of my eyes. Our chairs are our life line, you disrespect our chair and thats like disrespecting us. If the average person purchased a Audi or some other really expensive car and than had a valley park it, and that valley took it and crashed it into a wall or even took car keys and keyed the thing, would that driver not be held responsible? Yes they would, so why arent airlines being held responsible when they destroy medical equipment? There needs to be a change!

Title: Comment from Bruce Grimm
Comment:
Reporting disability related complaints is important so that the passengers issue regarding alleged discrimination is handled in a timely manner.

The agency has access to direct reporting of consumer complaints through phone, mail, hotline or online through the Aviation Consumer Protection Division.

Airline customers also can make disability related complaints directly to air carrier customer service representatives, airline management or ADA compliance through the Department of Justice.

The DOT should consider including discrimination reports on the platforms available now and relieve the airlines from this redundant reporting.  In most cases, an alleged discrimination report will not be created on the day of travel rather some time later.  Airline staff really have no inkling that a complaint will be filed until after the fact which generally will be some time later.

The current reporting method is outdated, redundant and does not seem to be effective.

Title: Comment from Ron Jesse
Comment: I have not personally encountered a whistle blower incident, however I know of two people that have.  They were both transferred, humiliated and lost all possibility of advancement as a result.  Clearly there is no real protection for those that report bad conduct of their employer.

Title: Comment from B L
Comment:
I write to the Department of Transportation in support of the amendment to explicitly ban the use of electronic cigarettes and similar electronic nicotine delivery systems on the use of aircraft. The arguments against this amendment are fundamentally incorrect. Firstly, the health effects of electronic cigarettes can not be examined nor studied until they manifest in the population. E-cig use is relatively new, studies do not have a large enough sample size to determine their health effects like with cigarettes. Moreover, the batteries of e-cigarettes have proven unreliable and faulty. They pose the risk of an in-flight explosion which should automatically justify their banning on aircraft. 
The fact that you even believe that it's just water vapor that you're inhaling proves your sheer idiocy. Last time I checked, water vapor on its own doesn't have enough integrity to come out in a billowing cloud. 
I am appalled by the self-righteous stubbornness of the opponents to this amendment. Like dude, just chew some nicotine gum or put on a patch. Face the reality that you are nursing a substance addiction and that it does not justify exposing a whole cabin to the smell of your artificial strawberry-scented "water vapor".

Title: Comment from Anonymous
Comment: This law should be imposed as soon as possible with strict regulations against the use of electronic cigarettes and similar electronic nicotine delivery systems use in aircraft or any other public transport system.  Permitting the use of such product is promoting it. Easy access and no regulations increase the probability of their use and hence increase the rate of morbidity and mortality. There are multiple chemicals identified in e-cigarette aerosol. Secondhand e-cigarette aerosol contains nicotine, hazardous ultra-fine particles, volatile organic compounds, and other chemicals, some of which are carcinogenic (e.g., formaldehyde, metals like cadmium, lead, & nickel, and nitrosamine). The battery powered nicotine delivery systems pose fire risk and are required to follow specific instructions if to be present in the aircraft. Release of these chemicals could potentially be harmful to infants and young children and also adults with respiratory problems travelling in the confined space such as an aircraft.

Title: Comment from yuxuan li
Comment: I am a college student who is a current smoker of e-cigarettes. The use of this new type of tobacco products has greatly increased throughout these years. I do believe that the number of users of e-cigarettes is getting to an excessive, dangerous amount, and it has already reached the critical point for us to set up new regulations for these groups in public. I agree we should amend the existing airline smoking rule to explicitly ban the use of electronic cigarettes on all aircraft in scheduled passenger interstate, intrastate and foreign air transportation. I do believe that e-cigarettes should be classified as one kind of cigarettes and it would definitely bring up the same potential health and passenger comfort concerns that they pose in an aircraft. In this sense, we should ban the usage of e-cigarettes just like what we did in the smoking prohibition in intrastate and interstate air transportation. I suggest adding e-cigarettes as hazardous items in the security check, just like lighters and liquids. I believe it is a great time for the FDA to take charge before this brings any actual negative influence.

Title: Comment from Mystified Disappointed
Comment:
Utterly mystified by this action. Notice does not explain what is hoped to be gained by this "clear message" to the Cuban government. If we are against repression of Cubans, it seems that cutting them off further from opportunities to travel to the U.S. or to receive visitors from the U.S. only further contributes to that repression. This regulation has no personal impact on me or my family, but I am disappointed for our country and for those negatively impacted by this action, including our business, such as U.S. based carriers, the administration claims to support.

Title: Comment from A. Nonymous
Comment:
This comment is submitted as part of a class exercise in Administrative Law.  At this point, I do not feel that I am qualified to comment on a matter involving potential future violation of privacy rights by means of tracking person(s) who have issued complaints against airlines and system manufacturers by the Department, nor am I ultimately comfortable with my name being attached to something as part of the public record without the ability to do further research into the matter before submitting.  However, I do find it concerning that the Department of Transportation is seeking a means to do so.  Given the concerning conditions of air carriers over the course of the last two decades worth of deregulation, I imagine that the list of person(s) issuing complaints against air carriers and manufacturers has grown considerably. 

By all means, if this measure is adopted by the Department, please ensure that all person(s) listed and/or documented have access to their file, in accordance with FOIA.

Title: Comment from Daniel Garcia and Lamar Bennett
Comment:
From: Daniel Garcia and Lamar Bennett, CUNY School of Law
To: Elaine L. Chao, DOT Secretary 
Date: 4/7/19
Re: DOT-OST-2017-0028 "Maintenance of and Access to Records Pertaining to Individuals"

        Our names are Daniel Garcia & Lamar Bennett. We are second year law students at the City University of New York and we write today to express our concern regarding proposed rule DOTOST20170028 Maintenance of and Access to Records Pertaining to Individuals which exempts the Aviation Consumer Complaint Application Online System ("ACCAOLS") from disclosure of individualized records. We oppose the proposed rule because of the impediments it will place on potential litigants right to discovery pursuant Federal Rule of Civil Procedure rule 26(a)(1)(A)(2).  	
	Our concern is grounded in three main points. First, the rule does nothing in service of 
the public interest (the DOTs ability to conduct investigations), while it does seriously 
undermine the interests of private citizens (the right to information). Second, the proposed 
rule will have an adverse effect on private litigants seeking redress for any harm committed
by airlines or DOT employees. And third, the mechanisms to determine whether dissemination 
of information is appropriate are discretionary.  
	The purpose of this rule is articulated thusly: to protect records compiled for investigations and inquiries into alleged Federal civil rights and consumer protection misconduct by airlines and air travel companies. This proposed rule does not adequately public interest (the DOT investigative needs) and private interests (freedom of information) because the DOT can arbitrarily rule that nearly all the information collected is part of an ongoing criminal or regulatory investigation. As you state: The Privacy Act of 1974, 5 U.S.C. 552a, requires that agencies tell the public when they maintain information about a person in a file that may be retrieved to that person's name, this compiling of information does not necessarily mean that the information is being stored for the, exclusive, purposes of investigations or litigation. The publication of such information would not hinder the departments ability to conduct ongoing investigations in any substantial way. 
	Exempting the publication of these records would have two adverse consequences for the public: first, it would prevent individuals from being informed consumers, and using their wallet to affect conduct of private business; and second, it would put potential litigants at a disadvantage in determining patterns of impermissible behavior.      
	This proposed rule could seriously disadvantage airline passengers who are seeking to file discrimination claims against airlines pursuant to Civil Rights Act, as airlines fall into the classification of public accommodations, and, in rare instances, Bivens actions against DOT employees. For instance, a plaintiff or group of plaintiffs who are alleging racial discrimination would need information about the consumer complaints to establish that the airline has a pattern or practice of racially profiling people.  These examples show that there is a serious risk that this proposed rule will undermine the right to discovery, pursuant to the Federal Rules of Civil Procedure Rule 26 because material information on the ACCAOLS will be exempt to disclosure.
	The proposed rule allows for ways around the exemption, whether through a waiver by the OST or individualized FOIA requests. This contention does little to quell our concerns about an individual right to access their information under the Privacy Act. That standard seems ephemeral at best and may be applied differently from one instance to another. This vagueness could mean little, if any, information would be disclosed because of this exemption from publication and the DOT may refuse to disclose information that may highlight embarrassing patterns of discrimination by airlines or DOT employees. 

	For all the reasons stated above, we respectfully oppose this proposed rule in its current form.

Sincerely,
Daniel Garcia & Lamar Bennett

Title: Comment from Robert F. Nixon
Comment:
Mr. Jonathan Moss, Assistant General Counsel for Regulation
Docket Management Facility, Room W12-140
U.S. Department of Transportation
1200 New Jersey Ave., SE
Washington, DC 20590-0001

Dear Mr. Moss:

In response to Docket Number DOT-OST-2017-0069-2855 published in the Tuesday, Feb. 5, 2019 Federal Register / Vol. 84, No. 24 (https://www.regulations.gov/document?D=DOT-OST-2017-0069-2855 ) requesting Public Participation and Request for Comments, King County Metro Superintendent of Transit Fleet Contract Management Group Mr. Steve Policar and I respectfully re-submit our comments originally submitted to FTA on September 7, 2017 regarding FTAs Buy America Handbook (https://www.federalregister.gov/documents/2017/01/17/2017-00873/buy-america-handbook-conducting-pre-award-and-post-delivery-audits-for-rolling-stock-procurements ).

Based upon our combined 50+ years experience conducting and/or directly supporting 185+ Buy America audits, Mr. Policar and I wish to revise and update the Handbooks inaccuracies that are (c) inconsistentunclear; (d) not conducive to uniform or consistent enforcement and need to be updated to reflect developments that have taken place since the guidance was issued.  FTA Recipient auditors are inconsistently cherry-picking which excerpts to enforce, many of which conflict with 49 CFR Parts 661 and 663, causing major concerns in the industry at all levels.

Our proposed solutions provide descriptive alternative guidance that FTA can simply Cut & Paste over the applicable existing text.   

Please contact Mr. Policar at (206) 477-5878 or steve.policar@kingcounty.gov or me whenever we may be of assistance.  Steve and I welcome the opportunity to meet with you in Washington, DC to work through these issues and participate in future stakeholder meetings. 

Thank you for your consideration.

Respectfully yours,

Robert F. Nixon, DM2US	
Steven S. Policar, King County Metro

Title: Comment from Cathy Wampler
Comment:
Department of Transportation, Docket Number DOT-OST-2017-0069

As ADA Coordinator for the County of Riverside Transportation Department (California), I would like to express a desire for USDOT/FHWA to provide guidance and to adopt the Public Right of Way Accessibility Guidelines (PROWAG).  The draft PROWAG was initially drafted in 2011, for which the public comment period closed in 2013.  

ADA Coordinators for local agencies throughout the nation are trying to enforce draft PROWAG design standards within public road right-of-way for which the USDOJ and USDOT/FHWA and US Access Board have found to be "best design practices," but for which the US government has not yet adopted.

Accessibility design in public road right-of-way poses unique design challenges that are much different than the building accessibility design standards contained in the 2010 ADA Standards.  Working without adopted regulations is hampering local agency efforts for providing accessible pedestrian facilities for persons with disabilities, a civil rights issue outlined by the Americans with Disabilities Act of 1990.

It is our understanding that the current Presidential Administration is opposed to issuing "new regulations."  

We would like to respond by saying that "less regulation" is not "better business" for agencies trying to implement accessibility goals for Americans, including disabled veterans, children, elderly and others.

Title: Comment from American Concrete Pavement Association
Comment: Fundamentally, ACPA believes that current federal pavement type selection policy (as expressed in the FHWA Pavement Type Selection Policy Statement: 1981 FR Vol 46 No 195) is sound and is grounded in a requirement that states consider alternative combinations of materials, as well as life cycle cost. In other words, states are required to consider both asphalt and concrete paving materials in a way that fairly compares them. Unfortunately, FHWA is not enforcing these federal policies appropriately and as a result, many state DOTs do not consider alternative combinations of materials (competition) nor do they use life cycle cost analyses to inform pavement type selections. This lack of action on the FHWAs part is clearly and demonstrably costing taxpayers money  roughly $5 billion each and every year, according to industry and MIT estimates. By rectifying these problematic stewardship oversights, U.S. departments of transportation could complete roughly 10% additional infrastructure work at no additional cost to the taxpayer.

Title: Comment from Melissa Mendes
Comment:
The Fresno Regional Workforce Development Board (FRWDB) has observed that the U.S. Department of Transportation (DOT) and its various operating administrations do not currently have a uniform policy for targeted hiring initiatives and funding related to job training. This discrepancy gets in the way of local workforce development boards and their partners from implementing additional methods of getting unemployed and underemployed people back to work. In order to realize the maximum benefit of federal infrastructure projects and achieve President Trumps vision of rebuilding our infrastructure while putting millions of Americans to work, consistent policies are needed to address targeted hiring and funding related to job training at the operating administrations within the DOT (Federal Railroad Administration, Federal Transit Administration, Federal Aviation Administration, and Federal Highway Administration, etc.).

Our recommendation is based on our experience recommending targeted hiring policies for the California High Speed Rail project.  These proposed policies were deemed constitutional by the DOTs Federal Railroad Administration (FRA) and adopted by the California High Speed Rail Authority. During the course of this long-drawn-out process, discrepancies between the DOTs operating administrations became apparent. While the Targeted Hiring recommendations were eventually cleared by the FRA, and nearly-identical recommendations made by the Los Angeles County Metropolitan Transportation Authority were cleared by the  Federal Transit Administration (FTA), confusion still exists within the DOTs other operating administrations  namely the Federal Highway Administration (FHA). During a meeting with California Department of Transportations Director, he stated that targeted and/or focused hiring initiatives are not allowed by the FHA. This sentiment has been echoed by those within that administration, despite the fact that targeted hiring initiatives have been allowed by FRA and FTA after full vetting from their legal counsels. What is deemed legal by two administrations within the same department should be allowed by administrations throughout the DOT. Clearly, a uniform policy is needed, the result of which could be increased job opportunities for Americans in disadvantaged communities that need them most.

Federally-funded public infrastructure projects have the potential to produce multiple economic benefits, including the creation of employment opportunities for the nations most economically disadvantaged areas. In its 2017 Annual Report, the DOT estimates that transportation accounted for 13 million jobs or 9% of the U.S labor force.  Targeted hiring initiatives and related job training strategies increase the likelihood that unemployed and underemployed individuals in economically distressed communities have access to these jobs. Currently, the U.S. DOT and its various administrative units lack a uniform policy for either targeted hiring initiatives or funding for concomitant job training.
  
We request that the DOT adopt a uniform policy that applies to each of its operating administrations that allows for targeted hiring initiatives on federally funded projects. The FRWDB further requests that each operating administration be allowed to use a portion of its funding for job training related to DOT projects.

Title: Comment from American Academy of Sleep Medicine
Comment:
Dear Mr. Moss:

On behalf of the American Academy of Sleep Medicine (AASM), I am contacting your office to submit comments regarding the U.S. Department of Transportation (DOT) Notice of Review of Guidance docket number DOT-OST-2017-0069.

The AASM is a professional society that represents a membership of 10,000 physicians, scientists, advanced practice practitioners, allied health professionals, and accredited sleep centers. The AASM is the leader in setting standards and promoting excellence in sleep medicine health care.

Over 475,000 police-reported crashes involved large trucks in 2016. Of these, 3,864 were fatal, and 104,000 caused serious injuries. Thirty seven percent of all fatal crashes, 23 percent of all crashes involving injuries, and 20 percent of all property-damage-only crashes involving large trucks occurred at night (6 p.m. to 6 a.m.).1 These data indicate that our highways are far from safe. One potential cause of vehicular crashes is inadequate sleep, either through insufficient opportunity to rest, work schedules that are misaligned with biological sleep schedules, or intrinsic sleep disorders.

Over the last two years, the Federal Motor Carrier Safety Administration (FMCSA) has rolled back and removed several safety rules and regulations, and it withdrew a proposal to regulate the management of moderate-to-severe obstructive sleep apnea among operators.2 Similarly, earlier this year, FMCSA removed state-mandated meal and rest breaks for California, despite the fact that fatigue or inattention caused by long driving hours without breaks can contribute to an increased risk for crashes.3

The following comments refer specifically to the proposal to repeal existing guidance documents published by the FMCSA. The AASM states clearly and unequivocally that repealing these documents neither maintains nor improves the current level of safety.
  
Guidance documents serve the critical role of providing a common framework for medical examiners, in the depth and detail required when addressing medical disorders that can impact driving safety, and with content that was based on input from experts in their respective fields. While National Registry of Certified Medical Examiners (NRCME) courses provide some level of training, these courses are developed and administered by third parties with minimal oversight. Not all NRCME training courses cover material in the same level of detail, nor in the same manner. Thus, considerable heterogeneity exists in the value and content of these courses. Such variability undermines the goal of ensuring a robust, reliable process in determining medical fitness for duty. 

Examiners, therefore, who cannot reasonably be expected to be content experts in all aspects of medicine, must continue to have access to the FMCSA guidance documents to review in concert with their own clinical judgment when making safety-sensitive medical decisions. As to replacing or modifying guidance, the AASM wholeheartedly supports updating existing guidance to reflect changes in the science and current standards of care. Many guidance documents would benefit from such review.  

Therefore, we strongly recommend:

1) Placing all guidance documents - including all Medical Expert Panel (MEP) reports, letters of instruction or guidance from FMCSA, and all recommendations/reports from the Medical Review Board (MRB) - on an easily accessible website, with quick links that examiners can use to access these resources when needed; 

2) Advising examiners that recommendations provided by these documents should be considered minimum standards of care, and not a substitute for clinical training, judgement, and more current guidelines from other professional organizations; 

3) Updating outdated MEP reports to reflect current state of the science; 
 
4) Updating and re-publishing the previously removed Medical Examiner's Handbook. We cite the Federal Aviation Administrations Guide for Aviation Medical Examiners as an excellent example of a living document that provides up-to-date guidance to examiners, and we encourage development of similar documents for all modal agencies.

Thank you for your consideration of these comments.

Sincerely,

Indira Gurubhagavatula, MD
Chair, AASM Public Safety Committee

REFERENCES  
1. Federal Motor Carrier Safety Administration. Large Truck and Bus Crash Facts 2016. Updated May 8, 2018; accessed May 6, 2019.
2. Federal Motor Carrier Safety Administration and the Federal Railroad Administration. 82 FR 37038. Evaluation of Safety Sensitive Personnel for Moderate-to-Severe Obstructive Sleep Apnea. Advance notice of proposed rulemaking; withdrawal. Aug. 8, 2017; accessed May 6, 2019.
3. Federal Motor Carrier Safety Administration. 83 FR 67470. California's Meal and Rest Break Rules for Commercial Motor Vehicle Drivers; Petition for Determination of Preemption. Order; grant of petition for determination of preemption. Dec. 28, 2018; accessed May 6, 2019.

Title: Comment from James Lamb
Comment: On October 22, 2019, the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration (NHTSA) of the United States Department of Transportation (USDOT) released new data that show that in 2018, the first full year the new ELD rule was in effect for the trucking industry to enforce commercial motor vehicle operators' compliance with hours of service regulations, more than 2 occupants of large trucks died. Every. Single. Day. This is the highest number of such deaths since 1988, making this stat a 30-year high. We believe ELDs have caused drivers anxiety to such levels that many now recklessly speed to beat the clock. We call on the Whitehouse to direct the USDOT to act on NHTSA findings and immediately suspend ELDs until unintended consequences can be studied to decide if the rule is ripe for repeal.

Title: Comment from John Adams
Comment:
Docket DOT-OST-2018-0030
 


Dear Department of Transportation:

Below please find a comment related to the above docket matter.
Interest of Commenter:  I have been a member of the American Airlines rewards program, and predecessor programs, since 1997. (American # 0L8_ _ _ _ - last four digits redacted).  During that time I have had the highest level of status and am currently what American calls Platinum.  I have flown during that time period anywhere from 50 to 125 segments a year on American and predecessor airlines.  I also have a Qantas frequent flyer account.
Every day for the last few months, I have sought to purchase a flight from Reagan Washington National to either Queenstown, New Zealand (ZQN), or Auckland, New Zealand (AKL).  I have sought to either purchase four tickets with cash or to use the over 1,000,000 frequent flyer miles my family has accumulated.  
My efforts to procure tickets have been a complete failure.  
{REDACTED FOR SPACE TO FIT, SEE PDF FOR FULL COMMENTS] 
Purchasing Qantas Tickets: You might ask, so why not just buy a ticket if you cannot find a way to spend your 1,000,000 miles to get to New Zealand?  I tried that too, without success.  First my Qantas experience.  I attempted to purchase business or first class tickets from DCA to Queenstown, New Zealand for April 9, 2020 (and adjacent dates).  It seems that Qantas doesnt make that route available under the status quo, and if the JBA would fix that, I wholeheartedly support the JBA.  Regardless, that makes purchasing a Qantas ticket from DCA to ZQN  either in first class or business  a total impossibility.  If, however, I wanted to merely purchase a ticket departing from Dallas, Qantas permits me to purchase Dallas to Sydney to Queenstown.  Of course I am sure I could probably purchase a ticket from Brisbane to Queenstown, but alas I am not in Brisbane any more than I am in Dallas. Under the status quo, Qantas does not make any routes available between the two points I wish to travel  namely DCA to ZQN, despite only requiring two stops (DFW, SYD).
Purchasing American Tickets: Heres where it really gets strange.  For the last few weeks I have attempted to purchase American Airlines tickets from DCA to Auckland.  Remember, we have over 1,000,000 American miles, but alas they have proven to be as useful as Confederate script to get to New Zealand. Moreover, American will not allow me to route into Queenstown (ZQN) at purchasing a ticket despite routing through Sydney where at least 2 Qantas planes will leave for every day. Instead, American has been offering business class seats DCA-LAX-SYD-Auckland for the eye popping amount of $16,839 per business class seat. Is the first 1 in the price a computer glitch?  Assuming the price is not an error, it is no surprise that American seems to not have sold a single seat at this price.  Air New Zealand and even Qantas is crushing American Airlines on price when it comes to travelling from DCA to AKL. Even within Americans own routes, there is something fishy about the $16,839 fare.  Round trip business class to Beijing China on the same day is $7,222, London is $5,912, Hong Kong is $7,338, and even Sydney at $10,549.  The business class segment over the Tasman Sea ups the cost over $6,000.  It leads one to conclude that current transpacific fares on American are as inexplicable as the American rewards tickets routing from Washington to New Zealand through Miami, Seattle or Fiji.
Position on JBA: To the extent the JBA improves these absurd circumstances, consider this a comment in support.  To the extent the JBA prolongs these terrible circumstances, consider this a comment in opposition.
Before the Comment Period Closes: My wife and I are going to continue to try to book tickets from DCA to Queenstown (or as a second choice Auckland) over the next 14 days that the comment period is open.  My wife, who also has American preferred status, and I will attempt to use either miles, or outright purchase some of the tickets we seek during the next 13 days.  She may leave a comment for you about our experiences attempting to do so related to this docket matter.  Perhaps the announcement of the JBA will itself improve these circumstances.  Either way, we will try to let you know if the situation has improved at all, or if we face practical impossibilities to obtain miles rewards tickets or even purchase tickets from our home (DCA) to our destination (ZQN or AKL) at prices that have a grounding in reality.
And if you are curious, the dates I wanted to travel to DCA to ZQN was April 9, 2020.  I wanted to return via Auckland (or frankly any city in New Zealand) on April 20, 2020.  We will continue to try to book a return flight on April 20, 2020 to DCA preferably from Auckland.  
Thank you for your time.
 
John C. Adams
(American Advantage # 0L8_ _ _ _ - last four digits redacted).  
703-963-8611

Title: Comments of Travel Fairness Now
Comment: Travel Fairness Now comments

Title: Comment from American Airlines, Inc.
Comment: See attached file(s)

Title: Comment from Carol Matheis
Comment: Please see the attached letter.

Title: Comment from LaResa Ridge
Comment:
As a person who is severely allergic to cats, my  needs should be honored as well. Airlines should have designated flights and  areas for animals and should inform the public of those designations.

Allow me to make an informed decision to protect my health!

Title: Comment from Debra Boudreau
Comment:
I'm writing about the emotional support pet scam for cheap inconsiderate people to avoid the pet travel fee.  With a phony document from the internet, these people are traveling with out of control animals that spread E. Coli, parasites, viruses, and dander, endangering the lives of other passengers.  They defecate on seats and in aisles, and bite people and service dogs.  In an emergency such as turbulance, crash, or fire, they are loose and will block aisles and bite people, resulting in the loss of human lives.  They bark and meow for hours and many are unwashed and stink. Their stool is large and stinks.  Dander and smell travel through the ventilation system.  Should mentally disturbed people even be on a plane?

Perhaps requiring that travelers with emotional support animals pay the pet fee, enclose the animal in a carrier, and require a health certificate will weed out the phonies. Require the remainder to buy two bulkhead seats.  The animals, when seated on the aisle will block passengers from going to the restroom, or easy passage to an exit in case of emergency.

The person requiring an emotional support animal can hug the animal in a soft sided carrier and eliminate the dander, E. Coli, parasites, viruses, and defecating on seats and in aisles problem.  Requiring them to wash their pet before travel would be a bonus.  Also requiring training as a service dog, i.e., not to bark, bite, and defecate unless prompted would furthur weed out the phonies.  Everyone I met with a dog on a 10' leash seemed quite normal despite not hugging their pet.

A mentally disturbed person can hug a pet through a soft-sided carrier.  This would require limiting the size of animal but protect people with allergies, asthma, and compromised immune systems.  Or do we not have rights?  

The latest scam is offering a service animal package on the internet.  People with genuine service animals are as outraged as I am.

DOT created this problem.  Please resolve it.

Title: Comment from P Elke
Comment:
Tighten the regulations, and consider people who have allergies to animals.  I have a husband who is allergic to the dander from cats and dogs.  He has a puffer which he uses for the asthmatic reaction when in close proximity to animals.  I was on a flight recently and informed the Airline about my concern when a service dog showed up in the waiting area at the gate.  I talked to the boarding agents, expressing my concern and asking that they check where the dog and owner were seated, and if they were in close proximity to us if they could change our seats.  I was informed that there were 3-4 dogs on the flight.  The agent said he would look after this prior to our boarding.  My conversation with the agents was 75 minutes prior to the departure time.  While I was boarding I asked what he had done and was told to step aside, and waited.  He then told me that there were dogs in row 19 and 20 and we were in row 21.  He told us to board and he would be in to help us.  As I boarded the plane I spoke to the cabin attendant who dismissed me and told me to talk to the attendant at the back.  We took our seats and it looked like there were no dogs in the 2 rows in front of us.  Then the same agent comes in escorting the service dog and owner to the seat directly in front of my husbands seat.  I jumped up and said, "This is not going to work, you have to find us another seat."  the owner of the service dog snaps back at me saying, He's a service dog and he's hypoallergenic." which I reply, there is no such thing as a hypoallergenic dog, it still has dander." ( I want to add that this is a big dog, possibly a labradoodle and not well groomed.  I could smell the dog the entire flight.)  I'm now out of my seat talking to the agent and the stewardess, clearly seeing that they are not going to do a thing. So I walked down the aisle asking  if someone would switch seats.  The head stewardess asks me to sit down, but I continue and finally as I'm near the end of the plane a lady offers to change seats with my husband.  Amen.

I want to add that people on the plane said things like the dog is a poodle and it's hypoallergenic, laughing at me.  This is how ill informed that people are.

Where are the rights of the passenger?  I paid over 1500.00 for each ticket and animal owners pay 50.00 to bring their pet onboard?  And of course service dogs and comfort dog owners fly for nothing.

To address the issue of service dogs.  I understand the need for them and the good that they do.  I personally have a friend who is blind and the dog is essential to his well being and livelihood.  There is though a big difference between a service dog and a comfort dog.  I am not trying to diminish comfort dogs and people who have emotional issues, anxiety and depression.  Just as they have needs so does my husband - he can't breath and has asthma when close to dogs and cats.  I'd like to know how these people would feel if they couldn't breath.  We also should be accommodated on the planes.  

I don't pay to fly with a bunch of dogs.  There should be a minimum buffer zone for those with allergies to pets, and airlines should be made to offer some flights with no pets.  There should be a designated area for the pets on the plane and an area that has plenty of leg room. ( The big dog on our recent flight did not fit into the leg space, and spewed over the floor infront of the next person.)
 
 Airlines recognized the issue with nut allergies and most airlines took action.  Why not do the same for allergies to animals.  Regulations are badly needed.
  
As human beings we all have needs, and the question is how to fairly accommodate everyone.

Title: Comment from Sandra Hayden
Comment:
What about the health and safety of passengers with allergies!!! I have allergic asthma. I have no way of knowing whether my physical and emotional well-being will be under attack when I book a flight.

This proposal contains NO PLAN to deal with passengers with allergies! I searched the text for the term "allerg":
- "Some individuals with disabilities prefer miniature horses to dogs because of allergies...". Two references.
- "Examples of work or tasks [performed by a service animal] include, but are not limited to, ...alerting individuals to the presence of allergens...". Indeed.

I don't understand why one person's disability that is emotional in nature (ESA) currently takes precedence over another person's disability that is both physical and has a traumatic emotional aspect. Can you not imagine being forced into a confined space with a physical threat, and how it feels when your protests are met with uncaring neglect?

What is it going to take for regulators and airlines to sit up and take notice, a fatality and lawsuits?

Title: Comment from Anonymous
Comment: Please consider the needs of people with allergies. It is not enough to move someone to a different section of an airplane. If you are very allergic to cats/dogs, that doesn't help. Why does an emotional support animal get priority over a paying passenger? Please don't allow emotional support animals on airplanes. My allergies are bad enough that my eyes sometimes get swollen shut. Is that really better than another passenger having anxiety about separation from their emotional support animal? There are also so many more people with allergies mild enough that they don't complain or submit public comments like this, but they are still inconvenienced. In addition to harming passengers with allergies they are a nuisance due to smell, noise, and occasionally taking up extra room.

Title: Comment from Rosemary Pixley
Comment: I understand a minute percentage of the population needs a licensed service animal with them to aid them.  However, the wording of the current ADA law has made it almost impossible for any business or transportation segment to separate actual trained, licensed service animals from peoples' pets.  This has caused a spike in animals on board planes.  As a person who has severe allergies to animals of all types it has become impossible for me to fly or travel by rail (within the USA) due to the number of animals in the passenger compartments.  I have done everything medically possible to reduce my reaction but can not travel with the number of animals traveling. That is discrimination.  I would like to see a revised wording of the ADA requiring true licensed service animals to have their credentials publicly visible and available for inspection (in all public places), all modes of transportation should only allow licensed service animals in the passenger compartment (therapy animals not included as they are not covered under the ADA and should not be) and there should be a mechanism to inform people ahead of time as to a service animal traveling or if a person with severe allergies is booked, no animals can be booked.  Transportation is for people not animals and those of us with allergies are being denied this which effects or lives in many ways beyond not being able to go on vacation.  I can not work in a job that requires travel, fly for family funerals/weddings, etc..

Title: Comment from X Jenks
Comment:
Animals should only be allowed on certain flights- say every other departure of a route- so that customers with allergies, or phobias, etc can also be accommodated. This is reasonable accommodation. To allow them on every flight prioritizes the needs of one class of passenger over another, and should therefore be subject to litigation.

No one should be asked to share part of their personal space with someone else's service animal- we paid for the use of that space for our feet and bags, and the pressure to agree is unfair. If a passenger must have an oversized animal they can purchase another seat.

It is plain to anyone who flies that fraudulent support animals abound. There needs to be a federally regulated system to prevent this fraud. Other passengers should not be subject to the dangers and inconveniences of these frauds.

Title: Comment from Anonymous
Comment:
Just experienced a flight where the dog barked aggressively at the flight attendants once we were airborne. The flight attendants did not get near the dog after that. The dog was in the section where we had paid for extra foot room and he stretched out in front of 2 seats so that a passenger was unable to stretch his legs out, even though he had paid extra. The dog sat in the row in front of me and passed gas every 7/8 mins. on the 2 and 1/2 hr. flight. The stench was stifling.The dog urinated on the terminal floor before boarding the plane and on the terminal floor after getting off the plane.
The dog had a simple leash that had "service dog" printed on the leash.
I have heard that people are now delivering other people's dogs for a fee of $600 and do so knowingly that the dog is not a service dog.
Something has to be done for the traveling public.

Title: Comment from Anonymous
Comment: Seems like it wouldn't be so hard to make a rule requiring that an animal either be (1) confined to a crate/carrier the entire time it is in an airport and/or on a plane, or (2) required to wear a muzzle. If you want to fly with your animal in the passenger cabin, you pick either #1 or #2. There are even muzzles for small dogs, flat-faced dogs and cats. If your animal cannot comply with either #1 or #2, then the animal can't fly. Problem solved. Exceptions only for animals that need their mouth to perform their service, i.e. dogs that pick things up off the floor for their handlers; a small percentage of the traveling service animals would fall into this category, and it would apply to none of the "emotional support" animals.

Title: Comment from Anonyms Flier
Comment: Recently had a severe asthma attack due to a dog on a plane. While the attendants were initially kind when they saw how severe my reaction was they didn't know what to do and pretended there was no dog, but let me move farther up the plane (I imagine they were in prevent a lawsuit mode).  Then told me not to use my ventolin (albuteral) inhaler because it was causing me to hallucinate a dog (interesting side effect). Once landing and walking a long distance to avoid a security dog (I used a farther line without one) I went to an urgent care in the airport and was treated for the attack which my rescue inhaler wasn't strong enough to fight off (good treatment thankfully) without which I don't know what would happen. Next connecting flight had no pets and went smoothly. I understand there are more pet people than people with severe allergic asthma, but I would appreciate if airlines could run one pet free flight a day for us so I could fly safely, even if not conveniently, again.

Title: Comment from Stephen McIntosh
Comment:
I do not think that the law should permit the transport of animals by air except for service animals for persons with documented disabilities. Animals present unreasonable security and health risks to other passengers. Many people have allergies and clinical phobias related to animals. 

Air passengers should have the right to not be stuck, potentially right next to, an animal that causes significant distress. As much as some owners are want to claim that the animal decreases their fear of flying, it introduces new fear and hazards to their fellow passengers.

Title: Comment from Anonymous
Comment:
I'm not severely allergic to animals, but I do have mild allergy issues as well as strong phobias related to animals. Why should one paying customer have an emotional support animal in the passenger area at the expense of another paying customer having a panic attack? I can take over the counter medicine to counteract the allergies, but none of my medications can deal with being trapped with a panic trigger.

Even then, service animals for the blind, those with a medical necessity, and who have had the training and authentic certification and can be calm in a plane I can deal with. Other people can't. People with severe allergies should not have to make concessions to those who opt to bring their pets on board. How efficient and effective is the cleaning between flights? Couldn't a person with a severe allergy still be triggered into an attack with the animal hair and dander left over from previous flights? I've read comments about how no-animal flights should be run once a day, but that one plane is still contaminated from earlier flights. Better certain planes and flights be designated for those with animals while the humans get priority.

It's not fair to people with special needs, on either side of the argument. Stricter regulations so only animals that have gone through the stringent training to become service animals can come aboard is a must, but it's against the law to demand to see a service animal's official papers (to my knowledge). Certifications are being faked. No matter what happens, somebody is going to suffer.

Title: Comment from Robert Dunleavy
Comment: Emotional support animals heading for airplanes should be in carriers while in the terminal. If too large for a carrier, those emotional support animals must be kept on short leashes. This should also apply to aircraft. This is clearly a safety issue for many reasons especially in the case of an evacuation. I doubt that any evacuation test ever included emotional support animals. In those situations every second counts. Until those tests can demonstrate that these animals will not interfere with the process they should be crated.

Title: Comment from John Y
Comment:
I have a severe allergy to dogs. As many as 3 out of 10 Americans have an allergy to dogs and cats. I can die and cannot breath when on a plane with too much pet allergens. We have to consider the consideration of allergens in the air of the plane.  This regulation does not limit the number of pets on the plane nor does it provide safety for a common health issue while the number of pet owners bringing dogs on planes are increasing. This is not safe. 

source: https://www.aafa.org/pet-dog-cat-allergies/

Title: Comment from J Y
Comment:
Please care about safety of people with allergies. I have a severe allergy to dogs. I cannot breath and can die. I have met many people with mild to severe allergies. As many as 3 out of 10 Americans have an allergy to dogs and cats. I can die and cannot breath when on a plane with too much pet allergens. Please consider allergens in the air of the plane.  This regulation does not limit the number of pets on the plane nor does it provide safety for a common health issue while the number of pet owners bringing dogs on planes are increasing in the US. This is not safe. 

source: https://www.aafa.org/pet-dog-cat-allergies/

Title: Comment from Jonathan Y
Comment:
Please care about safety. I have a severe allergy to dogs. I cannot breath and can die. I have met many people with mild to severe allergies. As many as 3 out of 10 Americans have an allergy to dogs and cats. I can die and cannot breath when on a plane with too much pet allergens. Please consider allergens in the air of the plane.  This regulation does not limit the number of pets on the plane nor does it provide safety for a common health issue while the number of pet owners bringing dogs on planes are increasing in the US. This is not safe. 

source: https://www.aafa.org/pet-dog-cat-allergies/

Title: Comment from MATEAUS TUNSTALL
Comment: I am a human. Dogs are not. I paid to fly. Not have drool on my shoes. Dog hair on my clothes. Passenger next to me is not blind. So upsetting. Please change the rules.

Title: Comment from Susan Kasperski
Comment: While on a Southwest flight recently, a women with a support dog boarded the flight and took one of the last seats next to me. The women fell asleep shortly after take off; however, her dog proceeded to stand, growl and bare its teeth at me the entire duration of the flight. The entire flight crew could see the dogs agitation but all said there was nothing that could be done. To make matters worse, I have a sever allergy to animal dander and needed to retrieve my asthma inhaler but I was virtually unable to move for fear of being bit by the dog. The flight was only a short trip from Indianapolis to Chicago so I waited patiently to touch down in Chicago and de-plane; however, I could not help but wonder what I, or others, would have done if this situation would have to be endoured on a longer flight.  Not only did this situation pose a great health and personal injury risk to me, it was stressful. We must recognize the potential risk and impact to the other passengers when allowing animals to be uncaged in the cabin.

Title: Comment from E P
Comment: As a person with a disability and an anxiety disorder, I can say that fake dogs are a bane to my very existence. My dog went through 2 *years* of training and I went through three weeks of training in order to learn how to work with my dog in public. I understand people have a fear of flying but sometimes need to fly. I understand that people have anxiety. However if you have a true anxiety disorder, you can train a true service dog to help. Have an anxious few moments on a flight is a far cry from an  anxiety disorder. Service dogs only with private passengers on planes. Perhaps as a comprise, have a trained therapy dog trained to go on certain flights that are made just for really anxious people. That way there would be an animal to support the anxious people but you know it would be highly trained so it would not disturb the non-anxious passengers. I dont want to see people without support but untrained dogs being allowed public access has to stop.

Title: Comment from Dina Riccobono
Comment: Spirit and Southwest are violating the law by requiring extra seats be purchased by the disabled if their service dog does not fit under one seat or passengers do not feel comfortable being reseated. This is not the same situation for diabled or handicapped passengers with different disabilities.

Title: Comment from Audra Hendrix
Comment:
It seems to me that we need a formal process for training and certifying emotional support animals in the same way that we do for service animals.

Emotional anxiety is a real condition that can be abated by an emotional support animal. Rather than exclude individuals with an emotional need in similar categorical strength as a disability perhaps we should work towards formalizing emotional support animals and then have them fall under the same rules in the ADA.

This will necessarily exclude animals and breeds that are not of the proper temperament or body type to truly provide emotional support as a service.

Emotional needs can be as debilitating as a disability or full-blown mental illness and so we should address this issue with the idea in mind that we provide support for those individuals who truly need it.

Title: Comment from Jill Stephens
Comment:
I fully support the presence of true Service Animals in the cabin on ights, as dened by the ADA. They are highly trained, non-aggressive, and critically helpful to their owners. But emotional support animals (ESA) are a dierent story, and their preponderance in such tight, close quarters has gotten out of hand. As one of the 10-20% adults who suffer from pet allergies upon exposure, I often y in fear of being seated near one of these "support" cats, dogs or birds. Despite the animal posing a "direct threat to [my] health or safety" (Air Carrier Access Act), it seems I would have to move to avoid an asthma attack (most likely to a less desirable seat than what I purchased and perhaps even without reimbursement for the dierence). That is unfair. Again, I'm not talking about actual Service Animals  I'd gladly make accommodations for the real deal. 

My suggestions for how to improve ACAA regulations to ensure nondiscriminatory access for individuals with disabilities, while simultaneously preventing abuse and fraud are as follows:

Bring definition of a service animal in line with the ADA definition  dog (or miniature horse) trained to perform specific tasks to aid their disabled owners. The disability can be PTSD or some other emotional affliction  there are specific tasks true service animals are trained to perform in such cases.

 Provide accommodations for those with allergies  in an effort to accommodate everyone with their support animals, we've become discriminatory against this group.
