 Require people traveling with their animal to obey all rules and regs  handlers are responsible for their supervision and care at all times; the animal should not touch other passengers in any way; clean up after the animal; stay in their carriers if applicable; etc.

Title: Comment from George & Karen Duet
Comment:
Dear Sir/Madame:
 
My name is Karen Duet.  I am the founder of K-9 Companions Los Angeles and owner/founder of K-9 Companions Nashville. My veteran husband George Duet and I have been training dogs and specifically Service and Therapy Dogs for 40 years.  It is our wish to be of service to the Airline Industry as well as other businesses in the USA in straightening out the current Service Dog Industry mess.  The problem with fake Service Dogs has reached a boiling point.  This is not only an issue for businesses but also for REAL Service Dog owners who are viewed with skeptisism.
 
It is our belief that the ADA law should be changed to mandate Service ID's with trainers information.  Part of the issue is that the dog training industry is not regulated but we believe there is a solution to this which is fairly easy.  The AKC is already set up for such a task.  We would be happy to liaison for this with the AKC.  Dog trainers are concerned with political implications if one group or another takes charge.  AKC already regulates judges, has policies in place for complaints, and understands dogs.  There are certain groups that are trying to take over and create a monopoly.  We believe that the AKC can do this impartially and can create a standard that Service Dogs are trained by.  There is already and known standard for Service Dogs which is:  On/Off Leash Obedience, CGC, Minimum of 3 Service Dog Tasks, and Public Access Training with the dog being a minimum of 2 years old to be certified.  There also needs to be a minimum standard for Service Dog Trainers established.  
 
We are looking for the right person to connect with to get this ball rolling on a Federal level.  If you are interested please contact us and we will be happy to help in a way that is fair to all parties.

Attached is a copy of Service Dog Certification that we provide.  Please note:  Agency Name and Logo ID# and contact info.
 
Sincerely,
 
George Duet US Army Retired
Karen Duet PPS
Current Assignees: Fran L
Request Information:
Question or Comment:	Comment	 
Contact Information:
Last Name:	Duet	 	First Name:	Karen
Email address:	klduet@aol.com	 	Phone #:	615-939-4877

Title: Comment from Philip Zepp
Comment: As an airline pilot I would love to see this happen. I'm so tired of walking through airports with animals relieving themselves in the food areas and on my plane.  It's unsanitary and not everyone loves your annoying pets. Tired of flying around a zoo.

Title: Comment from Neil Devries
Comment: No. I travel a lot and see too many people abuse this privilege and treat it as an end around to pet transit fees. Moreover, planes arent equipped to handle large pets in the passenger area of aircraft. Lastly, people have flown in airplanes for decades without support animals and only now people need them?  This seems kind of ridiculous.

Title: Comment from Bill Brooker
Comment: I have traveled by air a lot over my lifetime - close to 2,000,000 actual miles over 35 years.  I am fully in agreement that service animals required by a disabled person should be accommodated on an aircraft.  However, I also believe all other animals should be kept out of the passenger cabin of an airplane.  People have greatly abused the "emotional support" aspect of their animal.  Honestly,  any animal not specifically trained and certified as an actual service animal is a hazard to any other passenger on the plane during an emergency.  I don't know where flying has become a right,  but it's really a privilege - that people have to agree to protect the rights and safety of every other passenger on the plane.  If people can not agree to this, then that is a conscious decision by them, and they should choose other travel arrangements,  or not take the animal on the trip with them.  Even in airport terminals where emotional support animals are to be in containers or carried at all times,  I see lots of dogs running around on leashes (and even a couple times not on leashes).  If the owners can't even obey these procedures they certainly can not be expected to follow safety protocols during an emergency.  I love dogs and have owned one for the majority of my adult life,  but that doesn't mean that they need to fly in the passenger cabin with me.

Title: Comment from Anonymous
Comment:
It makes no sense to ban peanuts and allow animals on a flight. When someone has paid for a ticket they should not be 
subject to avoidable risks from animals. Furred animals also shed and leave dander on seats and carpets. Someone with an allergy
can still be at risk if they board a plane after a dog or cat has left. Those without the correct temperament to fly unaccompanied by 
an animal should make other arrangements.

Title: Comment from Deborah Michals
Comment: As a wife of an airline pilot, I travel frequently. I am appalled at the number of people who purchase Service Animal certificates and vests in order to bring their pet on board for free. Ive seen these animals bark, and/or whine through out long flights, disturbing passengers around them. Ive seen someone who was allergic to dogs have a serious reaction. Ive seen these fake Service animals defecate, urinate, and vomit. Ive even seen one bite a passenger, all things a true Service Animal would NEVER do. Unfortunately, I think the only way to curb these abuses is to require Service Animals to be certified. First, a medical doctor, who has been treating a patient for at least a year (to avoid doctor fraud), should attest to the need to have that animal WITH the patient on a plane. Second, the animal should have a certificate of training from an accredited training program teaching and evaluating  standardized skills required to to be a safe and non disruptive animal on a plane. Third, the size and type of animal should be limited. In an evacuation a Mastiff, for example, presents a danger to other passengers. These requirements could be grandfathered in so that anyone who wants to fly with their service animal knows they need to select one of the appropriate size and type. Fourth, animals should be required to be on leash and muzzled during the flight, because ANY dog can bite when frightened or threatened. Fifth, any dog who is disruptive in any way on a flight should be banned from flying, and the owner should pay for any damages. Sixth, any passenger who fraudulently identifies an animal as a Service Animal should be banned from flying. Seventh, anyone bringing a Service aboard should have to notify the airlines when purchasing their ticket and the number of animals on a flight should be limited. There should not be more animals than flight attendants so that in an emergency, if the animal panics or is injured, flight attendants will be prepared to assist the disabled person. Unfortunately, rules are made for the idiots, as my mom used to say. We need these changes to protect the truly disabled, and the other passengers who do not deserve to face the inconvenience and danger that these dishonest, selfish people faking a disability present.

Title: Comment from Jen
Comment:
The initial reasoning behind emotional support animals was so that people could find alternate means of addressing anxiety, nervousness, etc. while flying rather than taking medications. Instead, what this means, is that many other passengers who are allergic to animals are forced to either not fly or take medications so that some else doesnt have to (this usually means an inhaler for asthma, Benadryl or other prescriptions), while reactions can take days to clear up. And since it can take at least a year to clear out animal hair and dander from a home, this means that passengers can have allergy and asthma problems even after an animal has left the plane. 

Animals should be allowed on planes in carry-on, but should not be allowed out, touching seats, passengers, or the floor. In addition, flight attendants should be given the authority to ask questions and confirm items about the people and the pet - just like they can ask for and dive into the medical history of someone with allergies. Finally, If the decision is made to continue to allow emotional support pets, airlines must include an equivalent amount of flights, at the cheapest rates, for pet-free flights. 

In addition to being a safety issue, this is a health and disability issue.

Title: Comment from Kristy
Comment: Please restrict passenger animals to only service animals that are supporting health needs of an individual.  These animals protect people who have IMMEDIATE health needs that, in some cases, can ultimately lead to death.  I am NOT in favor of emotional support animals.  While I'm sure they benefit people with mental health issues, these people do not have an immediate life or death health risk at stake.  Personally, I'm super allergic to cats and dogs and I've been on two flights where I had health issues due to an emotional support animal sitting near me.

Title: Comment from Diana Struthers
Comment:
As a service team with a CCI trained dog,  I am so thankful to have Marvin assistance each and every day.   But each and every time I go out....I feel as if I have a target on my head, not because of my disability but rather because of my service dog.  There are so many animals out there that claim to be "service" animals that now even  a service team such as Marvin and I are questioned and look down upon.  Marvin has been attacked at least 6 times, we have been refused service at multiple restaurants, refused a train seat until cunductor notified and made someone move. On several airplane trips been snapped at and barked at by "service" and or support animals, picked up another service animals shit in the eating area of a cruise ship, also attacked by this "service " dog and again treated as second class citizen due to other people passing their family pooch off as trained service animal.
I understand people wanting to take their dogs everywhere. But it's not only not fair to people with disabilities who have well trained service animals ; but also not fair to take these poor animals out into loud, busy, scary places and expect the animal to behave and stay calm.
I feel the best answer for all concerned, whether service animal  or emotional support animal who wants to access public transportation should be a required "public Access test" and certification. This could be via a government entity or using the testing already available through many service animal providers. As it is CCI makes our teams complete before graduation, at one year, and then every 3 years. Key would be to make PROVIDERS and teams responsible for inappropriate behavior in public.  Then no one could buy it over the net! Or better only certain providers could test, for$ then these providers could supply more well trained animals to disabled people like me. By the way CCI provides Service animals 100% free to those people who need them and have gone thru the application process.
I only speak about CCI because this is who I have obtained Marvin from and can't speak of other organizations. 
Also please don't say getting a public Access card would identify is as disabled...the service dog does that. 
Honestly,  I'm sure most, if not all, emotional support and or service teams would appreciate a public Access card to put a stop to the rampant abuse of false emotional and or service teams.

Title: Comment from Barbara Novak
Comment: Please ban ESA's from aircraft. By definition, they need no training so any ESA poses a potential risk to the traveling public. My husband and I have raised 11 Service Dog puppies for Canine Companions for Independence so we are well aware of the difference between Service Dogs and ESA's. Every instance of bad behavior by an ESA makes it harder for people who are disabled and genuinely need a Service Dog to have their dog accepted by business owners. Our puppies in training are accosted on an almost daily basis by ESA's and fake Service Dogs who are in public places that they should not be in. If a person is so emotionally disabled that they need an ESA they should go further and get a trained psychiatric Service Dog. Banning ESA's is an action that is long overdue.

Title: Comment from Anonymous
Comment: I think there is no reason for dogs to travel in cabin. Flights have become a horrible place to be in due to incidents like the one happened with delta. I am a person with extreme phobia towards dogs. What about my disability?

Title: Comment from Kathy Van
Comment: Emotional support is bullshit. What if carrying guns provides me emotional support and soothes me. Should I be allowed to carry them in flight?

Title: Comment from Sufyan Khan
Comment: I do not see the point of carrying your pets around in every place. Only in west do you see these many pets. Billions of people in many countries live perfectly fine without so many pets or carrying their pets everywhere around.

Title: Comment from Amanda Brandon
Comment: Emotional Support animals should travel in cargo as during the flight there is no need for emotional support.

Title: Comment from Laura Ren
Comment: People carrying service animals should be required to purchase seats for them as it can be dangerous for other people to sit right next to them. Just like I cannot transport another human being with me no matter how much emotional support he or she provides me without purchasing a ticket for him or her.

Title: Comment from Jasmine Prasil
Comment:
To Whom This May Concern:


I find that the DOT has created rules that make it a challenge for me to have access to flying all major airlines. The airline industry has made it incredibly hard to travel period imagine adding a Service Dog to the mix . I blame those that took advantage of a weak system. However, fort he past 4 years that I had my Service Dog, I have refuse to travel most major airlines and now have taken to riding trains with my Service Dog. 

As you already know most major airlines have these stipulations to fly with my Service Dogs are as follows: I need to have a signed document from a psychiatrist, veterinarian and myself (the passenger). This does not take in account a passenger that sees a licensed social worker or psychologist sporadically for many reasons (uninsured, unable to afford health care costs, transient, etc.). This is a huge issue with meeting the first criteria. No other public place requires such documentation. It is illegal for a majority of places to even require such documentation. Further, I feel that it opens up discriminatory treatment from airline crew members as psychiatric illnesses qualify for Service Dog by the ADA. 

Perhaps if crew members were properly trained there wouldn't be such issues with Service Dogs to begin with. Train them to know the ADA Law, which questions to ask people, observe dog behaviors. Granted people do take advantage of the ADA and have "fake service dogs" or people want to avoid the pet fee. Perhaps airlines can use different documentation methods. If the federal government can deem me to have a psychiatric disability - but the airline companies don't is quite odd. Further, the costs involved. I'm low income and the $200+ cost to get a documentation plus the 2-3 months in advance for scheduling. If I am taking a last minute trip the next week for a job interview in NYC and I live in Denver, then I will not be able to get the documentation in time. 

Should the DOT amend its service animal regulation so psychiatric service animals are treated the same as other service animals?  Yes. I do not want to be discriminated against because my disability is invisible. It is also impossible to purchase a ticket 12-24 hours in advance. I purchased a ticket the day before and was disqualified because of the time frame. It takes United Airlines 2 days to review paperwork. My family works in the airline industry - they get benefits and they travel last minute. I can't even travel with them because of the stress it brings my family with flying with a Service Dog due to the airline conditions. I'm sorry I can't purchase this last minute airline ticket on United for $150 because I have to fly Southwest at $500.


In the 4 years that I do fly with my Service Dog - she is well behaved to a point where crew members and passengers are amazed at her behaviors. She has internationally traveled on 13+ hour flights.

 She has saved me from panic attacks on flights to which being thousands of feet above sea level and having a panic attack is scary just thinking about i. My Service Dog sits in my lap (she is a 10 lb Service Dog) and sleeps during the flight on her pillow and blanket. I use key words - "I don't feel well" or "I'm Sick" and she will perform calming and walking assistance to get me to sit down (unless I'm on the flight). She listens to voice tone and body language - too high pitch or too low pitched - performs calming tasks and distraction tasks to regain focus or resetting my mood to not experience a panic attack or manic behavior or episode.

Either way my Service Dog has changed my outlook on life to where I can travel and she LOVES traveling too. She's an international traveler and always ready for our next big adventure together. Prior to having a Service Dog my next big adventure was being on the couch for 2 weeks straight depressed and never leaving the house.  

One huge recommendation - it'd be nice to have flight crew offer us both water. We share one cup of water together. People do not often realize that dogs do get dehydrated on planes too.

Title: Comment from April Hoyt
Comment: Please stop pets from being in the public area's of transportation, there are lot's of children who get sick around animal's, it is not fair that they can not fly when pet's are allowed to. Service dog's are ok as you are not likely to meet many but it has gotten to the point that we can not fly anymore. Thank you for listening.

Title: Comment from Rachel Peeples
Comment:
As a veterinarian and dog trainer and as someone who has often worked with service dog owners and trainers, I recognize and value the human-animal bond and the tremendous impact that animals can make on the lives of humans.  It is undeniable that thousands of people are able to live functional, independent lives despite debilitating mental and physical disease due largely to the services provided by a properly trained animal.  Service animals are absolutely essential and necessary for these individuals and mandating businesses, residences, transportation, etc to allow these animals is unarguable.  

Conversely, public safety must be preserved and every effort taken to insure that service animals do not pose a danger to other animals or humans especially given that they are allowed mandatory access to places animals typically are not allowed for safety or health reasons.   Businesses have a duty to protect their patrons in addition to the obligation to following the law regarding service animals often putting them in an impossible, unfair dilemma.   

Currently, it is as simple as a small amount of money to an online business to get a service dog vest and ID card.  No proof of needing a service dog or appropriate behavior is required.  Medical privacy laws prevent the general public or business owner from verifying the need for and actual qualifications of a service dog.  So these people are free to falsely claim their pet is a service dog - which is bad enough itself but typically these pets are as rude and as spoiled as their owners creating chaos disrupting businesses, behaving in such a way as to create health concerns in the food industry,  threatening or actually attacking people, and preventing real service dogs from performing their tasks. This is unacceptable and cannot continue. 

The problem is escalating rather than improving - self-regulation is not going to happen.  The ONLY way service animals can be allowed to function AND public safety preserved is by the government regulating service animals.  The current laws and regulations do not provide a means for minimizing fraud, for insuring that the service animals are trained properly to pose no danger to public safety, or for allowing businesses to protect the safety of their customers from untrained, false service dogs.  The government has to step in to force people to act like responsible adults.  People with true disabilities requiring a service dog to lead a functional independent life have enough hardship already - they do not need additional problems and requirements.  But, as often happens in life, the responsible have to "pay the price" for the irresponsible.  I have debated and considered many solutions and the only one that I think can be effective is the following:

(1) Some agency (perhaps the department of agriculture or the state veterinarian's office or  . . . ) has to be given responsibility to authorize/legitimize service dogs and the ability to punish those violating these procedures.  

(2) This agency through its own employees or perhaps working through professionals (for example most veterinarians become accredited to work as agents for the department of agriculture in issuing health certificates and reporting zoonotic disease)  will certify the animal is properly trained to be in public.  Again medical privacy is a concern so handling that certification while protecting privacy may be difficult.  A test such as the one that American Kennel Club offers - the canine good citizen test - might be the criteria to determine a dog is "safe for public" and the actual service work (ie seizure detection, low blood sugar detection, etc) may not need governmental approval since the government's concern is public safety not the medical aspects.  The animal's personal trainer can address the actual service work.  

(3) A legitimate medical need (physical or mental) is established via a medical care professional "prescription" with the   registering agency.  

(4) If criteria met - medical need and safe behavior - this agency would issue a service animal license to authorize access via ADA regulations.  This license, if state issued, needs to be accepted nationwide.  Without an official license - no access.  

In short - set up/assign a overseeing agency, require medical documentation for needing a service animal, certify the animal is not a public threat (graduating from recognized professional service dog trainers, has canine good citizen title, specific criteria assessed by professional such as vet or trainer, etc) then issue an official license.  Punish those attempting access without a license. 

If you have any want or need to further discuss this matter with me, I will be happy to. 

Rachel Peeples, DVM
GA VET 006294  Federal accrediation 044777
Coastal Community Veterinary Clinic
279 Briarwood Circle
Hinesville, GA 31313

Title: Comment from Christian K-9 Academy
Comment:
As professional trainers we see this as a huge industry problem. People often want to get their dog "certified" as an "emotional support animal" or "service dog" so they can take them anywhere. The truth is there is no required certification at all for any service dog. Not even dogs for the handicapped or blind have a legitimate certification of training for their dog unless it come from a private company or organization. But you can find police dogs that have state mandated certifications in order for them to work on the street.

 If the government would come up with a national certification for all types of service animals you would not have the problems you would see today. Such as a pitbull attacking a child at a terminal, or a dog being a nuisance on a flight. If there was a test that the dog had to complete Fido could prove he could be in the same area of a child without reactivity, and also prove he can withstand long flights without losing his bananas. The only way to come up with such certification is to collaborate with industry professionals.

Can a dog help with PTSD and mental issues? Of course, research has proven that, but the dog and handler should have to prove that they can do a job in any environment before going into a public setting. Just like a driver's license, handlers should also have to take some course proving they have the knowledge and capability of handle the dog.  If handler and dog both received training and earned a license problems would not occur. It would also be very easy for airlines to see who is real and who is not because it would be a license issued by the govt or DOT.

Title: Comment from Laurel Prudhomme
Comment: Fake service dogs and ESAs on flights jeopardize the potentially life-saving work of qualified, highly-trained service animals. Fraudulent service and ESAs significantly infringe upon the rights of a person with a disability, when accompanied by a service animal, to have the access granted to them by law. I strongly support the initiative to review and adjust current policies. People should not be able to apply for an ESA certificate online without even meeting the approving doctor face-to-face. Doctors who authorize ESAs without in-person consultation with applicants should face financial penalty, suspension and/or revocation of license. Airlines should require documentation stating that service animals are registered with the National Service Dog Registry and have passed their public access test. People attempting to board flights with fake service dogs and/or fabricated ESA status should be charged with fraud.

Title: Comment from Valerie Fry
Comment:
I am a Certified dog trainer. I work with Individuals training their own service dogs to help them with their disabilities. This is a daunting task to say the least. Approaching access issues is a situation altogether a different struggle. I try to help with this as much as I can. So that they do not have to fight this battle alone. It is frustrating to go into an establishment and see an untrained dog and for that dog to start barking or to be jumping on other customers, or worse have an accident in the store, and the person act like it is not their responsibility to clean up. I do believe their needs to be a standard of training a dog should be required to pass. I believe this is already in place. I believe the American Kennel Club has the best test already in place for these requirements and if these are put in place would not cost the Government anything. 

The American Kennel Club Created the Canine Good Citizen test in the 80's its a 10 part test that tests a dogs social skills. Skills around another dog, skills for being pet by a stranger, and being handled. If a dog cannot pass this test they should not be allowed in a close confined area like a cabin of a Airliner. That is putting other people in jeopardy. These flights are stressful at best. Feeling the tension from all the passengers and themselves, and in a close proximity, a CGC is a minimum requirement. 

The American Kennel Club has also created other tests sneak the Canine Good Citizen, Called, Canine Good Citizen Urban- The Pubic Access Test, I believe all Service Dogs Should pass this test. And all MY Service Dog Teams do pass this test. It is also a 10 part test but completed in a public location in realistic environment to create a real situation for a complete day of activity in the public. 

The American Kennel Club is VERY Thorough on who they allow to become Evaluators to conduct the CGC tests. a trainer must prove hundreds of training hours and teaching hours. the AKC follows up with the references submitted. Then they trainer is either accepted for denied. The trainer has to reevaluate every two years. 

The test is conducted but the evaluator with the dog and person. A dog cannot be tested until the dog is with their person and handled by their person. They will receive a certificate from the AKC proving they have passed this testing. 

Leaving things the way they are now on the honor scale is not working. People are taking advantage of others and of the airlines. We have to do something. 

Please let me know if I can answer any questions about this. And thank you for your time.

Title: Comment from April
Comment:
True there needs to be some kind of standard without hurting the people who need the animal. Many service dogs can be trained by their owners. Some naturally detect low blood sugar, ect. But what many dont understand is their service dog MUST also BE TOTALLY social to people/dogs & not be unruly when in public. 

Many people can not afford the $3-$20,000 to get their own service dog so they do their own. Perhaps if the dog can pass an evaluation before boarding to see if they are social with dogs & people(espChildren)or not,  at least they wont be a danger to any other people/dogs if they pass the evaluation. Something has to be reasonable financially & should be done at least every 6 months unless the dog passes with flying colors with NO concerns whatsoever.


Perhaps charging a small fee to pass the test for the year. What people dont understand is if their service dog is NOT social than its fearful of whats going on around them & not paying attention to their handler who may need their help & wont get it.

I, myself, am a k9 behavioral modification trainer, & I am starting a certificate program to certify service & emotional support dogs as social that is alot less expensive than service dog training & requires 6 month recerts as dogs can regress as well if socialization is not continued on a regular basis. This has come about as several of my own clients service dogs have been attacked by other "service dogs".

Title: Comment from R Wilson
Comment: I support the need of truly disabled persons to have an assistance animal on flights. What I see as a regular flyer, however, is normally anything but that. On my last flight last Friday a young husband and wife carried on a large,16 week old black lab. The husband sat next to me and explained that it was the "dogs first flight" and it had been partially sedated. This dog was not a service animal, nor was it in any container. It was a flagrant abuse of lax policies and it had no business being on a plane. The ACAA needs to be revised, as the backlash against those with legitimate needs is inevitable.

Title: Comment from Sheila Howard
Comment:
ESAs are NOT service animals and do not belong on planes. Many of us are allergic to animals, for one, and I'm sick and tired of seeing these horrible people allow their pets to poop in public areas and attack fellow passengers. Please continue your work to crack down on entitled pet owners.

Look, I get it. I love my dogs and want to take them everywhere. But if all of Americas tens of millions of pet dogs came with us onto flights, into restaurants, and other places where pets dont belong, wed have a real public health crisis on our hands.

The Americans with Disabilities Act governs access across all public places. It mandates that access must be granted to people with disabilities who need service dogs, and it provides the primary definition for service dogs: dogs trained to perform a specific task in aid of the disabled. It also says that business owners and their like may not question a disabled persons need for a service dog; they may only ask if the dog is trained to assist with a disability and which actions its trained to perform. The ADA specifically EXCLUDES access for emotional support animals. Flights should do the same.

And while we're at it, can we work on making sure that parents actually PARENT their children on flights???

Title: Comment from dontmakemesitby pets
Comment: Please do not allow any service animal or comfort animal loose in the main cabin. I have seen photos of birds, large and small dogs in the main cabin. Allergies to hair, dander and pet feathers are real! Crews do not have time to  vacuum between flights so a pet that flew just once could contaminate and affect passengers for many weeks. I would prefer all animals to ride below in cargo. Why should we have to sit in seats covered in pet hair? Peanuts are rarely served onboard to accomodate peanut allergies, which are far less rare than allergies and asthma triggered by pets.Please value humans over animals

Title: Comment from Dennis London
Comment:
As a long-time frequent flyer, I have been waiting for something like this to happen.  I've seen dogs urinate on luggage while the owner just sits there on their phone in the waiting area prior to boarding. I've seen children bitten by supposed ESA dogs and cats, I've watched some of these supposed "support" dogs (with an ESA harness on them) running through airport terminals with their owners chasing after them.  I've seen numerous dogs peeing and pooping in terminal seating areas, then watch as the owner either ignores the mess or sometimes (rarely though) let someone know that an animal made a mess and it needs to be cleaned up.  Did they say it was their animal?  NO!  

The rules definitely have to be changed.  These fraudsters need to be held accountable.  I'd actually like to see it where anyone with a service animal has to show all certifications, authorizations, or licensing for their animals prior to going through security.  For those with legitimate needs, I apologize for the inconvenience but until this gets addressed even the legit animals are going to be looked upon with a jaded lens.  And the penalties need to be harsh enough to keep the fraudsters from attempting this stuff in the future.  They are attempting to break federal laws regarding the transportation of animals...and that must not be taken lightly.  They need to be hit with more than just a little fine.  If people know their "pets" can be taken from them, they have to pay a hefty fine, and face the possibility of going to jail upon repeated offenses...then perhaps they'll stop.

Title: Comment from Anonymous Anonymous
Comment:
I have a child that is severely allergic to dogs and cats. We were going to board a plane on a layover and noticed "service animals" in line to board. I notified the airlines of my child's allergy and they asked for proof. Amazing how I carry an epipen and proof of my child's allergies (which are life threatening) but people with their pets are not required to. The airlines told me that without proof I would have to pay to change my flight or they could place us in a different part of the plane. I asked why the pet wasn't bumped or required to provide proof. In the end, we were bumped (for free). I explained that it was a no win situation for the airlines. If we flew and I had to use the epipen on my child they would be required to do an emergency landing. We missed connecting flights and had to go through a ton of hassle for someone else's pet. 

If people NEED their pets they should be required to show proof, or at a minimum have to notify the airlines in advance so other passengers can be notified. Airlines should have to notify passengers in advance of pets flying on the aircraft, and be required to make some sort of accommodations for either party to facilitate the travel. A standard needs to be established on how to handle pets as well as people who have medical or personal preferences against them.

Title: Comment from Angela Anonymous
Comment:
I have a Service dog, two actually, but when it comes to traveling I only bring one. 
A Service dog and Emotional support animal are NOT the same thing. Service dog is a well trained DOG that helps it's handler with their disability. 
An Emotional support animal is just for comfort.
I also train service dogs there is a requirement for training. There is no requirement for an emotional support animal to be trained.
As for certifications there is no certification for Service dogs or Emotional support animals PERIOD.
Some organizations give out badges for ID ONLY. The crap bought off the internet to say their dog is certified should not be accepted as ANY kind of proof of anything.
Like the FHA they require proof not of disability but of a Doctor letter or prescription saying that a Service dog or Emotional support animal/Companion animal will help mitigate symptoms or help of whatever ails the person.
This is totally legal to ask for in this situation and most people with legitimate need for an assistant animal will have this or can acquire it from their healthcare provider.
The ADA does not only protect the Service dog team it is there for the businesses also if they are educated on how the ADA works for service dogs and ESAs.
The Airline can set parameters solely based on what the ADA states and be protected by it as long as it is followed in the correct manner. This should not be so hard to understand
If the rules are followed properly the fake ones will be turned away or properly handled like any normal pet that is loaded for travel in the belly of the plane. People are going to get upset but as long as the law is followed they are just gonna have to deal with it.
If someone has an ESA or more than one they should only be allowed to travel with one, if they want more than one to travel with them then it will have to be in a carrier and considered like an ordinary pet in that instance. I believe for traveling purposes only the ESA should be limited to just a dog nothing else.
Cats are a stretch because at least you can go through training classes with a dog.
The only animals that are considered as Service Animals are Dogs and Mini horses. It is common sense that a mini horse is definitely not flying on a plane. 
I believe that an ESA especially a dog should have to go though an AKC canine good citizen class proving that it has and is going to act properly in public.
The Airline can legally ask for that certificate of training along with the Doctor letter to help minimize unruly ESAs. This is why only cats or dogs should be considered.
I don't care how many Emotional support animals someone has if you have to travel consider getting a dog that can be trained to act appropriately while traveling with you.
The Airline can put these parameters on ESAs legally because there is no standard on what an ESA is or has to do per the ADA. There are Standards for Service Animals.
I think everyone gets confused when it comes to laws of what can and cannot be said or done when it comes to Service dogs or ESAs.
Get very familiar with what the ADA says.
My personal opinion on how this should be is and I tell all my clients that documentation is the key to any legal issue.

For Service Dogs always document your training sessions, have a training log
Always have up to date shot records
Acquire a letter or prescription from your healthcare provider stating that a service dog is recommended for your treatment plan. 
Once they are ready to proceed in training I conduct the AKC Canine Good Citizen test and provide documentation that they have been through an 8 week class
We move on to more training and eventually I give a Public access test before blessing off that they have completed their training. 
Not every Service Dog owner will have this because it is not required to go through any formal training but it is what I Do for my clients. 
When I travel I have to provide my Prescription from my doctor I believe this is totally acceptable for Service dog teams


For ESAs I do not train them but this is what I would recommend
Dogs should be allowed for travel only because they can be trained to act appropriately in public
A letter or prescription from their Healthcare provider. Since they are Emotional Support Animals that tells me that they should be being treated by a mental Health doctor 
or the one who provides you your mental health medication not just any doctor. So an Ortho doc cannot give this kind of letter hopefully you get what I mean.
A current certificate of an AKC Canine Good Citizen test. It expires every year
Current Vaccination record

This is basic stuff that should be considered and is not hard to accomplish if people are in legitimate need of a Service Dog especially an ESA
A travel bag with basic essentials to care for the animal properly while traveling including wipes or something to clean up accidents because ACCIDENTS do happen.

Title: Comment from Debra Gates
Comment: As someone who works in the public transportation field, I am hoping that the guidelines for "service animals" are updated to help us sort out real from fake service animals. I drive a city bus and we have the same problem as the airlines. If someone says their animals is a service, we have to take them at their word, even when we know the animals are nothing more than a pet. I've had to remove people from my bus because their "therapy" animals growled at a passenger. I have friends who have real service animals and growling at someone is not something that is acceptable at any time. We know this, but the abuse of this regulation is rampant among all aspects of public transportation. We do allow pets on our buses if the pet is in a carrier, or if the pet is too large for a carrier, it must be muzzled. And it must be under the control of the person who brought it on, at all times. If a dog becomes disruptive it, and the person who brought it on, will be removed from the bus as soon as the next bus stop is reached. Please find a way to update your regulations so that we can put a stop to fake service animals being allowed on public transportation. It's a safety hazard to the public and it gives real service animals a black eye. Thank you.

Title: Comment from NY Artist
Comment:
I have a service dog that I personally trained.  She helps with mobility.  She's calm, doesn't interact with other humans and doesn't make any noise, drool or do anything offensive.  If she was with me in a plane (I refuse to fly because of the chemicals in the plane that make me sick, the crowding and the shady things going on with safety) she would crawl under the seat or under my feet and not move an inch for the entire flight. I would hate to see her banned from flying for any reason.

I am also a believer that dogs who are well behaved and leashed should be welcome everywhere like they are in Europe.  The USA is totally backward when it comes to dogs.  However the dogs must be well behaved and not an annoyance to anyone when in public.

Title: Comment from bob myracle
Comment: TRUE  service animals only!!!!  As tight as seating is currently, its a crazy idea to have some huge hairy animal to squeeze into an already tight space.  I was a commercial airline pilot for 30 years----todays rules are just totally out of touch.

Title: Comment from Stephanie  Anonymous
Comment:
As a breeder, trainer and dog animal lover logically the solution is licensing. 
It is sad it has come to this however this needs corrected immediately.
 Everyone has a service,therapy or  emotional support animal. 

The  solution  to this entire problem is licensing. State and Federal licenses are needed under the owners social security number. Every us citizen has a social security card or eligibility. Proof of individual liability insurance  in case the animal injures someone, does harm or damage. Require all to be registered with their state. The requirements should be successful completion of training.Skills test and a medical statement from their physician . Containment of animals within the containment guidelines. 

IF you do not do this then you are dead in the water. IT's time to end this madness for the airlines and passengers.

Title: Comment from Naomi Scearce
Comment: As a handler of an autism service dog for my teenage son, I support stricter regulations. Poorly trained and untrained dogs put our dogs at risk. Thousands of hours and thousands hours went into training our dog. All of which could be ruined in one encounter with a dog who suddenly (she's never done that before!) lashes out. Untrained dogs give our dogs a bad name and make public access harder when people eye us suspiciously.

Title: Comment from Carol Anonymous
Comment: My 10 year old daughter has a service dog for seizures. This is not an obvious disability, unless she is actually having a seizure. Just because you cant see her disability, doesnt mean she doesnt need her service dog.  Let me say it again, she has a SEVICE DOG, not an EMOTIONAL SUPPORT ANIMA!. I support and agree with the airlines cracking down on fake animals. We have flown several times with her dog (mostly on delta) with no problems. If the airline request papers provided by the trainer, i dont have a problem showing them because we have nothing to hide. I agree with the DOT and airlines cracking down on these fake dogs. It is very annoying to see a fake animal anywhere in public or on a plane because it gives the legal and legit dogs a bad name. Most of the people doing the complaining, usually have something to hide. Good job airlines, i 100% support your efforts on this matter.

Title: Comment from Connie Packard Kamedulski
Comment:
The fake service animal scam is out of control! I support more regulation of ESA and service dogs. I would propose specific training and behavior testing of service animals. The AKCs Canine Good Citizen program would be one level of nationally recognized training.

In addition, I am an active dog agility competitor. I would like to fly my dog to national competitions several days drive away. There are many of us traveling to distant competitions and I know that some of the service dog/ESA issue is related to these highly trained animals needing transportation but not in the cargo hold. I would like to see the airlines offer dog-in-cabin flights to competition sites without restrictions on size of dog.

Title: Comment from Katheryn Martin
Comment:
I am allergic to all birds, all cats and most dogs and I also travel frequently by air. I have been receiving two allergy shots a week for the last 12 years and continue to do so. I seriously doubt that all the animals I see in the airport today are actually medically necessary. I think people are abusing the current easy access to travel with their untrained, ill mannered pets.

I am particularly concerned with the way things were handled in June 2017 in Atlanta, when a huge dog attacked and mauled a passengers face while he was helplessly trapped against in the window seat.

Traveling by air is not a right but a privilege that you pay for dearly. If you have a true disability, your dog should be properly trained. It is possible that you might not be able to travel by air. It is not right to trample on the rights of all the other passengers just to accommodate one person.  I do not want animal dander floating in the confined space of an airliner, landing on my person or in my drink. 

Many passengers suffer because they are not allowed to smoke but they are told to just do without and that is acceptable. These people are addicted to nicotine and actually suffer on long flights. No one cares. This situation is no different. 

I think that something needs to be done to tighten up the requirements so that only medically needed service animals are on board . Service animals need to be trained and certified by reputable trainers. Online certifications by a "doctor" that has never seen the person or animal should not be accepted. Alternate methods of emotional support should be exhausted and documented first.

Title: Comment from Joanne Wilds
Comment: As a Veteran and someone authorized to have an ESA, I would hope that this would be taken seriously from both angles.  I realize there is "abuse" of the rules but, I also realize that there are people such as myself who benefit greatly from the ability to travel easily with a trained, certified ESA.  And I think it important to point out that one of the reasons there is "abuse" of these rules is because to travel with a pet in cabin is costly.  The airlines need to look at their own policies, and the need to make even more money off of the public.  To travel with a pet in cabin is now about $100 one way on domestic flights.  And that pet "counts" as your carry on so, in essence, those traveling with a pet in cabin are paying for their carry-on bag and also NOT allowed another carry-on.  And, that there are specific rules that have to be followed to carry that pet on top of the fees.  Maybe if the airlines were not so in need of finding yet another way to get more money out of the public, there might be somewhat less abuse of the system.  Please ask the airlines why they need to charge so much to fly a pet in cabin before you put restrictions on those of us who benefit greatly from having our ESAs.

Title: Comment from Tanya Edwards
Comment: Please consider adding all forms of public transportation. I drive for a large transcontinental bus company and the fake animals coming on board is out of hand here as well. Last month we had a women with multiple cats in a duffle bag and more in a kennel. My fear is with thechange in the air rules more unregistered non-service animals will end up on the busses. Thank you for your consideration.

Title: Comment from Gail Carroll
Comment:
As a volunteer puppy raiser for Southeastern Guide Dogs, we raise guide dogs from about 3 months old until around 15 months old.  It is important that these pups in training experience many forms of transportation and have the opportunity to become comfortable out in the "real world" when they are fully trained to be a guide or service dog for an individual with visual or other disabilities.  Flying on airplanes when they are mature enough to successfully navigate an airport and the entire flying experience is a valuable skill which will give pups confidence to lead his ultimate handler anywhere.  

In the State of Florida, Statute 413.08 covers service dogs.  Contained in this statute is a section that reads:  "Any trainer of a service animal, while engaged in the training of such an animal, has the same rights and privileges with respect to access to public facilities and the same liability for damage as is provided for those persons described in subsection (3) accompanied by service animals."

This phrase allows puppy raisers to take guide dogs in training anywhere in the State with all of the rights, privileges, and responsibilities of a working service dog.

I urge you to include guide dogs in training in your rule making on this issue.  Thank you.

Title: Comment from Jennifer Brown
Comment:
Emotional support animals should NOT be granted the same access as legitimate service dogs especially in regards to air travel.  It is my opinion that emotional support animals should not be allowed to fly except under the same rules as pets (in carriers and for fees).

The exploitation of the system by people obtaining fake documentation so that they can fly for free with their pet in cabin has caused tremendous difficulties for those travelling with well-trained and legitimate service dogs and those travelling with working dogs on official orders.  ESA/pets are not required to, and very often do not have ANY specialized training.  The also have not had training or certification for public access.  Compound that by placing them into a confined and crowded space and it is a recipe for issues including the attacks on other passengers such as seen in multiple incidents. 

Individuals with legitimate service animals are already affected by their disability and their service dog provides them with freedom and assistance despite this disability.  The ESA/fake service animal negatively impacts their access by being confronted by aggressive and untrained dogs as well as the stigma that ESA/fake service dogs are having with their poor behavior.  

As a handler of a working dog who has legitimate reason to fly on occasion with my dog for official business the ESA/fake service dogs have become a big issue for us as well.  My working dog has been lunged at aggressively by ESA/fake services animals on multiple occasions in the airport.  On planes they have been disruptive.  Because of the wide-spread issue, airlines have become much less friendly to granting access to working canines as well, and now laws are having to be introduced to protect us.  If not for the explosion and exploitation of those with ESA/fake service animals this would not be necessary.

I hope that the Department of Transportation will support changes to the Air-carriers Access Act that will eliminate ESA access and crack down on falsely representing a pet dog as a service animal.

Title: Comment from Chris P
Comment:
Is there a way to have an "access pass" of sorts for dogs that have been on a flight and did fine, if signed off on by x number of flight attendants?  

Make it possible for airport staff and flight crews to report issues that could deny a dog access to a flight or future flights?  Each dog would have to be assigned a visible ID tag, that can be read from at least 2' away, for proper identification of offenders. Different colors could be used for different purposes as well.  It could be reported (by text or calling a central number) if they see the dog barking at another dog/person, pulling constantly on leash (when that is not a specific task for the person's mobility), peeing or pooping inside, or otherwise able to articulate how the dog is not under control. If a dog gets reported X number of times or by x number of people, it's behavior would need to be assessed by someone who understands dog behavior and can evaluate whether or not the dog is suitable for flying. It could also be evaluated WHO is doing the reporting.  Such as, if one person has made reports on just about every dog they have seen, that could be an indicator that the person just doesn't like dogs or has something against dogs in airports and the reports may be bogus. This could also serve to track how many incidents of improper behavior are seen on a regular basis. The tag could be issued when the person checks in and returned when they arrive at their destination. Staff could also report GOOD behavior, so if a dog gets a boat load of good reports and only a few bad, it would help weed out bogus reports of bad behavior. 

Requiring training certificates isn't likely to work as there will just be a market for those certificates the way there is for the bogus ID cards.  So I'm not sure how to ensure or enforce the training aspect other than observing the dog/handler prior to the flight. There are also issues with cost and access for people who truly have limiting disabilities (and only disability income and lots of medical bills) in getting their dog "certified" if such a thing were required.  So it would restrict those who need it most and the fakes would find a way around it. 

Definition needs to be clear- Service Dog is TRAINED to do TASKS that mitigate a person's disability.  This can include psychiatric tasks like interrupting self destructive behaviors, body blocking, physical pressure to ground a person, etc. IF the dog and person qualify for ADA protection, it is a Service Dog regardless of the person's disability and should be treated as such.  If the dog is not trained to do tasks that help the person with their disability or the person doesn't have a disability as defined by ADA, it is an ESA. 

ESA don't have public access so they are not exposed to things that service dogs are and ESA are more likely to freak out in a confined, loud, crowded, and moving environment.  While a Service Dog, that accompanies their person to all sorts of public places, has likely encountered crowds, tight spaces, all sorts of human behavior, other dogs, etc. And is more likely to handle the flight better.  The dog's behavior, pre-flight, should give a pretty good indication of whether or not the dog is a real service dog with public access experience, or if it is a fake. 
  
Is there any way flight simulators could be available for service dog training and to ensure a dog (or person with a disability) will be able to handle a flight before they get in the air and find out they can't?  Being able to handle such a simulation could give the dog a "fast pass" of sorts. It could also help autistic kids/adults, people with fears of flying, etc.

Title: Comment from Leslie Dingwall
Comment:
The U.S. Department of Transportation, DOT-OST-2018-0068

Emotional Support Animals (ESAs) present difficulties as so many are not adequately trained  - the adorable but excited dog jumping on kids or adults, doesn't know how to deal with the public, or crowds, other dogs or animals, noise, children - may pee on the floor if they get excited may lunge at near by animals, and sometimes - may be the dog who bites an adult or a child.

A Service Dog is the one who is not barking, lunging, chasing, jumping on people, peeing on the floor (or worse) or running up to other people and dogs/animals.  It is well trained, can interact well with the public, unobtrusive, and meet the needs of and perform the tasks needed for their handlers.

We struggle with the fallout of ESAs. Their behavior can be anything from docile, semingly friendly to snarling, or aggressive, walking quietly, or bouncing off the walls.  It's like the Forrest Gump movie - they are like a box of chocolate in that you don't know what kind of behavior you are going to get.  Anyone can bring their pet anywhere and instantly claim it is an Emotional Support Animal. That can place me and my Service Dog right alonside a family pet who is not trained, not used to dealing with the public or the noise and commotion on a plane, or other dogs.  That dog might be friendly - or it might not.  That presents a danger both to my Service Dog and me.  That Emotional Suport Animal can lunge, bark at, or attack my Service Dog.  At the very least, it's actions will distract my Service Dog from it's duties. At the worst, both my Service Dog and I can be bitten.

We need some safeguards, some basic requirements for ESA's who are out and about for the protection of the public, ourselves, and our Service Animals.  A badly behaved "ESA" makes it much harder for genuine Service Dog Teams - they gives us all a black eye and people tend to give us more grief because of a previous encounter with a misbehaving ESA.

Thank you so much for inviting our input!

Sincerely, Leslie D

P.S.  Everything I have said here can also be applied to fake Service Dogs - the one where someone buys a vest online for their pet, Fido,  and tells everyone he is a Service Dog so they can take him everywhere a legitimate Service Dog might be.  They cause the same problems as untrained ESAs, and for the same reasons.

Title: Comment from Stew Chanley
Comment:
Please pass this!
I've been bitten by a so called service dog and I've had one jump up on my lap whole eating a bag of pretzles on a 4 hour flight from hell. This dog was old, unwashed and nasty. It's nuts on the airlines and is killing it for real service dogs.ENOUGH OF THIS CRAP. Stop these phony emotional support and service dogs.
Thank you, that is all

Title: Comment from Tom Johnson
Comment:
Pets should be left home when you fly on an airplane! 
All the Fake ESAs erode the legitimacy of those who have real disabilities.  Please crack down on these loop holes for fakers to exploit the poor current system.

Title: Comment from Gregory Basinger
Comment: There needs to be a HUGE crackdown on emotional assist animals.  The vast majority of emotional assist animals that I encounter on a daily basis is just a passenger circumventing paying the travel fees.  Service animals are obviously trained and well behaved to perform a service for their owner -- I am completely for that.  Unfortunately, most animals on the airplane are not well trained.  This needs to and must be stopped.

Title: Comment from Kyra Laffey
Comment:
I think that passengers should be limited to one ESA. There is no need for multiple ESAs. Passengers with ESAs should be required to submit a letter in advance from their treating physician stating they are disabled and have a disability related need for said animal. Similar to the FHA. I also think it would be reasonable to require ESAs to fit in carriers. Untrained animals that are too large to fit in their carriers present a burden and potential danger to other passengers as well as flight crew.

I think that service animals should NOT be required to provide a letter. Many service animal handlers are not in consistent treatment for multiple reasons. From simply not having the money to see doctors to having no reason to go to said doctor (for example a Deaf person does not necessarily go to an audiologist regularly because going to the doctor wont make them less deaf). I also think that service animals should include psychiatric service animals. Psychiatric service animals are held to the same standards as other types of service animals. Service animals should be limited to dogs and miniature horses. I think it is reasonable for airlines to ask the same questions that a business is permitted to ask per the ADA. 1) is that a service animal for a disability and 2) what work or tasks is it trained to perform. Legitimate handlers will be able to answer these questions. While service animals could not be kicked off mid flight for misbehavior, flight crew can be aware of the animals behavior prior to boarding. In the instance of questionable behavior, the handler should be given a chance to explain the behavior (sometimes tasking may look like misbehaving to the untrained eye), but in instances of misbehavior with reasonable belief that the animal may present danger to other passengers during the flight, it is more than reasonable to not allow to animal on the flight. 

The DOT should outright ban any ID or certification as being reasonable assurance that an animal is an ESA or service dog.

As a handler of a medical alert dog, I dont look disabled. I legitimately fear flying. Im afraid of harassment. Im afraid of other peoples untrained animals. Im afraid I wont be allowed on a flight simply because I look fine. Things need to change. But things need to change without making it harder on people who are already disabled and struggle with these issues.

Title: Comment from Anonymous
Comment: Pets should be left at home. Certified service animals trained to provide assistance to physically disabled passengers should be accommodated.

Title: Comment from Anonymous
Comment:
Non-service dogs are putting people at risk and should not be traveling freely among passengers in any public transportation. Most notably, some people have allergies, and while allergies can be minor, with just sneezing or watering eyes, others have allergies so severe that asthma attacks and eczema/hives are triggered by them. Being in close quarters with a dog is enough to set them off, and no allergic person should be forced to be in close quarters with an allergen just so that someone can travel with a pet (or glorified ESA pet). Others have phobias strong enough to trigger anxiety attacks or severe anxiety. And that's not even getting into the fact that many pets and ESAs are simply untrained or poorly trained, leading to inappropriate elimination, poor behavior, and, in some cases, outright aggression and attacks. 

Public transportation is for people, and for people's safety, we need to keep it to people only, making exceptions solely for those who need properly trained and maintained service animals, as defined by the ADA. 

Thank you.

Title: Comment from Mark Corder
Comment: Bona fide, certifiable training for any animal should be mandatory before allowing them to travel via commercial air in the passenger compartment.  There is no consideration for those with allergies to animals (of which I am one), yet it is nearly impossible to get peanuts on a flight due to those with peanut allergies.  If a person feels that he/she need their ESA at their destination, the animal can travel where a non-ESA animal normally travels on a plane.  Other forms of transportation are available to those who feel they can't fly without their ESA, just as those who are afraid of flying travel by using other modes of transportation.  Our society has evolved to the point where the vocal minority receives preferential treatment over the greater good of the majority.

Title: Comment from Anonymous
Comment: For those of us severely allergic to dogs/cats, it would be nice to see a reduction in animals on aiirplanes. Legitimate service dogs are understandable but our last flight had 5 dogs. None were service animals, only emotional support.  The people with emotional support animals also get priority seating. Something needs to change.

Title: Comment from Sherene McClellan
Comment: We are completely fed up with fake service dogs and ESA!!!  I have great empathy for the extremely small segment of folks that rely on their true service animal. All of these pet lovers who just don't want to leave Fido home are doing a real injustice to those truly in need. Let's protect the real disabled folks.  In trying to protect them from discrimination they are now the real victims in this fiasco. Get rid of the ESA sham.

Title: Comment from Anonymous
Comment:
The falsification of service dogs and emotional support animals has become epidemic. As a person with a disability and a certified dog trainer, I would make the following changes to the current regulations, the most important being a solid distinction between an emotional support animal (ESA) and a service dog (SD.) 

A service dog, including a psychiatric service dog, is specially trained in public access and to mitigate the handler's disability. For this reason, all service dogs should be allowed on all flights. It is acceptable and legal for gatekeepers to inquire about the tasks that the dog is trained to do. That would weed out the majority of fakes.

Since emotional support animals require no specialized training, they should either be banned altogether and treated as pet dogs, or required to travel in a carrier like a pet dog, because ESA's can pose a danger to passengers and service dogs due to their lack of specialized training to be safe in a public setting.  

Furthermore, one handler cannot safely handle more than one service dog, so the number permitted should be no more than one.

The same applies to ESA's; no handler can safely handle more than one. If ESA's are continued to be allowed to fly without a fee (like a pet dog), they should be limited to one. Any more than one is treated as a pet dog.

I have trained multiple service dogs for individuals with disabilities, and due to my position as a dog trainer and a person with a disability, I have been consulted by many dozens of people interested in finding out how to fly or obtain housing with their pet dog. Of the service dogs that I have trained, all have been trained to a level to be safe in public and to perform tasks to mitigate their handler's disability. 

Of the people that have contacted me regarding getting their pet dog designated as an emotional support animal, exactly zero of them needed the animal to mitigate a mental health condition prior to their desire to fly their dog or obtain "no-pet" housing. In my experience, 100% of ESA's are fake or designated as such by a person that happens to have a qualifying medical condition, solely for the purpose of obtaining housing or allowing their dog free air travel in the passenger cabin. I have never known a single person who already had a dog designated as an emotional support animal (ESA) prior to seeking air travel or housing.

To reiterate, I believe that the lack of specialized training in public access of ESA's is a detriment to passengers, crew and service dogs, including psychiatric service dogs, which are not the same as ESAs. The safety issues of ESA's far outweigh any benefit of allowing them free range on an airline flight. If a person with an ESA, who presumably would have a legitimate disability that qualifies them for an ESA, truly cannot travel without their ESA, they should invest in a trainer to ensure the animal is trained in public access and two or more tasks to mitigate the disability of the handler and enjoy all the benefits of a legitimate service dog (SD.)

Title: Comment from A Sutton
Comment:
My story
======
I have friends with guide dogs and diabetic alert dogs that have been hurt by increased regulation on service dogs. 
I would like to fly my own big and highly trained well-behaved, non service dogs in cabin .... just as is possible for small dogs today and am happy to pay for a seat for my dog. 
I have driven at great expense 4 time driven from CA to FL and back because I could not trust the airlines with my dogs, flying the dog in the hold....   
I have spoken to several people that abuse ESA because of the fear of losing their large dog if they fly as cargo/in the hold

I would suggest that you take a carrot approach to solving the ESA abuse and safety issue instead of a purely stick approach that I believe will only backfire

(1)  SUGGESTION:  Allow service dogs to be certified ONCE with the airlines  - Kind of like TSA-Pre -
WHY?   Do not subject service animal owners to 3 day delays in approving their flight. I have friends with true service dogs for whom this kind of delay and extra paperwork has become a barrier to their freedom.  What if someone with a diabetic alert dog needs to urgently visit a relative or get medical treatment via plane and can't wait 3 days?

(2) SUGGESTION:  Allow owners of well-behaved dogs (pick a certification such as AKC Canine Good Citizen)  or a temperament assessment of your choice,  to purchase a seat in cabin for their dogs to be seated in or contained in.  Make it a 1-time qualification subject to revocation if any issue occurs in flight.
  
WHY?  I believe that the majority of abuse (and I know this from talking to people that have abused ESA) is not due to the cost of flying a dog  as asserted in the proposed ruie

Abuse in fact  is due to FEAR THAT THE AIRLINES WILL LOSE OR HURT YOUR DOG. Your precious pet matters.  That is why you are flying with it.   The airlines have poor pet safety record in this regard .

While this fear persists, any regulation that you put in place will get worked around by these people and the problem will continue and will just get uglier.  In other words, you will not solve the problem with additional regulations and paperwork and inconvenience.     

You need to get inside the true cause --- To these abusers, their pets are their kids..  Ask yourself, would you want your child or grandchild to be separated from you during flight, or to travel alone in the hold of a plane?    

Or, as many of us that have sat in planes next to poorly behaved children, some carrying infectious colds.... Is a child truly better behaved or safer to be close to than a healthy, well trained dog?  My point - There is a bit of a double standard here and many dogs are truly much more pleasant to fly with than children  :-)

RECOMMENDATION: Since most well-behaved and well trained big dogs are accustomed to travelling in crates or containers,  it is perfectly OK to require that they travel in cabin, in a crate or sit in one in a seat that has been purchased by the owner, located next to their owner.  A crate would be the most safe for all concerned. The pre-req for doing this can be something like an AKC CGC certification,

(3) As to number of animals that could travel with their owner, I'd suggest 2 per traveler since many folks would like to take their well behaved animals on vacation with them but find themselves unable to due to the current airline restrictions.  2 dogs are manageable by 1 person.

Title: Comment from Holly Waldrop
Comment: I support a licensing/credentialling agency that would certify/license dogs for disability assistance or emotional assistance. There is no reason to continue to allow anyone to bring any dog, let alone any animal, on a plane just because they want to do so. I have trained and shown dogs for the last 36 years, and I have flown puppies in cabins (following all regulations to do so.) There is no reason not to 1) restrict access to dogs only and 2) require credentialling.

Title: Comment from Matthew Easton
Comment: ESAs and fraudulent service dogs on flights has been a severe safety issue traveling with my guide dog. Several times we have nearly been attacked in airports and on flights. Traveling can be stressful for any pet especially on a plane and busy airport environment. My guide dog is my mobility device and when my dog is injured because of a dog that is too dangerous to be in public, my independence is lost.

Title: Comment from Andy Glockner
Comment:
I am all for a true service animal to be allowed on board. 
emotional support animals on the other hand are a completely different story. These people have abused the system for the past 20 years and this needs to be stopped.
Dang near every flight I am on there is a dog on a lap or a cat on a lap.
these are not service animals. These are people taking their pet with them for free on vacation.
it is a disgrace to the actual service animals out there and if I'm not mistaken there are only 200,000 true service dogs in the USA.

No more emotional support animals. It's preposterous.

Title: Comment from Bridget
Comment: There are so many service dogs out there and its time to start making some rules that keep everyone safe. I have seen so many pets that get away with it and it really makes things difficult for everyone. These dogs preform tricks not tasks! I think all should have to show to a register service dog trainer that they are capable of performing such tasks. After that all real service animals should be given a pet license that can be scanned just like a human ID thats registered to a real database not some site online where you pay twenty dollars and get a certificate. This protects the handler with knowing that their dog can preform certain tasks, people who have actual facility trained service animals, airline attendants and the public from coming in contact with a fake. Please help crack down on all the fakes!!

Title: Comment from Carolyn
Comment: I have been training service dogs for veterans with PTSD for several years. Their service dogs are far more than emotional support dogs and should be allowed access, regardless of their breed. A well trained service dog of ANY breed is just that, well trained. There should be zero breed restrictions. Service dogs are trained for specific tasks and those with PTSD often have other medical issues as well that require a service dog, yet they are still considered a psychiatric service dogs? This all too often gets them put under the ESA category and gets them banned from airline travel and even hotels if they are forced to drive because they arent allowed to fly. There needs to be more control over the fake service dog industry, starting with businesses who will certify (for a price) your untrained pet as a service dog so it can go everywhere with their owner. As long as these shysters are out there, the uneducated public thinks if you dont have a certificate or an ID card that your SD isnt s Real Service Dog. I think real doctor approved ESAs should be allowed access, but in carriers and under a weight limit to fit under the seat. I believe there should be NO weight limit or breed restriction for trained service animals.

Title: Comment from Joseph C
Comment:
As a physician, I see people with both physical and mental disabilities, as well as medical problems not visible to the general public. Physical support is easy, crutches, wheelchairs, etc. 

Mental illness is different, but in the vast majority of anxiety, depression, altered mental status conditions and emotional problems the average physician, psychologist or psychiatrist would NOT recommend the first prescription would be to get an emotional support animal!

Mental-emotional health professionals use counseling, psychiatric therapy, medications and other treatments to diagnose and treat most conditions. Many emotionally stressed people actually get worse when they have to take care of and feed, groom and walk an animal. Current evidence based medical recommendations do not include an animal.

When someone takes medication or sees a psychologist, it does not impact the other 100 people inside an aircraft. When they bring a dog to calm their nerves, it can create havoc. When the animals owner expands the definition to demand hotel and restaurant accommodations for these animals, they may be breaking the law. I think the proposed rules will help both the afflicted and the passengers on airplanes everywhere, and support this enthusiastically!

Title: Comment from Judith Martin
Comment:
I have a registered and certified Therapy Dog that passed 4 hours of testing before being approved. We volunteer in the Juvenile Court system and public schools, and have for a long time.  We have no ADA rights and none are expected.  That said, I feel we need to establish some regulations as pertains to Service Dogs or ES dogs.  I have several suggestions to create a better environment for dogs who are needed to provide Health Services to their humans.

American Kennel Club already has in place a very inexpensive testing program that starts at "Canine Good Citizen".  It is low priced, widely available (and could be made moreso) with a large numbers of certified testers.  The dog must demonstrate some simple tasks of sit, stay and other basic household skills that all dogs should possess anyway.  There are a couple other skills which would also be good; added at the next level of testing such as non-reactive to other dogs and strangers, and quick recovery from a startle event.  Any dog without these skills could cause a potential problem in any public venue.

I realize cost of training might be an unfair hindrance to some who have need for a service dog.  That could be mitigated by provision of insurance coverage for a basic training and health check, or some scholarship funds provided if a doctor suggests a dog would be useful for the patient.  The AKC CGC is low priced.  My Therapy Dog certification is $30 per year and Health testing is less than $50 per year.

I fully believe in Service Dogs and the qualities of dogs that are useful to humans.  I also would love the comfort of flying with my dogs and would gladly pay for a seat on an airplane to have them calm me on a flight.  Until airlines address this desire, I will not pass my Therapy Dog off as a Service Dog.

Title: Comment from Anonymous
Comment: Due to the close quarters and possible danger posed by unregulated animals, airlines should require handlers of ALL ESA, PSA, and service dogs to have a certification from a licensed evaluator or veterinarian that states the dog has passed a test. All of those dogs should be able to be approached or handled by strangers and not react fearfully to being in novel situations. There are ways to cheaply and effectively regulate the problem without it being an undue burden to those with disabilities.

Title: Comment from George Baker
Comment: The problem is there is no government official certification for service dogs.  The fact that there are few reputable schools for service dogs of all types also lends to the problem.  I am training my own service dog due to the fact there is only one school training dogs for the disability I have in the state I live in and there are mixed reviews about it.
