If schools could be government certified, a national government test for dogs whether school or personally trained and a certificate that can be given and required to be presented upon request would solve most if not all of the problems with people trying to game the system.  Making it law that only dogs with this certificate can use any public transit or lay claim to being a service dog would put an end to abuse of the "Service Animal" issue.  For emotional support animal another set of criteria accompanied by appropriate laws should be set and again government certification.  Part of the law made should make it mandatory that all businesses train their employees of the law and what to ask for.

Title: Comment from Anonymous
Comment:
I WOULD LIKE TO THINK SOME ONE IN NEED OF A SERVICE DOG COULD TAKE A SERVICE DOG ON A AIRPLANE WITH NO PROBLEM. YOU MAY LIKE TO LET ANY ONE KNOW IF THEY HAVE A SERVICE DOG AND WANT TO FLY THEY WOULW NEED A KNOTE FROM THERE VET SAYING THERE DOG IS VET CLEARD AND IN GOOD HELTH WITH ALL SHOTS. AND A LETTER FROM THERE DOCTOR SAYING THIS DOG IS A SERVIS DOG AND WHAT TYPE OF SERVICE DOG AND WHAT IT DOES FOR THIS PERSON. OR SOME THING LIKE THAT. MOST PEOPLE THAT DOBT HAVE A SERVICE DOG WONT GET A LETTER FROM THE DOCTORE SAY IT IS.
WE HAVE A LETTER SAYING OUR JANNER IS A DIABETIC DOG. FOR ME AND DARCIE IS A DIABETIC DOG FOR MY WIFE. 
YOU CAN SEE WHAT I AM SAYING BY GOING TO ME WEB SITE AT WWW.NPMARIA.COM IF I EVER WANTED TO FLY ON A PLANE I WOULD SHOW PROFF THAT MY DOGS A SERVICE DOG.

Title: Comment from Beverly Fisher
Comment: You are causing handicapped people to use other forms of transportation, because denying their service dog on the plane you are denying the handicapped the right to fly. A service dog is an extension of it's owner, DENY ONE FLYING YOUR DENYING BOTH.

Title: Comment from Kelsea Stafford
Comment:
This regulation is too vague. American Disability Act already clearly defines what is a service dog and what is not. The key words are "task trained" which Emotional Support Animals and Therapy dogs are not. It also clearly states that the only two recognized Service Animals are "dogs and miniature horse". Majority of ESA's are the issue, for they are not required any training to make their person feel better. Service dogs on average go through 1-3 years of training and accumulate over 2000 hours of training in a year. ADA specifically states that ESA's and Therapy dogs do not have the same access rights as SDs. Service dogs allow an individual who has a disability that seriously prohibits their ability to be live as an average non-disabled person. Some service dogs even provide work that prevents loss of life such as diabetic alert dogs, seizure alert dogs, and guide dogs to only name a few. There are also psychiatric service dogs who assist our military veterans by preforming tasks such as deep compression therapy, blocking from bodily harm (cutting/suicide), and retrieving help. Bracing dogs are taught to become a standing crutch for their owners who fell out of their wheelchair, or are missing a limb. The key again is that all of these dogs are trained specifically to perform a task that mitigates their handler's disability. Majority of airlines also require prior notice to any SD teams flying through their disability assistance team. All other non-service dogs should be stowed in appropriate crates wether in the cabin or underneath. 

As it pertains to conflicting disabilities such as Allergies and another individual with a Service Dog such as guide and Medical Alert. The ADA requires all SDs to be well groomed at all times specifically reducing the risk of allergies from dander, bacteria, and such. Also more and more service dogs are becoming hypoallergenic breeds to further reduce pet allergens. If a person has a severe enough allergy to an animal it can cause them harm or death it should be well documented by allergy tests, and medical records just like a disability so there is not liability of an airplane company if one or the other has to to change seats, flights, or airlines in order to achieve both accommodations. Not everyone will be happy but they will be accommodated.

This proposal needs to be reworded with a clear definition that follows the ADA and a department wide retraining on relations with individuals with Service Dogs. For instance, simply asking "Is that a service dog?" and "What task(s) is that dog trained to perform?" the answers are a direct indicator of a valid service dog team. If they answer with "He/she helps me feel better" that is not a task and therefor would not qualify as a service dog. This does not violate HIPPA for you are not asking about the person medical history, or disability simply the dogs task training. I do not approve of this bill for it needs to be more accurate what rules, safeguards, and definitions the DOT is seeking, and RIN 2105-AE12 specifically excludes service dogs from its proposal. 

I am more then happy to further this conversation in a calm and explicit manner.

Kelsea Stafford

Title: Comment from Merry Cohen
Comment:
I am a dog lover and enthusiast.  I believe well behaved, trained dogs are a joy to be around.  But unless they have been trained and certified to be an emotional support, medical alert, and/or seeing eye dog, then THEY DON'T BELONG on the airplane.  I am also a retired flight attendant and have seen everything from "certified" "emotional support pigs" to untrained service pets of all sorts on an aircraft.  The people that are getting certificates on line, or vests on line for their "medical alert" dogs (that aren't) are going to ruin this for those people that are truly in need of traveling with their service dogs.

Seeing eye dogs are rarely small breeds  or pitty mixed breeds for obviious reasons.  We used to have qualified "trainers" come on board with the dog in training.  If it is found that dog gets air sick or cannot tolerate the enclosed spaces, that dog does not pass as a service dog.  It takes MONTHS of training and hundreds of hours of time to qualify.  PLEASE don't ruin this for the people that really need this privilege.  This is also not about SHOW dogs getting to ride in the cabin for free.  Please people.  Be sensible.

Title: Comment from Linda Berg
Comment: Both my husband and myself use owner trained service dogs. One is a mobility dog for a service related disability for my husband. His second dog as the first was retired due to age. The other trained for a medical condition I have.  Both dogs travel extensively and have been praised for their manners and attention to their partners. (us)  The American Disabilities Act already has in place reasonable and effective guidelines for service dogs. Whether they be guide, hearing ear, medical alert, or mobility. The dog MUST above all be controlled by her handler. Must NOT show any signs of aggression or present any behavior that might cause injury such as leaping at people. It appears to me that it has been so called emotional support dog who are not covered by the ADA that have been the source of troubles. These animals have no training requirements, no standard of behavior, NOTHING to define them. To compare this category of dog with service dogs who are trained to do a specific job is sheer idiocy. They are not service dogs, they have no rights under currant laws.  I personally have reported dogs obviously uncontrolled and in 2 incidents aggressive and growling at people passing.  Yet when I notified the people at the airport assistance gate of the obvious deception I was told the policy was not to risk offending customers by confronting them about their service dogs.  One of those dogs disrupted my 3 hour flight with nearly constant barking and howling. It reflected badly on all true service dogs including mine who quietly laid under the seat dozing.  We do not need more laws, we do not need government interference in the training of the dogs or what breed(s) are right for service. Many of us are on limited income and have limited resources. We do however take great pride in our well trained, well behaved, service dogs who allow us to go places and do things we could not without them.  I highly suggest not creating a knee jerk reaction ruling to the serious yet very few incidents with those emotional support animals which make the 24 hour news cycle. When every day hundreds if not thousands of service dogs quietly go about their job without incident and without the glaring light of that same 24 hour news cycle.  Instead I suggest that airlines, stores, and other public places stop being so PC stop being so afraid of offending. When they see a dog that is not controlled by her handler, when they see aggressive behavior those in authority should step up and confront the situation. Ask politely that the person remove the dog from the public area and inform them that uncontrolled and or aggressive behavior is not acceptable under the American Disabilities Act. Not only are you doing your other customers a great service for keeping them safe. You are doing those of us with service dogs an even greater service by not letting those imposters give our dogs a bad name.

Title: Comment from Luisa Robles
Comment: I think some regulation is necessary to avoid fraud, but to call certain breeds or species out for an exception seems unfair. Some disabilities are not visually detectable, such as having seizures, or diabetes; people with service animals to alert/service such conditions should not be penalized and those animals should be allowed on board.

Title: Comment from Nicole Nolan
Comment: If the airlines would just let people bring their small, caged pets as one of their 2 carry-ons, with the simple requirement that the carrier fits under the seat in front of you, instead of charging $100, $125 or more, then most of the problem of defecating, and biting animals would be eliminated.

Title: Comment from Drew McNickle
Comment:
Well, I think it's important to understand the difference between a service animal and a support animal. As service animal is task trained. Scent based service animals aid with medical conditions. An emotional support animal, while classified as a service animal, is not necessary for survival or rescue in medical situations. I have two pit-mixes trained as diabetic alert service dogs. I choose the breed because of their strength. I have MS, and the dogs are strong enough to help me if I have an MS event, such as my last episode of paralysis. I don't agree with a breed ban. However, I believe a review of what qualifies as a service animal is necessary. Paying 200 dollars to the national service dog registry does not qualify an animal as a service animal/dog. Federal law bans asking for proof of disability. The airline already has the right to refuse anyone on the plane if there is a reason to believe a problem may occur. If an animal looks aggressive, hyper, nervous, etc., the airline can refuse to allow them on the plane.
I am of the opinion a service dog should be able to aid the handler in a specific manner. If the animal is there to comfort you; it is doing what a good pet does. When your animal keeps you from dying, its a service animal. If your animal keeps you from committing suicide, you should probably stay home anyway.

Title: Comment from Suzanne Brean
Comment:
As a frequent air traveler who travels for work with a Service Dog and who has lost a Service Dog in the past due to an attack by a fake Service Dog, I have some very strong feelings.

1. Pets and Emotional Support Animals (ESA) need to stay home. They do not have the training required to be in public.
2. It should be criminal to pretend your pet or ESA is a Service Dog.
3. Psychiatric Service Dogs, which are different than an ESA by training, should be treated as other Service Dogs.
4. If a dog is showing questionable behavior it should be removed from the plane before an incidence can occur.
5. ESAs traveling on planes take up room for those of us traveling with our Service Dogs for work. This puts our trained and needed dogs at risk. 

I am aware of an incidence where a fake Service Dog was left unattended by its owner while on a plane mid flight. This dog left its seating area in coach and went to first class to attack another Service Dog which was traveling there.

As a Service Dog trainer I strongly feel that All Service Dogs should have to pass a standardize test.

Title: Comment from Peggy  Backlund
Comment: Airlines should require all non-service dogs to travel in the cargo space in an approved travel kennel. Owners with service or therapy dogs should be able to provide proof of medical necessity from a licensed health professional. If owners expect to have their dog with them in the cabin they should have a certificate of their dog having passed Canine Good Citizen training at the minimum.  If they can't afford to take their dog to obedience class, tough.  They'll have to leave them home.  Guide dogs for the blind would be an obvious exception. I have a medical alert dog who goes almost everywhere with me. He is well trained and well mannered. People who try to pass their untrained, unsocialized dogs off as service animals are making it very difficult for those of us with legitimate service dogs to travel. The proposed rules need to be clear and specific, not to define what a service dog is, but what is expected of the dog and its owner before and during the flight. They should state what proof will be required regarding the medical necessity for the dog and it's temperament and obedience assessment, etc.

Title: Comment from Dick Braun
Comment: When a person can find paperwork stating that your pet is a support animal for a set fee on line that you pay them, Your animal is anything but a support animal.  Only Service animals should be allowed and the cost from puppy to finished training is in the 10's of thousands of dollars, not less than $100 for a fake document.

Title: Comment from SuwKoeller
Comment: I am a diabetic and I have a service dog that goes everywhere with me and it's a matter of life and death is my blood sugars go too low and I pass out. He is hypo allergenic so does not bother others. I'm am covered by the ADA and therefore my  dog should be able to go with me on a plane if I choose. I've been on planes where people misbehaved children are  more difficult than any service dog I've ever been around. Should we ban small children? This proposal should never take effect.

Title: Comment from Anonymous
Comment:
ESA's should be allowed on aircraft only under the following circumstances:

1. The person needing the ESA has a disability determination through our social security administration. This would put the accommodations more in line with the ADA. 
2. A system of qualification for an ESA is put in place. For example, a minimum amount of training, a minimum age, and a requirement that the animal be spayed or neutered. Obtaining certification for the ESA should require documented proof of these things.
3. The animal must wear an ESA vest at all times when in an airport or on a plane.
4. A one strike system is set up. If an ESA puts any passengers in danger/harms them or inhibits normal aircraft operation in any way, the animal is banned from all future flights.

Title: Comment from Tami S.
Comment: As an animal rescuer/foster, I am in support of making changes regarding air travel with animals to stricter policies to reduce the number of incidences involving fake service animals that may add risk to other individuals as well as to needed and trained service dogs. Being in the rescue industry, not only have I seen the system abused, but have seen others promote the abuse of the system as a way to fly dogs for free and the abuse of that privilege needs to stop.

Title: Comment from Carol C
Comment: I know people with different types of services dogs who would find it very hard to travel without them; one is blind, the other has balance issues. That said, both dogs are highly trained to be in crowded conditions, around strangers and in unfamiliar places while remaining calm and focused. I would not want anyone who relies on such a dog to be denied easy access to air travel because of changes to the law. Nor should they have to provide strip-search-level information about their disabilities to be able to bring their animal with them. During my travels, however, I have seen dozens of dogs (no peacocks yet) who are clearly not trained the same way. A few may even have been trained as ESAs, but they didn't easily respond to commands, were nervous the entire flight, and in one case, began to whine and pace. I find it selfish and cruel that people insist on taking Fluffy along with a false claim of "she's a service dog" when hundreds of disabled people would be happy not to have to rely on their service animal for help. It's disrespectful to them, and to anyone stuck around these posers in a restaurant or on a flight having to put up with it. I hate government regulation, but there has to be a simple set of tests for certain commands that would demonstrate proper training, as well as more clear-cut documentation for proof that the animal is a necessity and not an accessory. Having a disability is difficult enough; having to constantly justify your service animal or your need for it shouldn't be necessary. Having others think it's chic or an entitlement to mimic a real need for selfish reasons just makes it worse.

Title: Comment from Tim Steele
Comment:
I agree with a review of the ACAA. As written, the vague language encourages people to bring pet dogs, many of which are untrained and are a nuisance in confined areas such as airplanes. The current language also encourages fraudulent "certification" of service and support animals. The rules should be tightened up to reduce fraudulent pet access but with sensitivity to the needs of owners of valid service animals. I'd also like to see the unreasonable breed-specific regulations of airlines addressed at the same time. If a person's legitimate service dog happens to look like a "pit bull" it should not be up to the discretion of airlines to ban the dog because of a breed's reputation in social media.

Lest anyone think I'm anti-dog, let me go on the record: I'm the owner of two small dogs who could easily be declared "emotional support animals" under the current guidelines. I'll bet I (like so many others) could find an unscrupulous mental health professional to sell me a letter stating such (or just buying a harness online that claims it's an ESA and counting on airline employees to be cowed into submission). I love my dogs and would gladly take them with me - if not for the fact that such fraud perpetuates problems for legitimate service animals. Further, I'm a dog trainer. So, my dogs are well behaved in public. And it's STILL wrong to abuse the system as so many do.

Please tighten up regulations around service animals.

Title: Comment from Macy Hunsicker
Comment:
As someone with a psychiatric service animal having one DOT-approved form (doctor and veterinarian) for all airlines and only having to update the service animal health portion annually (to prove vaccinations) would be extremely helpful. Currently I have to take forms from every airline I may possibly need to fly when I go to the doctor.

Also, I understand the concern on behavior. What if there was a program almost like TSA precheck for service animals? Those who are willing to have them "certified" or provide proof of training and evidence of solid public access skills could fly without the 48-hr notice and less paperwork so those of us who fly with their service animals frequently could do so without undue stress and those who are not willing to go through the new registration/certification process could still fly just be required to provide DOT with advance notice and the required medical and veterinarian documentation many airlines currently require.

Thank you for your consideration.

Title: Comment from Molly Rylander
Comment: I have a couple inputs; 1) airlines should not be allowed to ban certain breeds if they are Service dogs. 2) however airlines should be allowed to ban certain breeds if they are ESA's. 3) it needs to be made clear emotional support animals are not the same category as psychiatric service dogs. All service dogs welcome on the same terms weather medical alert, mobility or psychiatric service dogs. 4) honestly I'd be fine if airlines banned emotional support animals ridding in cabins but offered them to ride in cargo space. 5) all service dogs handlers should bring along a note that states their need for a tasked trained service dog, and records from the vet they are up to date on shots. 6) emotional support animals should need a doctor's note as well but needs to be dated within a month of their flight. Obviously they should need vet records as well. 7) if you continue to let emotional support animals in cabins I think it should be required for dogs to wear muzzles since it would not interfere with giving their handler comfort. However requiring service dogs to wear a muzzle would interfere with their tasks. 8) I cannot stress this enough (so much I'll say it twice) psychiatric service dogs are not emotional support animals and should be treated the same as medical alert and mobility service dogs. 9) you could require emotional support animals, if they wish for their dog to accompany them onto the cabin, to pass a good canine test provided by the airline (for free) which should include the dog preform basic obedience(sit,down,stay), a stranger walking up and petting it or being extremely close to the dog with it showing no signs of fear/aggression, the handler should also show basic control over the dog(doesnt have to walk in a perfect heel but not be lunging towards other dogs/people/kids, not barking excessively) 10) slap a fee on for ESA's to ride, no more free rides it'll deter those just wanting to bring their pet along with no real need, those who really need an ESA shouldn't mind paying a little extra. Could also require them to put a deposit down for cleaning fees, biting, etc that they could be reimbursed at the end of their flight if the Esa behaves accordingly, $200 seems reasonable to me. 11) should be made clear any ID's/ certifications/ registries are not legal and will not grant access to anyone who shows them.

Title: Comment from Barbara Correa
Comment:
I travel most of the time with a certified Emotional Support Dog, a small, sweet, well behaved poodle, who helps me manage anxiety. In addition to my own travel documents, I have to submit airline paperwork (3 forms), and health information & vaccination from the vet and agriculture. This takes an inordinate amount of time. These animals are part of our family. There are many airlines that treat me and my ESA dog wonderfully, and are welcoming and helpful. We have never had a problem at the ground level and crew. At the management level, some airlines objecting to Emotional  Service animals simply do not care about about customer satisfaction or customer service - they have been treating passengers worse than animals for years. There are many more incidents where animals are lost or die as a result of airline mistreatment, than with ESA animals misbehaving. Keep the current regulations in effect. Thank you. 

Barbara Correa
908-720-2680

Title: Comment from Donna Miller
Comment: The majority of Emotional Support Animals are because airline passengers do not want to pay the pet fee.  So they simply get a doctors note and the pet is free and considered an ESA.  True Service Animals are for the blind, etc   The problem is easily solved with Service Animals being required to get a Certificate of Service from a certified animal training company approved by the Government.  All other animals are then required to be paid for just like the Pet In Cabin owners do.  The fact that people feel entitled to their pet traveling for free has fostered the abuse of this policy.  Pay for your pet to be your emotional support and keep it under your seat just like everyone else.  So tired of how we allow and even foster this entitled behaviour.

Title: Comment from Jen Godfrey
Comment: DOT-OST-2018-0068 I strongly oppose requiring emotional support animals to be in a crate. I have been flying with an emotional support animal (dog) since 2014. I have tried to take medications for anxiety while flying but I started to need a higher dose for effective control and the medication makes me too drowsy to drive (and taxis are too expensive when the airport is an hour drive away), and I have missed flight connections while on the anxiety medication. Flying with my dog is both more effective at controlling my anxiety and doesn't cause drowsiness. I fly with a 25 pound, non-shedding, italian waterdog. She does not fit in the type of carrier that fits under the seat, nor would she effectively control my anxiety if I had to keep her in a crate, plus that is one more item to have to transport through security along with a medical device and my personal items. The current paperwork I have to fill out to fly with her with Delta and American Airlines has been easy for me to fill out, and I am fine with doing so, my only concern is if I have to fly last-minute for a funeral or family emergency, I would not be able to fill it out 48 hours ahead of time as they require. If a training requirement is added to the rule, I am concerned at how that would take shape. I have been through obedience training with her, but what makes her safe to bring in an airport and airplane and be around people, including children, is her temperament and socialization, and I don't know that any obedience class necessarily ensures that. I agree that changes need to be made to ensure passenger safety and crack down on people faking emotional support status for their pet, but I am concerned with how it will affect my ability to fly with my legitimately medically required emotional support dog. I think airlines need to provide training for their employees to identify when a behavioral issue exists that may make a dog unsafe to go on a flight with passengers, and empower them to prevent a dog from entering the airport or airplane when it displays aggressive behavior, or nuisance behavior that the owner cannot correct within a reasonable amount of time. Airports also need to be equipped with better animal relief areas, and an easier way to get to those areas when flying alone. Unexpected delays and long layovers make a potty break necessary for most dogs, but at most airports, that requires going through TSA security. This is an issue not just for emotional support animals, but service animals as well.

Title: Comment from Anonymous
Comment:
I've seen enough unruly so called ESAs to last me a lifetime. A lot of them have been aggressive and clearly have ZERO training. Documentation needs to be required including the following:

1) Documentation from a mental health provider on a letterhead stating the person needs an ESA. The airline should be allowed to verify that the person is still in practice and contact them to verify that they wrote the person a letter. 

2) A Canine Good Citizen certificate from a valid institution such as an obedience school. Passengers should be required to upload them and the airline will verify it before that person and their dog are allowed to fly. A dog that is unruly would never be able to pass a CGC test so this would cut down on the problem significantly. 


It seems like many people in the comments though feel that their allergies or fears trump the ADA. Newsflash people: they don't. If an animal is trained to perform a specific task for their handler, it IS a service animal and can go wherever its owner does. Your allergies or fears won't ever trump the ADA EVER. An airline would get sued into oblivion if they did not allow a legitimate service dog onto the plane. There ARE service dogs that help with other things besides physical disabilities such a psychiatric service dogs.

Title: Comment from Anonymous
Comment: I only travel 3-4 times a year, but I've never had any issue with a dog or cat on a flight.

Title: Comment from Dan Baierl
Comment:
It seems most misunderstandings stem from the public's confusion between a service animal and an emotional support animal.  Service animals are covered under the ADA; emotional support animals are not.  Almost any animal can be referred to as an emotional support animal.  Not true with service animals.  They require extensive training and certifications.  The most prudent solution is to ban ALL emotional support animals from public transportation, restaurants and stores while continuing to allow for service animals to accompany and assist with their disabled owners. 

Service animals are not to be approached or interacted with by the public.  They have received extensive training at substantial cost and are performing a job.  They are not to be distracted.

Emotional support animals receive little, if any training.  They provide comfort to owners but no discernible service.  

Without service animals, the disabled owner cannot fully function.  His or her life may be in danger without the services of the animal.  Without emotional support animals, the owner may be upset, uncomfortable or lonely.  He/she are still able to fully function and perform activities of daily living without risk to life or limb. 

Service animals are needed.  Emotional support animals are wanted.  Please do not confuse the two.  Ever.

Title: Comment from Courtney Wayne
Comment: I am a licensed master social worker (LMSW) with a bachelors in Psychology. Emotional support animals are valuable tools for individuals living with a variety of physical and mental health diagnoses. There are regulations protecting the rights of these individuals in hotels, apartments, and other rented accommodations that would otherwise limit or disallow animals, but restricting these animals and therefore their human counterparts from air travel is rendering them second class citizens not permitted upon the most expedient means of travel to their accommodations. For those in the general public not affected by this this proposed rule making, this is an issue of convenience and resolving an irritant. For those who will be directly affected by this proposed rule making, this is an issue of restricted access, restricted movement, and in many cases furthering the stigma of mental health through discrediting their condition and what they have found helps. In any system, there will be abuse and it is reasonable, as is currently the policy, to be asked to present medical documentation to cut down on abuse. What is not reasonable is allowing public outcry over an issue that they do not fully understand to limit the rights of those that will be directly affected in a significantly negative way by restricting access, and stigmatizing people who are just trying to get by as best they can.

Title: Comment from Michael Jon
Comment: Please lock this down. There are way too many people who have decided that they are just too fragile to be out in public without their dog. It takes away from people who legitimately need the animals. Why though should someone with pet allergies needs be any less important than someone who is afraid to come out of the house with their dog. People need to get over themselves. Its time to require specific documentation, fees and regulations other than an eBay certificate. By charging an annual registration fee for emotional support dogs, it will cut down on the self entitled liars. There should never be a fee for legitimate guide dogs though.

Title: Comment from Anonymous
Comment: I lost my father on 9/11 in the World Trade Center attacks and my Golden Retriever has to fly with me because of my panic attacks. i do not know how anyone could be so insensitive to this matter or would mind anyone being able to fly with their pets. People have real true issues.

Title: Comment from Anonymous
Comment:
I have a child who is severely allergic to dogs, and is also immunocompromised.  When traveling on an airplane, we take all available prophylactics in case a service animal is aboard.  This requires strong medications, such a steroids, that are not without side effects. Even with precautions, my son will become ill when aboard an aircraft with a dog and require further medications once arrived.
When a service animal is legitimate, i.e. used for the safety (epilepsy, diabetes) or mobility (sight) I have absolutely no objections as all citizens reserve the right of free passage.  However, when the dog is used for emotional discomfort, or for the convenience of the passenger who doesn't wish to put the animal in cargo, it is outrageous.  The emotional well being, which is a subjective experience, of another person does not trump my child's physical safety.  That passenger who feels emotionally vulnerable on a plane has other recourse, i.e. alternative modes of travel or psychiatric medication.  They should not be endangering my son's health for something that is not necessary.  I have no forewarning of their animal's presence and no recourse to alternatives once aboard.  I feel for people who are nervous aboard planes, but they are free to seek therapy, counseling, and medical intervention.  No amount of talking will change my son's immune system as it is an objective fact rather than a subjective experience.  Other people have no right to endanger my son's physical safety for the sake of their feelings.  While they may feel like they're in danger, even though they are not, their solution to perceived danger endangers my son in an actual, physical way.  Felling like one is in danger is not the same as actually being in danger.
This is my personal experience.  There are so many other reasons to support the limitation of animal passengers to true service animals.  For instance, there are many people who have an acute phobia of dogs.  The presence of a dog aboard a plane inspires true terror for them.  Why does the person with the ESA trump the dog phobic person?  To soothe terror in one person is to create it in another.
Please restrict animals aboard a plane to true service animals.

Title: Comment from Tara Murphy
Comment: I support the DOT's concern about flying emotional support animals.  There is a gross abuse of the law.  Additional regulations are needed because airplanes are tight enclosed spaces.  Any animal flying should be medically necessary and performing a service that the human can't do for themselves, ie. guiding a blind person.  Real support animals are well trained.  Emotional support animals are untrained and should not be allowed on airplanes.  Perhaps the US Dept. of justice can crack down on the online stores selling fake vests and certificates to paying customers.  This would prevent the attacks that numerous people have suffered at the hands of fake service dogs in airports and in airplanes.  Please do this!  We haven't flown in years due to fear of being trapped in an airplane with untrained animals.

Title: Comment from Anonymous
Comment: Unnecessary and illegitimate service and support animals should not be allowed on planes (or in any other public space they wouldn't normally have access to, for that matter.) Without change, more people will suffer from everything from allergies to unhygenic circumstances (dogs or other animals peeing or defecating) to outright attacks. Clever individuals may even be able to commit terror with trained attack dogs if the laws are not changed. I will never support the use of illegitimate service or support animals and it is vital that the individuals that are taking advantage be stopped, to protect everyone, especially those who actually need these animals.

Title: Comment from Stephen Phillips
Comment: Emotional Support Animals are not legitimate service animals and should be banned from cabins.  Only true, highly trained  service animals, like seeing eye dogs should be allowed in cabins, and the owner should be required to provide documentary proof of the need and training.

Title: Comment from Rebecca Stapleton
Comment: People abuse the current law and bring untrained, unwashed and unbrushed dogs onto flights all the time by just claiming they ate ESAs. For those of us with legitimate medically diagnosed allergies to dogs, this heavily impacts our ability to breathe on flights. If someone is legitimately disabled and needs their dog foot health, that's one thing. But for all of the people who just don't want to board Fido, they're negatively impacting the health of other people just by being selfish.

Title: Comment from Jackie Frenzel
Comment:
There needs to be stricter regulations on the emotional and service animals, that travel with the airline
Industry. There is wide spread abuse by passengers that dont want to pay for their pets or the pets are unable to travel due to air carrier restrictions.

I see the abuse consistently in my position as a Customer Service Agent for an airline/. The airlines could do more to slow the abuse if the Air Carrier Act was stricter on their policies.

I have numerous examples that I could document of the abuse that goes on.  The abuse just causes extra strife for the passengers that are truly in need of this service.

Title: Comment from Aurelia Stone
Comment:
Trained Service Animals provide an invaluable service to their handlers.  Though many ESA's also provide valuable support to their owners, they are specifically excluded from the ADA regulations for access.  As a traveler with a trained Service Dog, I have been appalled by the number of  people falsely claiming ESA or SA status for their untrained animals who ultimately pose a threat to the rest of us.  I have seen large dogs in the aisles, climbing all over their owners and other passengers, as well as being aggressive to me and my dog.  
I personally do not object to being asked to provide (sign) a written statement as to what task my dog performs that is necessary for my well-being.  That, combined with vet certification that the animal is healthy and up-to-date on vaccinations are all that should be necessary for a service animal.  An ESA, on the other hand, should be limited, as is the ADA, to specific animals that are trained for support.  A certified statement from the owner or trainer that the dog has passed obedience training accompanied by a current letter from a licensed physician or therapist stating need is not beyond reason.  
Recognizing fake service dog and ESA registrations and refusing them is key to keeping the integrity of the system intact.
Thank you for the opportunity to provide my comments.

Title: Comment from Sue
Comment:
There is a huge difference between a trained Service Animal and a Emotional Support Animal.  As a frequent flyer I have traveled with both.  Service Animals are so well trained most passengers are unaware they are even on board.  They are there only to do their job and service their owners.  

Emotional Support Animals are "usually" family pets that the owners want with them when they travel.  These animals have often not received the special training required to truly serve or, in some cases, to even behave.  Most people would find travel, work or visiting a dentist easier while holding or petting "fluffy" however, they should not be allowed to diminish, in any way, the acceptance of a true Service Animal.     

The last flight I took, I was in Economy Plus and my seatmate had a German Shepard with her.  She freely admitted to me that she always has her (the dog) fly in the cabin because she can't afford to have her shipped in cargo - besides the dog may be uncomfortable or injured.  So - with this person in the middle seat, me on the aisle and another person at the window we flew over 4 hours with this dog laying on the floor at our feet knowing that this person was "gaming" the system.  At least I could move my feet to the aisle for most of the trip.

Title: Comment from Marcos Arroyo
Comment:
Please eliminate Emotional Support Animals from flights.  Also eliminate pets.  They are a scourge and the statistics back that up.  They've increased substantially over the last couple years mostly due to people just wanting to travel with their pet.  I know several perfectly healthy people that got their dogs registered as ESA's strictly to travel.  They don't need to travel with them.  

I encourage you to increase the safety standards of animals in cargo and essentially eliminate animals from the cabin.

Title: Comment from Rebecca Saelens
Comment: I currently work for a major Airline and I can say without hesitation that this is getting out of control!  I understand people need Service Animals and I'm all for it but the fact that anyone can say "its my service animal and it's for medical" Or any number of issues that are not necessarily correct but because they are protected I cannot deny them.  I have had people check in their large dog and put it in a kennel to be checked as cargo only to say "it alerts to seizures" and we can't say anything.  I feel sorry for the people who actually need these animals as their service animal because most people I see are abusing it and only trying to save money.  Also, the ESAN animals are out of control.  Now our airline only wants a print out from our website with a signature - well anyone can sign these documents.  Too many people want the dogs/cats to sit on their laps and to save money from not having to pay the pet fee.  I think this needs to be looked into and stopped before its so out of hand.  What about the people who are flying and are allergic to certain dogs or dogs that are banned breeds.  All they have to do is say it's an ESAN or SVAN and then nothing is stopped.  They bring on their Pitt Bulls and any other banned breads.  It's so frustrating as an airline agent to deal with these people.  One example of an ESAN that I had was a lady traveling with her dog said it was an ESAN.  I asked for her letter from her doctor - she handed me a letter with her HUSBAND's Name on Letterhead.  He was a marriage counselor and that was her doctor that said she needed an ESAN.  We have these stories each and every day and I am tired of asking what type of service does the dog provide and where's all your medical paperwork for the ESAN.  Please do something to make these "fakes" not be able to scam the system.  If it's a service dog then we should see the training paperwork.  If it's an ESAN then there should be some sort of training paperwork for that as well.  Not a printout from a webpage that you pay 60 dollars to get a certificate and a vest.  Just my two cents....

Title: Comment from Jackie Starr
Comment:
As someone who suffers from anxiety and depression, having my ESA with me makes it possible for me to fly and be able to function at my destination. As a legitimate ESA handler, responsible dog owner, and service dog trainer in training, I have made sure to have my ESA trained to high standards. She has obtained her AKC CGC (Canine Good Citizen) title and knows more commands than many service dogs do. She is even used to demonstrate tasks to service dogs in training. I believe that a title such as the CGC (as well as a proper ESA letter, of course) should allow me to travel with my ESA outside of a carrier. I agree that there are people abusing the law; however, I believe you should also take action to protect the rights of those upholding it. I would like to see Psychiatric Service Dogs accepted same as all other service dogs, as they are trained to the same high standards. ESA's are a little trickier. I would like to see a universal form (designed by DOT specifically for airline ESA use-this way, people with ESAs do not have to pay for their doctors to fill out multiple forms depending on the airline) that needs to be filled out by a primary care physician/psychiatrist only (psychologists and LCSWs do not have the right to write prescriptions for anything other than ESA's currently, and I believe that right should be revoked by anyone other than a person who writes prescriptions-this will make it more difficult to abuse rights). As for the behavior of ESA's, I do not believe that they should be restricted to a carrier, as this would be discriminatory to people with ESA's over 20 pounds. Instead, I believe that some certificate of training should be required. For example, a CGC title shows that someone other than myself has tested me/my dog to show that she: walks well on a leash; is kind/gentle to people and other dogs; is able to handle major distractions appropriately; and knows her basic commands in high distraction environments (all without treats, I might add). This CGC test is widely offered and usually only costs a minimal fee (to get my dog tested was only $25 and the certification lasts for three years). I believe that anyone who needs an ESA (verified by a doctor or psychiatrist) and is willing to provide training certificates should be allowed to travel with their animal outside of a carrier. Please do not take away this right.
CGC Information Website:https://www.akc.org/products-services/training-programs/canine-good-citizen/

Title: Comment from Brent Walton
Comment:
It's out of hand.  There are a few problems with the existing law...

1)  Anyone can claim an animal is a ESA without having to show any proof.  When challenged or asked, they threaten a law suit under ADA, and then they typically get their way.  (I like what one pilot said to me, "If they are so fragile emotionally they need their pet, WHAT IN THE WORLD ARE THE DOING FLYING???")

2)  Consideration is not given to the comfort, health or safety of other passengers.  I for one, am deathly allergic to cat dander.  I've already taken one trip to the ER for anaphylactic shock because of a cat.  Yet, I was told by one airline boarding attendant that someone's ESA takes precedence over my allergy.  Yet, on the same flight they removed peanut products because someone had a peanut allergy.  Human passengers should ALWAYS be given precedence over other animals. 

3)  A distinction needs to be made between a service animal that is trained for a specific task (e.g. seeing eye guide dog) and an emotional support pet.  As that pilot implied, do we want someone on a flight that is so emotionally unstable that they need to bring a pet with them?

4)  While this is out of the control of the DOT, the both service animals and ESAs  should require registration.  Registration should require veterinarian certification that the animal has had all of this shots and the ability to demonstrate that the animal can remain under the owner's control in stressful situations (like boarding lines or TSA checks.)

5) Speaking of control, the airlines, and especially the flight crew, should be able to refuse service to anyone with an animal that is NOT demonstrating it is under owner control.  Such things as constant barking that is not silenced by the owner's command, growling or hissing at other people, etc.  It should also be able to reject service based on hygiene. (i.e. if the animal is emitting a strong odor.)

6) Limit the variety of animals allowed to fly.  As noted by a USDA veterinarian, service animals are almost always dogs or miniature horses.  However, people are allowed to claim any animal as an ESA  -- duck, snake, tarantula, cat, etc.  Animals that can cause emotional upset to other passengers (i.e. snakes or spiders), shouldn't be allowed -- period.

While the DOT might receive push back from the ADA proponents who claim these people requiring ESAs are protected by the ADA, perhaps Congress needs to step in an create a law that better defines what classifies an animal as an ESA, where that animal can go in public, and allow for exceptions with the health, safety and comfort of others (in this case human passengers) are at risk.

Title: Comment from Courtney DeBower
Comment:
I believe that only true, trained service animals should be allowed on planes, in keeping with the ADA. I have anxiety being around unfamiliar dogs, yet every time I travel now I have to be around someone's pet that they have called a "service animal" for their own convenience. It's inappropriate that their fake anxiety is respected more than my true fear of being around these animals. A true service animal is a remarkable thing and is easily recognizable by it's behavior. I've never had an actual service animal try to jump upon me or. I've lost track of the number of people I have heard fully admit to lying about their pets and thinking it's funny/OK. It's disrespectful to those who truly have a disability and disrespectful to the rest of us who don't want to sit next to someone's pet. These animals should be in a carrier for the whole flight. 

Recently, my husband and I watched someone put out a puppy pad so their dog could go to the bathroom on the flight right next to us. The flight attendants make it worse by refusing to say anything to these passengers. In fact, they often call the animals cute and pet them, encouraging the passengers to continue this disrespectful action.

Please take action to bring civility back to flying. There is a process for transporting pets and these people should utilize that process instead of disrespecting people with a true disability.

Title: Comment from Cyndi Gottschalk
Comment: Well trained service dogs must be able to travel with their owners.  There should be a single registry for all documented service dogs.  A dog completing a registered service class could be provided a certificate after obtaining a passing score on testing.  There are organizations such as the AKC, Guide Dogs and Therapy Dogs International  that have experience in the certified training of dogs.

Title: Comment from ZOE BASSETT
Comment:
Let me preface this comment by stating that I personally have a service dog. I am an autistic adult, and the world is often overstimulating and confusing to me, leading me to have meltdowns in public. These often escalate to me making noises which are, frankly, a disturbance, or being unable to speak at all. My service dog, Mike, is trained to make me focus during these meltdowns, by providing tactile stimulation (forcing his head into my hands,) pressure therapy, and breathing support (he has been trained to breathe deeply while I am in a meltdown state, which my body then responds to and breathes deeper as well.)

While I personally have seen issues with dogs posing as "service animals," including my service dog almost being attacked while at a pet relief area in the San Francisco airport, I am hesitant to these new regulations. I feel that they may make travel even more difficult for those of us who are disabled, in a few main ways.

Firstly, I am wary that they may pose issues for those of us who have trained their own animals. Due to financial restrictions and, quite honestly, prejudice from service dog training groups, I am one of many autistic trainers who have had to train their own animals. Most service dog trainers will not work with autistic individuals, even though there is a clear and present need for autism service dogs. Additionally, the cost of said trainers, even when one goes through the hours of searching for one who would work with them, is often prohibitive. Many autistic adults are unemployed, and it is extremely difficult to qualify for disability with an autism diagnosis.

Secondly, I am cautious about the suggestion of requiring a letter for access to a plane. This measure has not seemed to do very much in the way of deterring people from bringing "fake" emotional support animals onto the plane, so I am not sure as to why it would do anything. Currently, I could go onto roughly five different sites and pay fourty dollars to have a doctor write me a fraudulent letter. I feel that not only would this not do very much, it would be prohibitive to those of us who need service animals but are unemployed due to our disabilities, or have limited access to healthcare. I understand that these new regulations are trying to "weed" out the "fake" service animals and support animals, but I feel that they may block some that do, in fact, need them.

Lastly, I am extremely nervous about the lack of definition between psychiatric service dogs and emotional support animals. They are extremely different, both in letter and spirit. Although, yes, emotional support animals do provide support to those with psychiatric disabilities, it is absolutely nothing like the support given to disabled individuals by their service animals. Service dogs go through years of training to reach the point where they become a service dog. The amount of work poured into ensuring these animals are appropriate for both their duties and public service is frankly astounding. A support animal needs absolutely none of that training, except perhaps, for housebreaking and basic obedience. I fear that this oversight in legislation diminishes the work that goes into service dog training, in addition to becoming yet another obstacle that service dog trainers face. 

I understand that the purpose of these new regulations is not to make things harder for service dog teams or disabled individuals, but I feel that unless treated carefully and respectfully, they may do just that.

Title: Comment from Skylar
Comment:
1. Psychiatric disabilities should not be stigmatized. PSAs perform tasks just like other SAs and are covered under the ADA.

2. ESAs arent service animals. They are not trained and do not perform any tasks. They shouldnt be allowed on planes because the stressful atmosphere isnt appropriate for an untrained animal.

 3. ESAs shouldnt be on any planes, if they are allowed they must be crated/contained for everyones safety.

 4. Only dogs and miniature horses are public access service animals. Small monkeys are in-home service animals and if allowed on flight they should require proof of training because they are a huge safety hazard and non-domesticated. Emotional support animals should be allowed of any commonly domesticated species as long as they are not larger than a large dog/miniature horse.

5. Service animals should be limited to two animals per disabled passenger. ESAs should either be limited to one animal or two animals that share a reasonable sized carrier.

6. Service animal handlers should only have to provide verbal assurance and answer the two questions: Is it a service animal required because of a disability? and What task does the animal perform? ESAs should require a letter from a psychiatrist, psychologist, therapist, social worker, or similar OR proof of diagnosed psychiatric condition and a signed statement from the handler. 

 7. Service animals should be leashed or harnessed unless the handlers disability interferes with these restraints, in which case proof of other method of control may be requested. ESAs should be crated/in carriers.

8. Trained service animals cannot pose any risk to the general public or staff. 

9. Veterinarian records of proof of rabies should only be required for ESAs as service animals who are trained do not pose any threat.

10. Standards must be negotiated individually between foreign and American airlines.

Title: Comment from Anonymous
Comment: As someone with allergies to dander and asthma, I feel limiting animals onboard is important. There are other methods of dealing with anxiety that travelers have used for decades rather than bringing pets along (I know as I've done it myself). Please make the regulations much more stringent to preserve the health of all passengers.

Title: Comment from Patty Contreras
Comment: I'm tired of people abusing the law, SERVICE ANIMALS are necessary for people with disabilities, EMOTIONAL SUPPORT ANIMALS are not necessary and there needs to be a law against allowing them in all sorts of public places! I hate seeing the ESA's in grocery stores, in movie theaters and in airplanes. People who bring their pets along for the ride, not for a medical purpose, just need to leave their pet AT HOME! I believe in, and know people with, Service Animals. These dogs are trained to recognize when their owner will or has had a medical episode such as epilepsy or diabetes. ESA's are pets, not medically necessary, and should be banned from airplanes. Service animals do their JOB. You can tell the difference. A service animal is well behaved, trained, doesn't get distracted and won't piddle or poop in the wrong place. ESA's will bark, snap at others, be distracted by those around it and piddle and poop wherever they want. Airlines have a right to ask the ADA questions, What job or service does this dog provide? If someone answers, it makes me feel good, safe, fine, etc. It is NOT a Service Animal!

Title: Comment from Rosa Falu-Carrion
Comment: I am a disabled American with trained service animals. The danger for me and my trained animals is all of the faux service animals that interfere with our tasks. My dogs are already looked at with prejudice because of their breeds. I don't mind showing proof of local training certificates and even my handicap tag. Everyone should have to do the same. There should also be laws the service animals on duty should not be on retractable or extended leashes.

Title: Comment from Carrie B
Comment: Please do not change the core of ESA rules. I have health issues and absolutely cannot live without my two ESA dogs. Prior to moving into my current home, the landlord would not allow dogs until I provided my ESA information. I understand that some people take advantage, but those of us who depend on it would be devastated if the protections went away. I'd rather be homeless than lose my ESA dogs.

Title: Comment from Julie A
Comment: Banning service dogs on airlines makes as much sense as banning Honey Nut Cheerios or trail mix that contains peanuts!  Individual do not choose to be disabled, they are the victims of unfortunate circumstances and preventing them access with their service dog is cruel.  Would you be willing to put a custom piece of equipment worth thousands of dollars in the cargo hold? I doubt it!  Service dogs can cost thousands of dollars and take years to train, the airlines have a less than perfect reputation when it comes to pets as cargo, I would not trust them with anything nearly as irreplaceable as a service dog.  While allergies are a concern, are passengers currently screened to make sure that they are not carrying nut? or covered in cat hair? what about cologne? perfume?  Flying is a form of PUBLIC transportation and passengers should expect to deal with all of the ramifications that come with this type of travel.

Title: Comment from Terri Readdy, DVM
Comment:
I am a veterinarian that has the joy to care for many service dogs & therapy animals. Hate that the flood of fraudulent ESAs are interfering with the functions of these wonderful animals.  Have had to educate people regularly on the fines & jail time that can be associated with fake service dogs (but the problem is getting someone to enforce the law). The designation ESA should just go away. 
Why would anyone want to live where everyone else is going to resent the animal? All of us with pets know the emotional value to having them ... but if you cannot get on a plane without your animal in your lap you need to work with a professional to overcome your fears. Too many people using this to get out of paying fees... ESAs need to pay to get on plane, need to pay the pet deposit for housing and maybe all this fraud would go away.
Love the new paperwork I have seen requiring the owner's doctor to write the need for an ESA having to be local to the person - now make the doctor partially  financially liable when the dog bites someone or damages / destroys property.  Just like veterinary health certificates for travel the ESA designation should expire every 30 days & require renewal thru a face to face visit with a physician for all but housing situation (& that should be renewed lease by lease).
Stupid people think I am the one to declare your dog an ESA... NO ... only that it appears healthy & is fully vaccinated & protected from / treated for  parasites. Even then many people I get to see with ESA's don't consider their pets valuable enough to fully protect them in their environment again reinforcing that they are just scamming the system and it is all about the money.

Title: Comment from Anonymous
Comment:
I'm fine with trained service animals flying on commercial flights or going any place their owner has to go.  However, people are abusing the undefined and unregulated "support animal" category to fly their pet for free and take them in to restaurants and elsewhere.  Enough!  If someone desperately needs their emotional support animal, then how about requiring the animal to get specific training similar to a service animal?  All of these pets need to be trained, certified, and licensed following a specific set of guidelines.  At least that would stop the casual abuser of the system.  
There should also be random tests of doctors who have written patients letters or whatever they do to cover the pet.  Doctors caught writing up bogus "emotional support animal" letters for patients need a very expensive fine for the first offense and one-year suspension of license for the second offense. 
Airlines should require that all pet owners provide proof that the pet is a trained service animal and the airlines should be able to ask for a demonstration.  Right now, businesses are terrified to question the pet owner because the pet owner immediately threatens to sue.
Part of the training and certification system for animals should include proving they can go three hours without needing to pee or poop.  The airlines and fellow travelers should not have to see, smell, or clean up such messes.  Airlines should be allowed to limit flight time for animals.  That includes animals in carriers in the baggage hold.  If a passenger wants to travel with a pet, they should not get a flight longer than three hours.  Actual time in the plane will be longer than that anyway with loading and unloading the plane and waiting for take-off.  A three hour limit should be mandatory.  People can take two or three shorter flights.  If they truly love their animal, they should agree with this time limit.  The animal needs a break.  Or the owner can take the train or drive a car.  No more than three hours of flight time without getting off the plane. Of course, international flights are a different matter. Perhaps airlines could have a designated pet flight (one per day) flying overseas.
These service animals (inc. "emotional support animals") should be limited to dogs.  If you need such an animal, don't go getting a bird, snake, rat, cat, etc.  Get a dog trained to provide services or emotional support.  If a person loses their sight, they don't expect their cat to become a guide cat.  They get a trained guide DOG.
Airlines should be held harmless if the gate personnel or flight attendants make the determination that the animal should not get on the plane.  If the animal is visibly nervous, or smells and needs a bath, or seems to be scratching too much (fleas?), or barking, or agitated...that is a pet that is not ready to fly and will be a problem on board.  Deny boarding.
People traveling with an animal need to remember they are not the only ones on the flight.  There are also people with allergies to animals.  And there are people who are terrified by dogs.  I once saw a little girl scream for ten minutes straight in sheer terror of the cutest little fluff ball of a Maltipoo.  The dog was sitting ten feet away and didn't even look at the girl.  She went bonkers screaming and sobbing.  She just had this horrible fear of all dogs.  There are people like that in the world and they have rights, too.
People who actually own a trained service dog should agree with everything I've said here.  People who abuse the system make it harder for those with real service dogs to travel or get around.

Title: Comment from Evelyn D.
Comment:
In its concern over the rights of individuals with emotional support animals, the FAA has neglected the rights and jeopardized the health of another group of passengers with disabilities, those with allergies to animals, especially cats and dogs. According to the American College of Asthma, Allergies, and Immunology, 24 million people in the United States suffer from allergies, of which over six million are children. And according to the Asthma and Allergy Foundation of America (AAFA), in the U.S., as many as three in 10 people with allergies have allergic reactions to cats and dogs. Thus, millions of adults and children are allergic to cats and dogs, with these allergic reactions on the rise in the United States and around the world. 

What is it like to have an allergic reaction to a cat or dog? According to the AAFA, Reactions include swelling and itching of the membranes, stuffy nose and inflamed eyes.  Highly sensitive people can begin coughing, wheezing and have shortness of breath within 15 to 30 minutes of inhaling allergens. According to the Mayo Clinic, People with asthma and pet allergy  may be at risk of asthma attacks that require immediate medical treatment or emergency care. 

A recent experience that my daughter had highlights the danger. She was on a flight in which a passenger with a dog took the dog out of its carrier. When my daughter, who is allergic to cats and dogs, began having allergic and asthmatic symptoms, the flight attendant asked the passenger to put the dog in its carrier. When the passenger refused, the flight attendant, while clearly sympathetic to my daughter, told her that she couldnt require the woman to put the dog in its carrier. Apparently my daughters rights as an individual with a different disability did not need to be taken into account. Despite the severity of the situation, the dog was never required to be returned to its carrier, which might have helped, though not have solved, the problem. My son-in-law spent the duration of the flight ready to administer an epi-pen. Fortunately, my daughter managed to make it through the flight on large doses of oral medications and inhalers, though her symptoms, as is not unusual with allergic reactions, lasted weeks longer. Further, according to the Mayo Clinic, injection of an epi-pen requires follow-up to an emergency room. This would not have been possible on the plane. Even an emergency landing would take critical time, is costly, and is an inconvenience to all the other passengers on the plane.

The person with the allergy is trapped with the allergen on the plane. Air circulating makes sure that the allergens, such as dander, are spread throughout the plane. Therefore, moving to a different seat is not a viable option, as the dander is distributed throughout the plane through the planes ventilation system. Note also that dander remains on surfaces in the plane for months. 
After the flight, the airline said that for future flights my daughter can cancel her flight and reschedule it if she gets to the airport and finds an animal on board. This is not a practical solution: even if my daughter chooses to reschedule, she may get to the airport for the new flight and once again find animals on board. 

It is one thing to allow a highly trained service animal, for example, a seeing eye dog, on a plane. However, recently planes are filled with many more animals, multiplying the risks to passengers with allergies. I have more than once seen couples where each brought a pet on board; I have also seen individual passengers bringing more than one animal on board a plane. The criteria for allowing an animal on a plane need to be made much more stringent. At this point in time, anyone can go online and, for a small fee and with no real medical evidence, get their animal certified as an emotional support animal. Allowing these animals on planes is not helpful to those with true service animal needs and is dangerous to the millions of Americans, including children, who are allergic to dogs and cats. 

The bottom line is, lacking an emotional support animal can be distressing. A severe allergic reaction can be fatal. Surely it makes sense for the FAA to act now to prevent a fatality in the air and to consider the rights and health of individuals with allergy disabilities.

Title: Comment from James D
Comment:
I want to thank you for this opportunity to state my concerns about the current airlines emotional support animal program. I grew up with pet dogs and totally understand the close attachment we form with our pets and the comfort and unconditional love that they provide constantly. 

When I became a parent I looked forward to giving my children similar memories with family pets as they grew up. My eldest daughter very much wanted memories like those that I recounted with my dogs.  Unfortunately, she developed severe allergies and after consulting various allergists and researching various hypoallergenic breeds we learned that there is no breed which is safe for everyone; the only prudent decision was to deny her the pet that she very much wanted. Because of her allergies she also had to forgo parties at homes of friends who had pets and eventually had to settle for a desert iguana as her pet. 

In recent years my daughter has needed to fly frequently and has had numerous allergic reactions to animals when traveling by air. Many people believe that an allergic reaction is resolved when a person is removed from the environment that is causing the reaction. In reality, these reactions can persist for several days and do not resolve until the histamine is cleared by ones body.  One allergic reaction on a Delta flight was unusually severe, nearly necessitating the plane to make an unscheduled landing when my daughter suddenly had difficulty breathing. Difficulty breathing can quickly create a need for her to administer her EpiPen. Injecting epinephrine necessitates that one seek immediate medical care. The pilot was already in contact with ground control in order to determine how best to proceed in the event that my daughter used the Epi-Pen. However, the knowledge that injecting herself with the EpiPen would necessitate an emergency landing caused her to delay administering it longer than she may have otherwise. Except for a longer recovery period from the reaction, all turned out well... this time. 

It is unfair to jeopardize the health of passengers with allergies, nor to force them to be heavily medicated, in order to meet the needs of those who are helped by the emotional support of a pet. The current program does not consider the anxiety produced among passengers with allergic and asthmatic reactions to animals as they await the symptoms they know they are likely to experience nor does the current program consider the actual health problems for passengers with asthma when on a plane with a cat or dog.

Title: Comment from Jon Sutherlin
Comment:
Being in the airline industry, I see this problem every day I fly.  The current rule is being abused.  As a dog owner who travels with my pet often, I find it irritating to follow the rules, get my health certificate ( which is another topic altogether as they are ridiculous ), and check my dog while we allow people to scam the system, ignore the rules by taking the animal out of its travel kennel and roam the airplane at will (mostly cat owners there).   We are allowing this while ignoring the very real threat to people with allergies.  

People with real disabilities are posting that they need their animals.  I agree.  Just understand that this proposed change is not about disallowing their animals.  It is aimed squarely at those people that abuse the law as it is currently applied.

Crack down on the scammer industry, require stricter licensing of what constitutes an ESA, maybe even create a new class of ESA that defines what emotional and physical issues make it necessary for an animal to be in the cabin, but the current law is broken.

Title: Comment from Vernon Davis
Comment: If an animal is going to fly in the cabin as a service or support animal, it must have documentation that it has passed a recognized and accredited certification program. That probably means that such a program needs to be established for support animals, similar to programs for service animals.  While it is reasonable that such certification be limited to certain species, certain breeds should not be disallowed simply on the basis of their breed. The criteria must be the ability of the animal to meet clear, established standards of performance.  Non-certified animals are a danger to other passengers and crew and should be treated as such.

Title: Comment from Stephanie Berntsen
Comment: As a service dog handler, someone who has gone through extensive training, whose dog has gone through extensive training, I fully support a full ban on ESA's on flights, and a greater burden of proof that the dog is actually trained to provide a service. I will willingly do what needs to be done to prove that my dog is here to alert to my medical condition and help me function. The selfishness of people abusing the system are making travel more dangerous for me and my dog.

Title: Comment from American Airlines, Inc.
Comment: See attached file(s)

Title: Comment from Tia Langley
Comment:
People have severe allergies to cats and dogs. Knowing I might have to sit next to one on a flight has stopped me from traveling. It is extremely unfair to people with allergies that someone who wants their pet for emotional support is more important then their ability to travel. Pets should only be in cargo on the plane, period. If thats not doable for someone then they need to make other arrangements

Punishing other people because a passenger wants to cuddle their animal on a plane is EXTREMELY inconsiderate to people with Asthma and Allergies. 

This is coming from someone with anxiety, a fear of flying, and OCD.

Title: Comment from K Allen
Comment: More consideration needs to be given to paying passengers who may have allergies to pets. I am a frequent flier and recently more often than not, I have been on flights with pets that not only make me uncomfortable but also aggravate my allergies.  People are getting over by faking documents to say that their pets are emotional support animals just to get them on the plane and no consideration is given for the other passengers, but yet if someone has a peanut allergy the flight attendants asks us not to eat peanuts.

Title: Comment from Melissa Stover
Comment:
In order to protect passengers as well as the flight crew from injuries sustained from untrained service animals, the service animals need to be required to show proof of obedience training.  The American Kennel Club has a basic obedience / temperament test called the AKC Canine Good Citizen (CGC) test.   This is a well recognized organization and test with evaluators all over the United States. The test is very inexpensive and would not be a financial burden on those with service animals. The dog must demonstrate the ability to accept a friendly stranger, sit politely for petting, allow a stranger to pet, heel beside handler on a leash, walk through a crowd, sit and down on command, stay while handler walks 20 feet away, come to handler from 10 feet away, approach another person with a strange dog, remain calm with a noise or visual distraction, be calm with a stranger while handler is away for 3 minutes. The dog can never show any aggression towards another person or animal. If they can pass these items, then they are considered a Canine Good Citizen.  More advanced tests such as the Canine Good Citizen Community and Canine Good Citizen Urban are also available. 

A person with an Emotional Support Animal is required to have a letter from a doctor saying they need an animal, but it in no way indicates their animal is safe to be in public.  These animals need to be tested with the AKC Canine Good Citizen test or another similar obedience and temperament test to protect the public and legitimate service animals from untrained dogs.  This doesn't need to be regulated by each individual airline, but by the Department of Transportation.  Any person with a legitimate service animal will be happy to submit proof their animal has been evaluated and safe.

Title: Comment from Anonymous
Comment:
To the US DOT:  PLEASE, PLEASE, PLEASE STOP ALLOWING AIRLINE PASSENGERS TO BRING ANIMALS INTO THE PASSENGER CABIN OF A PLANE.
PLEASE!!!!
It is not fair for people to bring dogs, cats, birds, or any other animal onto a plane unless and only unless there is a specific physical disability for which the animal is properly trained as a service animal.
I travel very frequently and I see people who are physically fine, not incapacitated, bringing large dogs and other animals onto a plane.  This so called "emotional support" animal is a "nice to have" for that person but is an inconsiderate affront to other passengers.
These animals are usually not properly trained as a certified service animal. They are loud, rambunctious, smelly, and dangerous.
For paying passengers and taxpayers who cannot be around animals for health reasons (asthma, fear, etc) and for those who don't want to share precious legroom and foot space with an animal, it is completely unfair that their rights are being violated by people who are selfish and inconsiderate to others in bringing their pets on board a plane.
The DOT has a responsibility to taxpayers who pay for expensive airline tickets to maximize health, safety, and comfort for the majority, if not all, passengers.
To single out a few passengers and allow them to make the flying experience unhealthy, unsafe, and uncomfortable for everyone else, including staff and crew, is completely unfar.
I know many pilots who are very frustrated with the situation as well.

Thank you very much.

Title: Comment from Jodie Emerson
Comment:
Secretary  Elaine L. Chao and DOT Staff,

I am pleased you are allowing comments on proposed changes to the Air Carrier Access Act from 1986.  I have a different perspective on animals in the cabin of an unventilated transport tube- hours away from clean air.
  
I am not afraid of animals per se- however, I developed an allergy as a teenager to dogs (always had one to cats).  My health history precludes me from owning or keeping an animal in my private domain.  You see, I am one of millions that has eczema linked to asthma.  A recent example, I was nowhere near these animals and yet I was triggered by a St Bernard on a ferry ride to Mackinaw Island (sitting all the way at the front of the inside cabin- as we were sitting in the last aisle because of the rain and temperature; and, Lucy a beagle that shed and shed it's hair all over the apartment I was visiting at the time.  I tried to move away from the St. Bernard and a second couple followed me with their two doxies!  By this time, I nearly stumbled over all the passengers trying to exit the ferry to get away from the animals that were causing me to wheeze, gasp, cough, and sputter for clean air (you see- I don't travel with an inhaler- in fact it expired because I so rarely am exposed to animals).

Only now is research from Rochester, New York starting to show eczema sufferers have a missing protein from the dermis of their skin.  This actually allows hives to form if I am licked, scratched, or God forbid what would happen to me if I were bitten by an animal. Eczema is also linked to allergic asthma.
