I understand traveling with animals that are service animals.  Usually, they are well behaved and you don't even know they are present- I can wear a scarf.  The odds of having a significant reaction from the exorbitant amount of non service animals traveling truly has me troubled.  

My health insurance is geographically located to three counties in Michigan- now I would be faced with out of network health care costs wherever the plane would have to land.  The majority of these NON service dogs, or emotional support animals, are not trained at all.  They bark at other dogs and their humans are too stupid to put the damn things in their carriers.  I witness owners letting them walk on leash in the airport terminals.  Waling on leash creates more of a hazard for people with mobility issues- getting people caught between luggage, canes, walkers, and wheelchairs.

I beg of you to put teeth in the new bill.  I only want to witness SERVICE dogs in public airport terminals and on planes.  Due to my potentially deadly reaction- I do not want emotional support animals on planes.  People are selfish and rude about their emotional support animals.  My cousin's 3 year old son was approached on our property with a little dog.  I had to scoop him up and away from the lady with her dog who was saying "he is friendly", "he is the mayor of this street and wants to meet the little boy".  She droned on and on about her precious little dog as I was running away with Cole.  She couldn't understand how a child even with deathly allergies to peanuts and animals wouldn't want to meet her dog.  

You need to protect the greater good from imbeciles.  I would go one step further and decline animals in the terminal- if they can't get through the terminal- they can't get on the plane.  NO MORE EMOTIONAL SUPPORT ANIMALS in PUBLICLY FUNDED AIRPORT TERMINALS.  Besides the point they would make a great vehicle to spread a biohazard, or potentially pack unmentionables in to cause harm to the U.S..  I haven't seen animals scanned for residue.  Just saying.

Dr. Jodie Emerson

Title: Comment from Michael Brown
Comment:
I am writing to express my strong disapproval of allowing emotional support animals on commercial aircraft. Air travel is already a miserable experience and smelly ill-behaved animals that take up floor space of fare paying human passengers is unfair. 

Furthermore, how does the FAA square having these animals aboard with evacuation safety?

Title: Comment from Julie Fitzgerald
Comment:
I have Parkinson's and I have a professionally trained service dog that I purchased through a reputable Service Dog Organization.  I was on a waiting list to receive my service dog for nearly two years.  She began training at 7 weeks and had over two years of service dog training before I got her.  This training came at a price.  The cost for the dog and training was $9000.00. I take this matter very seriously.  I chose a Goldendoodle as they are as close as you can get to a hypoallergenic dog. I carry with me her vaccination records as well as certification from the Service Dog Organization so the airlines and their employees can review them.  When I book my reservation, I always include in my information that I will be traveling with a service dog. This is done well in advance.  I also request a TSA support care specialist to help us through security.

For those unfamiliar with Parkinson's, we have periods throughout the day where our symptoms are fairly "invisible" or barely noticeable but due to the unpredictability of the wearing off of medication, we can experience an "off-time" and our symptoms both motor and non-motor are very apparent.  Off times can happen at any time without warning and can be stressed induced.  I have also undergone Deep Brain Stimulation Surgery to help treat my Parkinson's.  There is no cure for Parkinson's.  It is a progressive neurodegenerative disease.

I have issues with balance and gait.  I have fallen multiple times, once at the airport before I got my service dog.  I broke my clavicle and required surgery.  This happened on my way to my daughter's wedding. 

 My service dog has been trained to alert me when there are curbs, to help me maintain my balance and in the event of a fall, act as a brace so I can use her to get back on my feet.  Service dogs are are considered medical equipment, much like a cane, oxygen tank or any other piece of medical equipment.  The airline would not separate a passenger from medical equipment that is needed during the flight.

Mobility service dogs cannot be small dogs who fit on your lap. Mine weighs 44lbs. She can curl up into quite a small space but she will not fit on my lap.  I have recently become aware that airlines may limit and/or charge additional fare for a large service dog. I have seen this policy published on the airline's website under passengers with disabilities and service animals.  I recently had a flight and was told she would not be allowed to encroach on any other passenger's personal space.  I maintain control of my dog at all times.  She does not bark or growl and does not disturb other passengers. 

I know that there are people abusing the service dog policies thereby making it difficult for those of us with real needs and real service dogs to travel with our service dogs.  It angers me when I see a dog that is clearly not a service dog on a plane or in a public space.  They are often aggressive towards my dog and me as well as others.  They are a danger to the public and should not be allowed.

Please do not place size and weight limits on service dogs.  Please make accommodations for us, so that we can travel by air safely.  I have been subjected to overweight passengers, passengers with body odor, kids constantly kicking my seat, crying and sick babies, etc. encroaching on my space.  I have never seen a flight attendant suggest they fly with the baggage because there are size and weight limits, because they are encroaching on my space or disturbing me.  Please do not discriminate against a service dog due to its size or weight.  Do not allow airlines to determine what it "too big or weighs too much" and do not allow them to charge us extra for traveling in the cabin with our service dog.

I have done everything the right way, purchased a trained service dog from a reputable Service Dog Organization, vaccinations are current, have documentation stating she is a trained service dog and notified the airline well in advance I would be traveling with a service dog.  It is discriminatory and cruel not to allow a large service dog to accompany its owner and perform his/her duties for the protection of their owner.  

Airlines have made seats smaller and smaller to accommodate more  and more passengers and to quite frankly make more money.  They need to be required to have seats with areas that can accommodate their disabled passenger's service dogs that do not fit on the passenger's lap. We the disabled need the protection of federal laws much like the ADA fair housing laws that protect us from paying extra fees for service dogs and allow us to take them into public places. 

Having Parkinson's and being disabled is hard enough, please do not add to the challenges we face daily.

Title: Comment from Richard Bloom
Comment: I know it is a late comment but as a passenger I feel that in most cases those traveling with service animals result in a significant safety hazard to other passengers seated next to them by blocking access.   Individuals with service animals exceeding 20 pounds in weight and that cannot be held in the lap should be required to book seats in the row where they are sitting to accommodate the animal proportional to the size of the animal from the window out..  unless the animal can fit under the seat in front, constrained in a carrier.

Title: Comment from Jacob Gillard
Comment:
Thank you, thank you, thank you for reviewing this issue. It is way past time to clean up the flying barnyard. We are tired of the filth and fecal matter. People are getting hurt. It is not fair to the animals.

Stop the fraud. Selfish imposters just want to fly with their pets. They are on the verge of wrecking this for those with real needs. Authentic and well trained service animals are a superb asset to society and those with genuine disabilities. The flying public is not heartless and has no problem making reasonable accommodations in these cases.

When it comes to emotional support animals the rational solution is a total ban. It is not possible to define an objective standard let alone implement and enforce policy that is not open to flagrant abuse and compromises passenger safety.

Title: Comment from Vanessa Romero
Comment: I particularly like animals but find it very unfair and ridiculuos for people who doesn't like animals or is allergic to them to have to sit next to one. Its just like having to sit next to a smoker person when you are a non smoker. This is common sense... an animal is an animal regardless if it is well behaved or not. I have seen these pet owners letting their animals go freely around the cabin and bothering other people. I think is disrespectful. You pay your ticket to sit next to a person... Not an animal. Perhaps a solution could be to have a section on the plain dedicated to people traveling with animals so when you buy your ticket you know for sure you will not be sitting next to an animal if you dont want to unless you buy a ticket from this special section. It is lile a waiver of some sort... At least it wont catch you by surprise

Title: Comment from Nate I
Comment: If you are blind or have a physical disability (i.e. seizures) and have an actual service dog, it should be allowed on a plane. All other pets including emotional support animals should be banned. While I can appreciate emotional support animals can be beneficial to their owners, too many people abuse the definition of what an emotional support animal is. Its not fair for a plane full of rule abiding passengers to have to deal with a fraudulent support animal and its owner. If someone needs their support animal that badly, they can drive. I am not willing to risk my safety or that of my children potentially getting bit by a strange dog on a plane.

Title: Comment from Nic Mac
Comment: I was traveled back to NY after vacation and there were about 10 service animals on board.  The dog that I sat next to could not fully fit under the seat of it's owner. When I had to get up to use the bathroom she had to get up and try to coax the dog to get up. The amount of time it took I was almost ready to wet my pants. Now what happens if this is an emergency and I have to get out in a hurry? I'm told I can't keep my  handbag in the row unless it's under my seat. At least I can kick my handbag out of the way in cases of an emergency, definitely not the case for a 150 lb service animal. There has to be consideration taken for the safety of other passenger when making the rules about service animals. I think size should definitely  be limited.

Title: Comment from Matt Freeman
Comment: Two of the largest carriers, United Airlines and Delta Air Lines, restrict Emotional Support Animals (ESAN) to flights less than eight hours. This is a change from previous DOT regulations that permitted an ESAN on any flight provided that the passenger did not allow "unsanitary" animal waste. This rule, imposed by United and Delta, places an undue burden on passengers who need ESAN animals PARTICULARLY for longer flights. I trained my dog to travel back and forth to Europe and the Middle East without urinating or defecating in the airport or cabin. This has not been a problem for me nor for United. This rule is also somewhat disingenuous: many domestic flights have delays, short connections with inadequate time for pet relief, and other barriers that result in a travel time far longer than eight hours. Moreover, the eight-hour rule means that I can fly with my dog TO Paris but cannot fly BACK due to variations in flight time and travel direction.  It seems reasonable that the air carrier could ask a vet to "vouch" that the animal is well-behaved, or just be reasonable and leave the passenger accountable for the animal's actions.

Title: Comment from lucian siepielski
Comment: I have been attacked twice by dogs. I am therefore uncomfortable and afraid of animals. Sitting next to a animal makes be anxious and fearful. Therefore my comment is that there be a procedure in place where the airlines can be notified that I do not want to sit next to or have immediate contact with animals. This could be done by notifying airlines by phone or entry is an online section of the reservation that I do not desire sitting next to a animal.

Title: Comment from Anonymous
Comment:
I am an asthmatic with severe allergies to cats and dogs (among other animals, my allergy is to animal dander). I manage my health by taking daily medication and avoiding any allergy and asthma triggers. Being enclosed in a metal tube with recirculated air with animals is an issue for me. My last trip I had to endure this on three of the four legs of my flight. I didn't speak up about this to the airline as I was afraid the resolution to this problem would result in my being kicked off the flight due to my medical issue. Our destination has only one flight in and out per week so it was imperative we made the flights or our entire vacation would be missed. I stayed quiet, suffered the symptoms and had to fight health issues which altered our schedule the days following the flight.

I thought we lived in a human world where human services accommodated humans, not animals. Now I am finding myself dodging businesses and scenarios where people feel the need to drag their pets along. Don't get me wrong, pets are great and I really wish I could have a dog but I don't believe pets have any business being in public, let alone on an airplane. I know people claim some of these animals to be service animals but in the past few years "service animals" have popped up EVERYWHERE. I don't believe the majority of these animals are true service animals, they don't appear to be serving a purpose or carrying out a task required by those toting them other than hitching a free ride alongside their owner on the flight.

What about those of us with animal dander induced asthma and/or allergies? Where are our rights to not be subjected to illness-inducing environments? We don't seem to have any say on this topic and yet this affects us quite profoundly. I can't find out a flight has animals on it until I turn up at the gate to board the flight and then it is me, the paying customer, who either has to reschedule or suffer the health consequences. I believe this has gone too far. Pets belong at home, not sitting next to me in a Starbucks or on a plane. Something needs to be done to ensure the animals whom are flying are true service animals.

Title: Comment from Anonymous
Comment: There is a difference between a service animal and an emotional support animal. There is also a difference between my quiet, well-trained dog and your annoying, screaming toddler. Emotional support animals should behave appropriately and our rights to travel with them should be protected.

Title: Comment from James Wright
Comment:
The existing rules distinguishing between (i) psychiatric service dogs ("PSDs") and emotional support animals ("ESAs") and (ii) other kinds of service animals under the ACAA are needed, and the additional documentation requirements for traveling with PSDs and ESAs should not be relaxed.  

While there are virtually no reported instances of people self-determining that they need or outright faking, e.g., guide dogs for the blind, or alert dogs for seizures or hypoglycemia, or mobility support dogs, the number of people who decide that they want to bring their pets with them and therefore that they will take the position that their mental state is a qualifying disability, and that their dog's making them feel better when they're sad is a task to mitigate that disability, is substantial - as a person who has invested considerably in a service dog for my own, non-psychiatric disability and who participates in the service dog community, I see this on a daily basis.  

That, as combined with the substantial number of web sites offering to provide letters prescribing a PSD or ESA for a few dollars, where no competent medical professional has actually made a psychiatric diagnosis, let alone concluded that such a diagnosis is of sufficient severity to qualify as a disability (since surely not every psychological diagnosis is a disability, but in the PSD community, it is clearly treated as such), renders the treatment of PSDs and ESAs as no different than other types of service animals problematic.  

It is, unfortunately, trivially easy, *too* easy, to assert (and obtain medically unsupportable documentation for the idea) that you need a PSD or ESA, in response to which anyone who wants to bring their pet with them can now trivially easily falsify that.  And unlike with other categories of service animals, they *ARE* falsifying it, in large numbers, perhaps larger than the number of legitimate PSDs.  I have witnessed countless faked "service animals" in grocery stores, restaurants, and other areas and listened repeatedly to their owners overtly falsely characterizing animals clearly not trained as such.

And the effects of this on legitimate service dog owners are substantial.  Inadequately trained or faked PSDs have attacked many trained service dogs, causing them to have to be removed from service at the cost of tens of thousands of dollars and years of waiting for a replacement with reduced quality of life to disabled persons with service dogs.  They have also attacked numerous people, including airline passengers.  Furthermore, the presence of inadequately trained or faked PSDs and ESAs in other public access situations has resulted in tremendous damage to businesses and to distrust for legitimate service dog owners and consequent discrimination.

In short, it is hard to fake being blind, or epileptic or diabetic, or in a wheelchair - and there simply is no large scale systematic problem with people faking these conditions, and no need to impose additional burdens on these disabled individuals - but it is trivially easy to fake a psychiatric disability and even to find businesses to support this fakery, and people are taking advantage of that in substantial numbers.  Relaxing the treatment of PSDs and ESAs by airlines will exacerbate this problem.  Please maintain the distinct requirements for documentation of ESAs and PSDs under the ACAA.

Title: Comment from Helping Hands: Monkey Helpers
Comment: See PDF attached.

Title: Comment from Anonymous
Comment:
I think that psychiatric service animals should be treated the same as other service animals, such as for the blind and deaf. Those with a psychiatric disability should not be singled out. Everyone has the right to be treated fairly and who is to say a psychiatric disability is not as severe as a physical one. Someone with a psychiatric disability needs their service animal just as much as any one else with a disability. You cannot tell the extent of someone's disability just by looking at them. 

Although emotional-support animals (ESAs) are different then service animals, when it comes to travel an emotional support animal may be just as important as someone's service animal. Travel can cause a lot of people anxiety and these people have a right to have their animal with them. The point of having an ESA is to provide support in times of anxiety and distress. If travel is one of these times then some one with an ESA needs to have their animal with them. However ESAs need to be well behaved as well as service animals.

ESAs should be able to travel in a container or with a harness or leash. The person with an ESA needs to use their judgement as to which is going to work for them. I think it is reasonable to require a container be present incase it is needed but for some people their ESA isn't going to be able to help them if they are not able to be removed from their container during travel. 

Types of animals qualifying as ESAs should be defined to prevent people from taking advantage of the system and trying to bring something inappropriate with them. I think common house hold pets that are mammals can be considered ESAs (no reptiles, birds, insects, etc.)

Airlines should require veterinary health forms and immunization records for service animals because this is a basic safety matter. If an animal cannot be vaccinated for a health reason then a vet can state that on their form. All animals need to have a vet so it is reasonable to require a vet health form. Vets should have the right to determine if an animal is safe to travel. That safety includes the animal, handler, other passengers, and other animals. Health and safety are two things vets are highly trained in.

Title: Comment from Anonymous
Comment: I have severe reactions when exposed to animal hair/dander to include breathing problems, flushing, hives, itching, and my throat closing over.  Thus, I choose to no longer fly on U.S. carriers within the United States. Formerly, I was a frequent flyer and have been flying commercially worldwide my entire 58 years of life with zero problems. Now, due to all the animals inside U.S. aircraft, I feel as though I've lost fair access to air travel.  Please help me and fellow allergy sufferers regain the right to fly unencumbered, breathing re-circulated cabin air free from animal-related irritants, along with carpeting and fabric seats free from animal hair/dander.

Title: Comment from Katherine  Brown
Comment:
I have allergies to both dogs and cats. I also have asthma, as an adult I've grown out of it but pet allergies trigger it, especially cats. My asthma as a child was severe and when triggered I must use a rescue inhaler or I struggle to breathe.

I regularly travel and the increase in animals on planes has been noticeable. On a recent United flight from Boston to Houston, a passenger in my row got up to go to the bathroom. Her small dog got out of its carrier case, the lady next to me was scared and the dog crawled across her. I had to hold the dog until the lady returned from the bathroom. The dog fortunately did not trigger my asthma, I just had minor allergy symptoms, sneezing and had irritated eyes.

The returning flight to Boston, my asthma was triggered and I needed to take my inhaler due to pet allergies. I think airlines need to regulate what animals can be brought on board more stringently and notify passengers early on. All passengers need comfort during a flight, including those with allergies and ones who need emotional support. Those who need an emotional support animal should be restricted to approved flights and planes.

Title: Comment from Mary Zack
Comment: I have a small service, emotional support animal that has traveled with me for nine years. She stays in her kennel during all flights and in the airport.  Most folks do not even know she is there.  I have complied with all documentation including the new regulations. Emotional  support is equally as critical as physical disabilities.  No flight attendant wants or needs to deal with someone out of control mentally when something as simple as a calming influence,(dog) is there to anticipate issues and make a remarkable difference.  I understand the need to apply regulations, however, please bear in mind that many times flying to a destination for someone with a variety of issues is the only option they have.  Do not let a small percentage of people not conforming to regulations affect the majority of us who do follow the rules.

Title: Comment from Anonymous
Comment:
Pictures in lieu of 1,000 words very respectfully submitted.
Thank you for your consideration!

Title: Comment from Denise Michels
Comment:
Mr. Ronald Jackson, DFO
Office of the Secretary
US DOT
1200 New Jersey Avenue SE
Washington, DC 20590

Dear Mr. Jackson,

Please consider adding this language in 49 CFR Part 29:
"DOT Secretary shall issue regulations governing the TTSPG program for each subsequent Fiscal Year under this program 
in accordance with the Negotiated Rulemaking procedures under sub chapter III of Chapter 5 of Title 5."

This proposed rule was drafted by tribal representatives from all 12 regions and other Tribal Transportation entities with 
knowledge of Self-Governance and the Tribal Transportation Program. Once the rule is adopted, any proposed changes to 
the final rule should follow the Negotiated Rulemaking Process. 

Thank you for the opportunity to comment on this proposed rule.

Sincerely,
Denise Michels

Title: Comment from TAPCO
Comment:
January 11, 2019

Office of the Secretary (OST)
U.S. Department of Transportation (DOT)
1200 New Jersey Avenue S.E.
Washington, DC 20590 

Regarding Docket No. DOT-OST-2018-0210, Request for Comments:  V2X Communications

Dear Madam Secretary:

TAPCO is a Wisconsin based, family owned, industry-leading manufacturer and distributor of traffic and parking safety systems that improve safety for all road users. Since 1956, we have provided reliable, innovative, and intelligent safety solutions for communities in all 50 states.  Innovations like the LED-enhanced BlinkerSign or Wrong Way Warning Systems, shown to reduce wrong-way driving incidents by 38%.  New CV technologies are an area in which TAPCO has invested.  In 2019, TAPCO continues to advance intelligent road safety with its new CV Interface, to better inform and alert connected vehicle drivers about the road ahead.  We are excited about deploying these new CV products that can help more road users experience Safe Travels.  We appreciate the opportunity to comment on the developments in V2X technology and the Departments role in encouraging the integration of V2X.

Whereas DSRC is a proven, reliable, and mature technology platform, and deployment of DSRC represents the quickest and most efficient way to begin realizing the expected safety benefits of vehicle-to-vehicle and vehicle-to-infrastructure communication, TAPCO believes the US DOT should provide industrial policy leadership in establishing DSRC as a US industry standard, to eliminate commercial uncertainty and unleash pent up commercial investment and development, bringing benefits of accelerated deployment and economies of scale to municipal and state agencies as they modernize roadway infrastructure.  

Nascent alternatives to DSRC are several years from having infrastructure deployed in even the most densely populated cities, and will require additional years of development, pilots, and testing to occur before their safety benefits are achievable.  During this time, countless lives will be impacted by hazards that DSRC technology is able to mitigate today if it is deployed.

We believe a Department-lead, DSRC based standard for CV in the US would provide the fastest path for the US to commercialize and lead an industry, as well as realize the potential community and traveling safety benefits for all road users in the US.

Sincerely,



Jason Kugel
Owner

Title: Comment from Lake County Division of Transportation
Comment:
January 16, 2019
Finch Fulton
Deputy Assistant Secretary for Transportation Policy
Office of the Secretary (OST)
U.S. Department of Transportation (DOT)
1200 New Jersey Avenue S.E.
Washington, DC 20590
Re: Comment Request for Docket No. DOT-OST-2018-0210
Dear Deputy Assistant Secretary for Transportation Policy Fulton:
We would like to thank the USDOT for opening the dialogue on the complex and technical issues that are inherent to the connected vehicle discussion. Traffic congestion impacts the quality of our daily lives  time spent frustrated in traffic backups means less time with our families. The Lake County Division of Transportation provides a safe and efficient transportation system within Lake County, Illinois. 
In our opinion, connected vehicle technology should be going in the direction of 5G or Cellular-V2X. Using Dedicated Short-Range Communications (DSRC) has a significant financial impact on larger agencies and multiple-agency collaboration like Lake County PASSAGE. Cellular-V2X has the potential to be used in conjunction with central traffic signal system software or Advanced Transportation Management Software (ATMS), in which Signal Phasing and Timing (SPaT) data can be sent to vehicles via 5G for more accurate data sharing in real time.
We would like to raise our comments in the attached V2X Communications Comments document. If there are any questions or we can be of any assistance, please contact myself at jeffinger@lakecountyil.gov or (847) 377-7474. 
Sincerely,
Justin R. Effinger, PE
Principal Engineer

Title: Comment from Next Generation Mobile Networks
Organization Name: Next Generation Mobile Networks e. V
Comment:
The Next Generation Mobile Networks e. V. (NGMN) hereby submits the following comments in response to the Office  of the Secretary, Department of Transportation (DOT) s Notice of Request for Comment. 

In a letter from the NGMN board members to the European Commission, NGMN strongly recommends to adopt a forward-thinking, technology-neutral approach in developing the EUs C-ITS strategy. The letter, addressed to EC President Jean-Claude Juncker, calls upon European legislators to reconsider the current EC Delegated Act and include C-V2X on the list of potential technologies that European stakeholders may pursue and allow the market to decide which technology prevails. The board urges that given its importance, the Delegated Act adoption should not be rushed but conducted in transparent consultation with all stakeholders. A recent white paper on V2X technology published earlier this year by NGMN is also included, outlining the advantages of cellular technology over the less desirable Wi-Fi technology.

Both documents are in our opinion indispensable to answer the US DoTs Request for Comments.

Title: Comment from Marilynne Martin
Comment:
The Docket Summary states:

"Over the past several years, the Department of Transportation and its operating administrations have engaged in numerous activities related to connected vehicles, including vehicle-to-vehicle (V2V), vehicle-to-infrastructure (V2I), and vehicle-to-pedestrian (V2P) communications, collectively referred to as V2X communications. "

Let me point out that the one critical activity the DOT did not do yet. They did not ask the people - yes the actual drivers - whether they wanted connected cars and whether they wanted to pay the enormous costs of the infrastructure to support such a project. I offer my vote - NO - I do not want it and deeply resent your activities to mandate these radios in our cars.

Second, this document discusses whether we should use DSRC or V2X communications. As a member of the public I vote for any radio that will be easily able to remove or disable. That is the best radio.

Third, you need to understand that there is a percentage of our population that are electrosensitive and their bodies can not tolerate to be in close proximity to them. Don't take my word for it, let me quote the Cities of Boston and Philadelphia from their comments submitted to FCC Docket 13-84 where they state:

"The FCC admits its own lack of expertise in the field. But the overlap of federal agency responsibilities for RF radiation protection and the merely advisory status of the Radiofrequency Interagency Work Group often leaves leadership unclear and encourages a pass-the-buck attitude ...
 
The 1999-2000 judicial challenge to the FCCs 1996 rules never reached the issue of electrosensitivity as a cognizable disability under the Americans with Disabilities Act. (ADA) Here again, an agency responsible for ADA implementation acknowledges that the impairment may be disabling but has promised merely further inquiry. After more than a decade, that investigation remains unopened. The dockets here have been updated with massive additional evidence of the crippling effects of RF radiation on an admitted minority  but a suffering minority  of U.S. citizens. The FCC and its sister regulatory agencies share responsibility for adherence to the ADA and should replace promises with serious attention to a serious medical problem. This is one area where the FCC could lead in advice to electrosensitive persons about prudent avoidance." http://bit.ly/1kAYSu7 

A suffering minority, let that sink in. Placing the massive amount of radios and radar in these cars is going to kill them. Show some compassion. What you are planning to do is analogous to a school district claiming all kids must eat lunch in school, the school will set the menu, Thursdays will be peanut butter & jelly sandwiches and every child must eat it - no exceptions. We will stick Child Protective Services on all parents who try and home school their children with peanut allergies.

Technology is not safer than Humans.

Title: Comment from Warren Woodward
Comment:
I do not want to have or pay for connected vehicles and their required infrastructure.

The only acceptable radio in cars are the ones that can be easily turned off or removed.

Technology is not better than human drivers. Computers crash too!

Title: Comment from Alexandra Ansell
Comment:
I do not want to have or pay for connected vehicles and their required infrastructure.

Title: Comment from Garril Page
Comment:
This action will restrict my ability to purchase an automobile as I will not purchase a connected vehicle.  I do not wish to be required to pay for other drivers connected vehicles either:  if  others wish to buy these vehicles, that is their choice; however,  I object to my money either enabling or coercing other purchasers individual selections.
  
People should not be forced to purchase vehicles with features they find undesirable.  When I want a car without a radio, that should be my option.   Alternatively, I should have the choice to disable or remove any radio feature without rewiring a vehicle.  When I am offered a new vehicle without any such options, I do not purchase it.

I am unconvinced that technologically controlled vehicles are safer than those with human drivers.  If all cars were unmanned it might be feasible to create completely unmanned vehicular traffic flow, although I doubt that cold be so.  As long as there are humans and automated vehicles interacting, there will be disconnects.  Adding disruptive radio messaging is a random distraction that increases the  potential for accidents. My money and my purchasing power will remain with vehicles over which I have purchasing choices re features and control.

Comment:

2.	The only acceptable radio in cars are the ones that can be easily turned off or removed.

Comment:
There is no justification for attacking our health in at least a dozen ways by exposing us radar radiation.  The only way to test such radiation for safety is to do biological safety testing, something that has not been done.  The FCC safety guidelines are a joke, having been falsified by thousands of studies and cannot, therefore be used to support any safety claims.  

I am a widely published, widely cited scientist doing important research in this are and I have given 45 invited professional talks in ten countries on this EMF health impacts.

Martin L. Pall, Professor Emeritus
martin_pall@wsu.edu

Title: Comment from Gary Thomas
Comment:
The tremendous cost to implement V2X technology and necessary infrastructure should be borne by the providers who will profit from the system, not the car owners or taxpayers.

The only acceptable connected communications in cars is one that can be easily turned off or removed by the cars owner.

Additional connected communications technology must be as unobtrusive and transparent to the vehicle operator as possible. There are already too many distractions for drivers without adding another, more complex layer of technology that takes attention away from the road.

Title: Comment from Michael Atkinson
Comment:
1) As a cybersecurity professional, I am aware of many, many architectural, code, and configuration vulnerabilities in so-called connected car systems, the CAN bus, and other areas in automobiles. Auto manufacturers who sell in the USA have utterly failed to take commercially reasonable steps to protect their customers. The V2X Communications standard should not be adopted  much less mandated  until it has been thoroughly vetted in public.

2) The cost of this technology, even if adopted in a secure manner, outweighs its benefits.

I do not speak for my employer.

Title: Comment from Bruce Bubello
Comment:
Totally unnecessary and an invasion of privacy. I do not need or want my car to tell anyone
or any agency where it is. It is also not a very smart idea to allow any part of vehicle electronics
to be able to talk to or receive from another car, any data. This could easily lead to problems 
like with computer viruses or someone / something taking over vehicle controls. It also presumes
that I have or want a cellular plan or a data plan, which not everyone wants or has a need for 
or can afford to pay extra for it. Vote down this invasion of privacy. It is bad enough now that just
about where ever you go, some camera is watching you and in a lot of areas Automated License
Plate Readers are watching you and selling your data to private companies or to insurance companies
to determine driving habit.

Title: Comment from Axel Schmidt
Comment: I am against that ruling.

Title: Comment from David Woodman
Comment:
I oppose any requirement for connected car technology. It seems it would open the roads up to catastrophes caused by hackers. I don't want my car to be vulnerable to this sort of thing. 

IF it should be mandated, costs must fall on the providers of such technology, not consumers. 

Such technology is only acceptable if the car owner or lessee can turn it off or remove it easily. 

Additional connected communications technology must be as unobtrusive and transparent to the vehicle operator as possible. There are already too many distractions for drivers without adding another, more complex layer of technology that takes attention away from the road.

Title: Comment from Jim Gerlach
Comment: My wife is electrohypersensitive and unable to be exposed to radar, microwave, cellular, cordless, and or other electromagnetic fields. Your interest in putting such radiation in cars or exuding from the perimeter of cars is horrid. How do you expect to comply with Americans with Disabilities Act mandates for reasonable accommodation? Do you plan to have automatic shut off switches in vehicles proximate to anyone who is a known electrohypersensitive? What about the undiagnosed victims like my brother-in-law who is dying of brain tumors as we speak from proximate exposure to his cell phone because our society does not consider it prudent to caution people about such hazards. I don't want any form of radio in  my wife's car and I don't want the car to be capable of being hacked and controlled remotely like I have observed in Jeep production vehicles and others that needed to be "snuffed out" with vehicular misdirection, acceleration, and other lock down controls that have no business in human transportation.

Comment:
Three things to consider with this:

Cost: There will be tremendous cost to implement V2X technology and necessary infrastructure should be borne by the providers who will profit from the system, not the car owners or taxpayers.

Ability to Shut Off or Remove: The only acceptable connected communications in cars is one that can be easily turned off or removed by the cars owner.  This is a motorists right.

Ease of Use: Additional connected communications technology must be as unobtrusive and transparent to the vehicle operator as possible. There are already too many distractions for drivers without adding another, more complex layer of technology that takes attention away from the road.

Title: Comment from Anonymous  Anonymous
Comment: The cost of this should not be paid by car owners or tax payers. This should also be easy to remove and turn off.

Title: Comment from Daniel Terrien
Comment: Car prices have increased exponentially over the past couple decades.  I and most people I know, am tired of paying (directly or indirectly) for technology that we do not want or need.  Most of this technology is sold as necessary for safety, but just as with most such technology, it just allows people to drive more carelessly.  We are trading our liberty for a false sense of security and paying more for it along the way.  This technology and what it brings is not welcomed by most average American drivers and the benefits are really for those big companies that are forcing it upon us, such as insurance companies, car manufactures, big technology and wireless firms.  I strongly oppose any mandate for two-way connected communications in cars.

Title: Comment from Avrohom Keller
Comment: The tremendous cost to implement V2X technology and necessary infrastructure should be borne by the providers who will profit from the system, not the car owners or taxpayers. 	The only acceptable connected communications in cars is one that can be easily turned off or removed by the cars owner. 	Additional connected communications technology must be as unobtrusive and transparent to the vehicle operator as possible. There are already too many distractions for drivers without adding another, more complex layer of technology that takes attention away from the road.

Title: Comment from Schurkey Swanke
Comment:
DO NOT permit vehicle-to-vehicle communication.  Person-to-person communication between vehicles is bad enough!

DO NOT permit "autonomous" vehicles.

DO NOT permit any reach toward autonomous vehicles.

Society does not need more technology in motor vehicles.  Sooner or later, the communication system will be hacked or otherwise found to have flaws, and people will die in large numbers when the "system" crashes.

The LAST thing Society needs is for more people to become disconnected from the ART AND SKILL of driving a motor vehicle.  We'll wind up helpless when the "automatic" or "autonomous" system fails because the skill-set needed to safely pilot a vehicle will have atrophied.  (You think driver skill-levels are low NOW?  Just wait...)

NO vehicle should be able to apply brakes, accelerate, or steer without direct driver input.  Speed-holding devices ("cruise control") is as far as autonomous vehicle technology should be allowed to progress--and only then if it is independent to each vehicle (NOT connected to, or controlled by nearby vehicles or off-site monitoring stations.)

Vehicle-to-vehicle communication is the seed of destruction.  Society needs enhanced Driver's Training, not a bunch of hackable software tied into hackable hardware.

Title: Comment from Pat Goltz
Comment: I am opposed to this new proposal. We should not implement 5G technology at all, since it is high power RF and will harm the health of the people. I do not want to be bathed in RF radiation when I am in town, and since all of my children and grandchildren live in town, they would be bathed in it continually, and I do not want that, either. Secondly, what you are proposing is far more complex than any system ever designed. The more complex it is, the more likely it is to break down and fail, and this will be catastrophic. I also know from experience that any smart technology that distracts the driver is a hazard. Even the GPS display in many cars is a distraction. I can tell you that from experience. Any such technology should not be obvious to a drive. Third, all smart technology must be designed so that the car owner can turn it OFF. We have a constitutional right to be secure in our persons, and this would violate that. It should also be the CHOICE of a car buyer whether to pay for this technology in the first place, and he should be free to refuse it. It should be optional. The rest of us should not be forced to pay for it. As long as this is not optional, I will not buy or drive a newer car at all. I do not want anything about me to be sent to others without my knowledge, including where I am and where I am going. This new proposal sounds like very bad news, and I am totally against it.

Title: Comment from Dan Linssen
Comment: The C-V2X two-way connectivity capacity in automobiles is another new technology that will certainly be accompanied by unanticipated problems. While there may be individuals and organizations that want this technology, many of us have neither the need, nor the desire, for this capacity. Because of factors such as increased cost, privacy concerns, operating complexities, and unknowable downsides, C-V2X should only be installed in automobiles as market demand warrants. This should not be a mandated automotive technology.

Title: Comment from Kirstin Beatty
Comment:
My name is Kirstin Beatty, and I am director of NGO Last Tree Laws, a Massachusetts-based group dedicated to safer technology and environmental health. On behalf of myself and the group, I submit our opposition to connected vehicles. 

Dr. Martin Pall, professor emeritus of biochemistry and general medicine at Washington State University, is an authority who has stated we may have only 4 years before we see a collapse of brain function, fertility, and healthy genetic inheritance, just based on current wireless exposures. His 2018 presentation can be seen online at the Electromagnetic Safety Alliance. Connected vehicles represent an even larger jump in exposure, and so I hope you can clearly see that connected vehicles would be a mistake. 

The European REFLEX study found cellular damage resulting from ordinary wireless exposures which was comparable to damage from 0.5 Gy of gamma radiation, or 2000 X-rays (1). While damage was specific to certain types of cells, the fact remains that cellular damage is occurring from current wireless levels and this has costs which may already be paying. Neurologist, neuroscientist, and autism specialist Dr. Martha Herbert has noted similarities between indicators for autism and wireless damage, as discussed in section 20 of the Bioinitiative Review. Dr. Martin Pall has noted similarities between wireless damage, mood, and behavioral troubles, among them trouble with attention, learning, and emotional processing (2). One can just look to observe we are already paying with a society less capable of compassion and social graces.

If we must be so base as to only use money as reason for denying an action, then another objection is that wireless vehicles will be more expensive. The energy and resources required for wireless infrastructure simply are a waste. The development of infrastructure may be misused for abuse or surveillance, as in China, with or without legal permission.

For a driver-less car to work, there must be infrastructure throughout the United States, leaving no place untouched, and further wireless power levels must be high both from and to the car. Urban areas have already suffered a greater number of cell towers and thus greater ill health, but driver-less cars would require infrastructure in pristine and typically untrammeled areas. Research indicates birds, bees, plants, and other species on which we depend are also at risk; a recent study of 5G impacts on insects suggests even greater damage may result (3, 4, 5, 6). 


At the end of Dr. Seuss's The Lorax, all the trees have been cut down leaving not a single tree and only pollution. Dr. Seuss's book is a fantastical story: let us keep the idea a fantasy. 


References

(1) Risk evaluation of potential environmental hazards from low frequency electromagnetic field exposure using sensitive in vitro methods. (2004) European Union. Quality of Life and Management of Living Resources. OLK$-CT-1999-01574

(2) Pall ML. (2016) Microwave frequency electromagnetic fields (EMFs) produce widespread neuropsychiatric effects including depression. J Chem Neuroanat. 75(Pt B):43-51. doi: 10.1016/j.jchemneu.2015.08.001.

(3) Balmori, A. (2009) Electromagnetic pollution from phone masts. Effects on wildlife. Pathophysiology. 16:191-199. 

(4) Balmori, A. (2010) Mobile Phone Mast Effects on Common Frog(Rana temporaria) Tadpoles: The City Turned into a Laboratory. Electromagnetic Biology and Medicine. 29:31-35.

(5) Beatty, K. (2018 November 9) 5G harms butterflies. Last Tree Laws. https://www.lasttreelaws.com/blog/5g-harms-butterflies

(6) Arno Thielens, Duncan Bell, David B. Mortimore, Mark K. Greco, Luc Martens & Wout Joseph. (2018) Exposure of Insects to Radio-Frequency Electromagnetic Fields from 2 to 120GHz. Scientific Reports. 8: 3924

hi,

Title: Comment from Craig Snyder
Comment:
RE: DOT-OST-2018-0210

Hello: Communication technology is an extremely complicated and fast changing landscape. How this technology should be applied to the automotive world, particularly considering the future of self-driving cars, should be looked at very carefully. A decision to mandate one type of technology should be done only if absolutely necessary. In this case, the negatives of a singular mandate cannot be justified. Manufacturers must be able to adjust easily with changing technology in order to create the safest and most useful systems. 

I strongly recommend no regulation on this matter.

Title: Comment from Vincent Mikalinis
Comment:

The only acceptable connected communications in cars is one that can be easily turned off or removed by the cars owner.

Additional connected communications technology must be as unobtrusive and transparent to the vehicle operator as possible. There are already too many distractions for drivers without adding another, more complex layer of technology that takes attention away from the road.

Title: Comment from Tom Giese
Comment:
It seems like this V2X system is very expensive. Since the costs are high, it is important that vehicle owners and taxpayers not be saddled with the costs. The providers, who stand to profit from this or any system, should bear the entire cost of implementation.
The only acceptable communications systems in cars would be readily turned on or even removed by the car's owners.  We have enough intrusions into our privacy. We need to be able to opt out should we so desire.
If any system is implemented, it needs to offer zero distractions to the driver. There are already way too many distractions in every vehicle for safe driving.No more screens or touch pads to have to look at and page through menus.  Stop the nonsense of telling drivers not to use their phones, yet make changing the radio station or volume level impossible without looking.

Title: Comment from Daniel Lancaster
Comment:
If people choose to install any kind of communications technology in their vehicle, they should be free to do so. However, people should also be completely free to purchase a vehicle without any communications technology at all. Furthermore, any communications technology installed in any vehicle should be easy for the owner of the vehicle to turn off or remove at their discretion. Government regulation of privately owned vehicles should always be minimal. 

The above is my legitimate personal opinion, both as a vehicle owner and as an individual with extensive education on the issue of government regulation. I hold a Bachelor of Arts Degree in Homeland Security and a Graduate Certificate in Public Administration.

Title: Comment from Scott Williams
Comment:
The tremendous cost to implement V2X technology and necessary infrastructure should be borne by the providers who will profit from the system, not the car owners or taxpayers.

The only acceptable connected communications in cars is one that can be easily turned off or removed by the cars owner.

Additional connected communications technology must be as unobtrusive and transparent to the vehicle operator as possible.

There are already too many distractions for drivers without adding another, more complex layer of technology that takes attention away from the road.

Title: Comment from ED EDSEN
Comment:
The tremendous cost to implement V2X technology and necessary infrastructure should be borne by the providers who will profit from the system, not the car owners or taxpayers.
    The only acceptable connected communications in cars is one that can be easily turned off or removed by the cars owner.
    Additional connected communications technology must be as unobtrusive and transparent to the vehicle operator as possible. There are already too many distractions for drivers without adding another, more complex layer of technology that takes attention away from the road.

Comment:

Title: Comment from charles cripps
Comment:
The tremendous cost to implement V2X technology and necessary infrastructure should be borne by the providers who will profit from the system, not the car owners or taxpayers.

Title: Comment from Walter Borntrager
Comment:
V2X is a serious threat to privacy and freedom!  This must not be a mandatory feature of vehicles!  This would be tantamount to requiring everyone to use GPS ankle bracelets like a prisoner!

An appropriate law would be to require vehicle manufacturers to provide the ability to completely remove any V2X electronics from their vehicle!

I am a veteran as was my father.  V2X would remove freedoms that my father and I - and tens of millions of others - have offered our lives for!

Title: Comment from Bruce Liddel
Comment:
I've often wished there was a better way to communicate with other nearby motorists.  "Pardon me, but you are blocking the passing lane.  May I please pass?"  "Pardon me, but did you know there is something dragging on the ground underneath your vehicle?" "Pardon me, but I thought you might want to know your right rear brake light is not lighting. "

For a brief while, it looked like CB radio might be the answer, but alas, uncivilized people made that unacceptably unpleasant.  

That said, whatever you come up with absolutely must incorporate these three fundamental principles: 

1)    The tremendous cost to implement V2X technology and necessary infrastructure should be borne by the providers who will profit from the system, not the car owners or taxpayers.

2)    The only acceptable connected communications in cars is one that can be easily turned off or removed by the cars owner.

3)    Additional connected communications technology must be as unobtrusive and transparent to the vehicle operator as possible. There are already too many distractions for drivers without adding another, more complex layer of technology that takes attention away from the road.

Title: Comment from John Anthony
Comment:
The tremendous cost to implement V2X technology and necessary infrastructure should be borne by the providers who will profit from the system, not the car owners or taxpayers.
The only acceptable connected communications in cars is one that can be easily turned off or removed by the cars owner.
Additional connected communications technology must be as unobtrusive and transparent to the vehicle operator as possible. There are already too many distractions for drivers without adding another, more complex layer of technology that takes attention away from the road.
 https://www.regulations.gov/docket?D=DOT-OST-2018-0210
Deadline: February 25, 2019

John Anthony

Title: Comment from Bill Payne
Comment:
As a professional chauffeur with 20+ years experience, I'm been exposed on a daily basis to drivers who are focused on their phones, vehicle apps, selecting their music...seemingly everything but the task of driving.  With all the distractions for drivers already available, there is no need for another, more complex layer of technology that takes attention away from the road and the task of driving.

Automakers and any other entities who stand to profit from V2X technology should be the ones responsible for funding any additional infrastructure needs, funding should not fall to car owners or US taxpayers.

With privacy issues an ever growing concern, whether an individual is using a phone, a computer or simply walking or driving down a street in their hometown, US taxpayers don't need another invasive technology which they have no control over or have no ability to turn off or remove from their vehicle The only acceptable connected communications in cars is one that can be easily turned off or removed by the cars owner.

Title: Comment from  William Keeling
Comment:
Vehicle data , transmitted among vehicles, should be source anonymous.
In other words, no personally identifiable data, should ever be created from the outset.  This will ensure privacy and will also eliminate constitutional concerns and challenges in regard to data storage.

Title: Comment from James Nelson
Comment: This intrudes on our freedom. And it adds expense. Please find more important areas to address like texting when driving. Unlicensed drivers and so on.

Title: Comment from Ross Rhode
Comment: I oppose any mandate for V2X Communications. I feel this will add more unneeded cost to vehicles. It creates a false sense of security. It is also an invasion of our privacy and a loss of our liberty.

Title: Comment from Gary Qualset
Comment:
Thank you for the opportunity to provide public comments from an individual constituent.  I'd like to make the following comments for serious consideration from an individual user's perspective.

>  The tremendous cost to implement V2X technology and necessary infrastructure should be borne by the providers who will profit from the system, not the car owners or taxpayers.

>  The only acceptable connected communications in cars is one that can be easily turned off or removed by the cars owner.

>  Additional connected communications technology must be as unobtrusive and transparent to the vehicle operator as possible. There are already too many distractions for drivers without adding another, more complex layer of technology that takes attention away from the road.

Title: Comment from Alan Travaglianti
Comment: I am against any automotive communication from car to car unless it is paid for by the providers who will profit from the use of this system.  Also, as a freedom lover, I want to be able to easily disconnect my vehicle from said car to car communication system.  Finally, my new 2109 Chevrolet already has enough distractions going on with the need to use the screen to do many of the items my previous cars did with simple pushbuttons and dials.  This new system should not be anything I need to do further to distract from my driving.

Title: Comment from Tim  Edwards
Comment: This a cost that should be paid by the manufacturer of the product.  Why should the motorist have to pay for it? Also the person whose vehicle it is installed in should have the option of turning it off and taking it out of the vehicle.

Title: Comment from j. roberts
Comment:
I am against the communications between automobiles.     It is an invasion of my own privacy.  And a security matter for me and my automobile, regardless of the driver.

When we have all these self driving autos.. ..     What keeps terrorist from loading a dozen autos with bombs and having them heading into a large city  communicating with each other or even worse, innocent drivers of other autos and blowing them up.

All self driving autos should have steering wheels and brakes setup like normal autos, so they can be controlled in case of  a malfunction.

When you are trying to read the lines on the highways and they are covered by mud, snow or road construction...self driving cars are just accidents waiting to happen!

Title: Comment from J Miller
Comment:
Dear NTSA,

I object to adding C-V2X communications on several grounds.  First, the public should not be paying for this expensive addition, unless each vehicle owner voluntarily accepts the fees.  I do not.

Also there needs to be a way for the vehicle owner to easily turn off off any system.  The last thing we need is more Big Brother or driving distractions.  

The best way to improve safety is to disable texting from a moving vehicle, and enforce lane discipline, not add more layers of gadgets and bureaucracy.

Regards.

Title: Comment from douglas harrison
Comment:
Thank you for hearing my concerns on this matter...

While advancement in technology is generally a positive for society, I believe that it needs to occur naturally in a free-market system.  As such as the C-V2X or similar technology moves forward, including supporting infrastructure, the costs should be the responsibility of product developers rather than general consumers and taxpayers.  This includes, but is not limited to, requiring auto manufacturers to subsidize the technology, which ultimately raises the prices of their vehicles whether they are outfitted with technology or not.

American consumers should be able to choose whether or not to participate in such technology, whether indirectly via taxes and higher prices, or directly in the form of an "option" on the vehicle purchased.

Vehicles built with this technology should be required to have an "OFF" switch that is easy to access.  The technology should also be employed in a manner that does not offer an additional distraction to drivers that already have a multitude of distractions that draw their focus away from the task of actually driving.

Thank you again for your consideration!

Title: Comment from Brian Bender
Comment: The freedom to opt-out of having and/or using a two-way radio in your car is a must.  The only acceptable radio in cars are the ones that can be easily turned off or removed.

Title: Comment from Robin  Bloomgarden
Comment:
DOT,

Regarding your V2X Communications, Docket ID: DOT-OST-2018-0210, I am not interested in any connected cars! If you insist on having every car connected, then please make it so I can turn it off if I want to! 

This technology is just one more assault on my health which is already being assaulted by wireless radiation from every direction! I cannot survive in a world completely dominated by wireless radiation! Nobody will survive for long.

Yes to a plain old radio in my car, but NO to more radiation devices in every corner of it, on all buses, trains, planes, etc.

Here are two links that discuss the many negative issues of cell phones, 5G, Smart Meters, and wireless technologies, which all use radiation, some are even worse than others :

Environmental Health Trust   https://ehtrust.org    and    WHAT ARE 5G AND THE INTERNET OF THINGS?  https://whatis5g.info

Please educate yourselves.

Sincerely,

Robin Bloomgarden
1430 Willamette St #493
Eugene, Oregon 97401

Title: Comment from Arthur Frazier
Comment:
I am pleased to comment on V2X and will be brief:
1. The number one concern, regardless of technology, must be Security. The current rush to the Internet-of-Things (IOT) has resulted in thermostats, TVs, and refrigerators that can be easily hacked. We cannot have hackers controlling vehicle systems.
2. The tremendous cost to implement V2X technology and necessary infrastructure should be borne by the providers who will profit from the system, not the car owners or taxpayers.
3. The only acceptable connected communications in cars is one that can be easily turned off or removed by the cars owner.
4. Additional connected communications technology must be as unobtrusive and transparent to the vehicle operator as possible. There are already too many distractions for drivers without adding another, more complex layer of technology that takes attention away from the road.
5. V2X technology must not be used by States, cities, etc. for the automatic collection of revenues (speeding tickets, parking tickets, etc).
Thank you.

Comment: 2 way communication built into new card must be unobtrusive and totally controllable by the driver/owner.  It must be able to be turned completely off by owner, if desired. It must put no demands on owner that are not desired by owner. Features must be selected by owner for use.  Cost should be borne by owner only for features desired.  No cost should be borne by owner, if no features are desired.  It cannot be used by public or private entities to track a vehicle or its use, without full permission of owner.

Comment:
The exceptional cost to implement V2X technology and its necessary infrastructure should be borne by the providers who will profit from the system, NOT the car owners or taxpayers.

Connected communications in cars must be easily shut off or removable by car owners.

There are too many "technology advances" that cause distracted driving such as smart phones.  Any technology must not interfere with driving.

Title: Comment from Arthur De Volve
Comment:
NO. No inter connectivity is necessary or beneficial. Drivers are already distracted, going down the road, punching data and menu choices on their touchscreens.  More of this will just lead to more distracted driving/accidents. 

Most importantly, any tech of this sort should be *easily* disabled by the driver.  Any data should be the legal property of the driver and or owner. And, no one should be able to legally demand or demand by incentive that the driver keep these devices engaged, or even in the car.  In fact it should be required that the entire device should be removable from the vehicle as easily as unplugging a fuse and their should be no mandate by anyone that the device be in the vehicle or passed on with the vehicle when sold or traded.

Title: Comment from Jennifer Wood
Comment:
I do not want to have or pay for connected vehicles and their required infrastructure.
    The only acceptable radio in cars are the ones that can be easily turned off or removed.
    Technology is not better than human drivers. Computers crash too!  Furthermore, a substantial body of evidence ( over 10,000 science studies and possibly tens of thousands of studies) clearly show that radiation from Mircowave/ RF (wireless) radiation is harmful to health. and instrumental in many serious diseases.  It also has been shown to impact cognitive function so wireless RF sensors that are meant to prevent accidents might cause as many accidents as they create. Millions of people world wide now suffer from Microwave Sickness and other illnesses linked to RF radiation who will experience serious impairment if radio frequency systems in automobiles cannot be removed.  Industry could also suffer substantial financial losses as well due to any defected systems that cannot be removed and so forth.  This is not only a violation of human right to health; it is a violation of good business practices.

Title: Comment from Frank Faeth
Comment:
This is a train running faster than it needs to, without any pre-agreed destination.  My comments:

	The tremendous cost to implement V2X technology and necessary infrastructure should be borne by the providers who will profit from the system, not the car owners or taxpayers.
	The only acceptable connected communications in cars is one that can be easily turned off or removed by the cars owner.
	Additional connected communications technology must be as unobtrusive and transparent to the vehicle operator as possible. There are already too many distractions for drivers without adding another, more complex layer of technology that takes attention away from the road.

I am unhappy about the trend towards believing AV will solve all our problems and that fact it is being imposed on us -- while I like some of the features, I don't need AI taking over my driving privileges. 

Thank you.

Title: Comment from Stuart Kienlen
Comment:
First, there are, and will continue to be, lots of Baby Boomer drivers on the road.  They may not be comfortable with the additional technology.  Therefore, it needs to be simple.  Granted, no one sets out trying to make new things complex.  But there must be a concerted effort to keep this as seamless as possible.

Second, privacy concerns dictate that this technology must be able to be COMPLETELY turned off.  This shouldn't be one of those cases where a driver thinks he has turned the system off, but in reality, the system is still performing function X or function Y without the driver's knowledge.

Third, this technology should not increase the cost of vehicles.  Many businesses will figure out a way to monetize this technology.  Those businesses should bear the cost of the technology; not the drivers; not the taxpayers.

Title: Comment from S V
Comment: 2.The only acceptable radio in cars are the ones that can be easily turned off or removed. If someone needs this type of assistance, perhaps they should not be behind the wheel.

Title: Comment from Marilyn Wood
Comment: I oppose connected vehicles and their required infrastructure. I do not want the adverse health effects from the constant radiation they emit, and I do not want to have to pay for them. They offer no advantages that I can see, and they will further endanger public health and well-being.

Title: Comment from Susan Brinchman
Comment: Virtually all independent, non-industry research shows that rf microwave radiation is hazardous to health. Devices emitting this type of radiation should not be allowed due to these clear public health hazards, which include, but are not limited to cancers, immunological and neurological impacts, DNA single and double-strand breakage, memory problems, inflammatory diseases, and a likely contributor to obesity, diabetes, Altzheimer's, early onset dementia, and autism. It is irresponsible to consider placing technologies in vehicles that have these risks and hazards, for an unknowing public, and ultimately forcing the public to expose themselves to these hazardous rf emissions, in order to use transportation. Further, it is entirely unnecessary, and simply a profit-seeking industry-driven effort. Our government should protect our citizens and residents, not collude with industry to harm them. www.electrosmogprevention.org

Title: Comment from Anne Mills
Comment:
I do not want to have or pay for connected vehicles.  I do not want to pay for required infrastructure, with money or health.
The only acceptable radio in cars are the ones that can be easily turned off or removed.
Anything for money, right?  Doesn't matter who it hurts, right?  Until your family member is the one that suffers, all is well.
I love my computer.  I don't want one in my car.  I don't want my car telling me when to drive where or how.  I don't want my vehicle locking the doors for me or steering or braking or using lights.  
If someone is not capable of passing a driving test and driving safetly ...if someone is not capable of driving due to drinking or drugs, they do not belong behind a wheel.  This is what will happen.  This is what has already happened with autonomous vehicles.  They depend on the vehicle while they talk on the phone or sleep off a drunk.  
Technology is not better than most human drivers. Hasn't your computer crashed?   Might be interesting on a twisty mountainous cliffside road, though.

Title: Comment from Michael Mitchell
Comment:
I am opposed to the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration proposed mandate of two-way connected communications in vehicles.  My two primary objections are as follows:
1.  The federal government has no clear authority to be involved in this field.
2.  It is probable that the resulting increase in radiation would be harmful to those exposed to it.  I say this because I am aware of the studies by independent researchers which show that cell phone radiation is harmful.
However, realizing that government agencies are generally unconcerned about limits on their lawful authority, and generally unconcerned about health effects of technology, I also am concerned about other aspects of the technology.  I offer the following comments.
I am concerned that implementation of such technology will constitute an invasion of privacy. 
Any means of facilitating connected communications in vehicles must be unobtrusive and transparent.  It must not demand attention from the driver, who is already subject to many distractions.
Connected communications must be easily turned off or removed by the vehicle owner.
The cost should be borne by the providers who will profit, not by vehicle owners or taxpayers.
Thank you for the opportunity to comment.

Title: Comment from Mary Beth Brangan
Comment:
I am horrified at the prospect of this totally unnecessary
exposure to damaging radar radiation.  Servicemen operating
radar during WWII were sickened and permanently damaged.
Studies showed infertility, cataracts, headaches, nausea, etc.
Why haven't the thousands of independent credible peer reviewed studies
showing damage to DNA and cellular function, not only in humans, 
but in all creatures, plants, trees, insects, birds, etc. from RF,
been taken into account by the proponents of this idea?

Conservative estimates of people totally unable to tolerate exposure
to man-made Radiofrequency radiation are from 3% of the population to 
30% and rising. Everyone is affected by this.  Effects are cumulative.
This V2X technology should be banned.

I am totally opposed to this and I do not want to have or pay for connected 
vehicles and their required infrastructure.  The only acceptable radio in cars are 
the ones that can be easily turned off or removed.
   
Technology is not better than human drivers. Computers crash too!

Title: Comment from Cynthia Peck
Comment from Christine Calabrese

Do the research https://www.wired.com/story/krack-wi-fi-wpa2-vulnerability/  just wifi is not secure and these V2V instruments are probably totally vulnerable.

Title: Comment from Kim Jacobs
Comment:
I am against vehicle connectivity!

I do not want to have or pay for connected vehicles and their required infrastructure.

Title: Comment from Scott Johnston
Comment:
I have several issues with this new technology. I don't think it is the proper role of government to be involved in the establishment of the technical specifications or use of the technology. If there are going to be regulations associated with this technology it should be set out in this way.
If a purchaser of a vehicle or system that contains this technology, they should have the opportunity to opt-out or disable the use of said technology. It should not be mandated to use. 
If companies want to use this technology they should bear the expense of the build-out of infrastructure. Car owners or tax-payers should pay for infrastructure. This should be the responsibility of those who will profit from its use.
Additional technology added to vehicles should be completely transparent to the driver. We don't need additional distractions forced upon drivers. A lot of the new technology added to vehicles makes it more difficult to operate. Dials and buttons are much more tactile and easier than being distracted by a touch screen.

Title: Comment from Nicole O'Quinn
Comment:
I object to the V2X Communication technology for the following two reasons: cost and invasion of privacy.

Instituting this technology is going to be costly and even more so if the Government is going to foot the bill.  The Government is notoriously bad at defining requirements which is why nearly all large Government projects cost many times more than the original estimates. We the taxpayers will be paying for another large Government project with dubious results and many unintended consequences.

In order for this technology to work somebody or something needs to know where your vehicle is at all times.  This data is open to exploitation by Government agencies, Law Enforcement agencies, commercial entities, and criminal elements.  What most people don't seem to understand is that individual pieces of your travels are not informative, but string together each trip on a timeline then a picture of your life and habits emerges.  This technology then becomes back door surveillance.

Title: Comment from Jean Mukherjee
Comment:
The inclusion of V2X communications and other technology on transportation vehicles should not be mandated and in fact, should not even be promoted or installed.

1-This technology is extraordinarily expensive.  If a manufacturer wants to utilize this technology, then they should bear the full cost of any infrastructure requirements and all liability.  Tax payers should not be responsible for these costs.
2-Such technology if installed should be able to be removed or turned off by the user.  There should be no costs to the user associated with removal and/or turning off this technology.
3-In recent years, many of the various technological additions to vehicles are extremely distracting to drivers.  Further, they give drivers a false sense of safety/competence.  The result is numerous daily distracted driving incidents--drivers driving into building, telephone poles, pedestrians, bicyclists.  
4-I have purposely put off purchasing a new vehicle in recent years and will continue to put off such a purchase because I do not want a vehicle with a screen in it.  When I'm in my car, I want to drive without distraction.....I do not want to stare at a screen....I already do that all day.  I also do not want to pay for technology I'll never use--my current vehicle has cruise control--something that is absolutely impossible to even contemplate using in the crowded NE US.
5-It completely confounds me as to why so much effort is being put into taking over the activity of driving.....I enjoy driving.  Humans have been driving for decades.  Trying to mimic a human and their ability to drive is indeed a technological challenge and I'm sure manufacturers are betting on reaping large financial gains from this fad, but the effort and financial input required is a complete waste.  There is no way to account for all the parameters on the road in all weather and all conditions, particularly when there is a vast mix of vehicles, both with and without various technological advances.  Such monetary expenditure and effort should be devoted to something that needs fixing--like climate change and environmental preservation and reclamation and preventing species collapse.
6-Once again, we are adding technology to something and creating yet another item that will become obsolescent within a matter of months or years.  The result is more eWaste, more enviornmental degradation as we seek conflict minerals to create this technology and yet more materials that cannot and/or will not be recycled or re-used.

Title: Comment from Lynn Stull
Comment:
I have no desire for this type of automation. I do not want to have or pay for connected vehicles and their required infrastructure. The only acceptable radio in cars are the ones that can be easily turned off or removed.
Technology is not better than human drivers. I object to the additional radiation that will be needed to power the V2X Communications network. In addition to the excess radiation, the energy cost to this type of infrastructure in not sustainable.
