Title: Comment from Ted Loewenberg
Comment:
V2X Communications as proposed will be incredibly expensive to implement and deploy. It is a pipe dream that will become a financial nightmare for America. Every meter of road, highway and public space will have to install beacons to simply describe where the navigable surfaces are, in addition to sensors to reflect current reality of use (number of peds, rates of all traffic, weather and so on). Pedestrians and cyclists, as well as rented scooter users, Segways, and such will have to participate through their personal phones (what happens when the batteries run out?). Every sign and traffic control device will have to communicate with all the vehicles about their status (red v. green), stop, left turn only or turn prohibited,etc.  That means electrical power to every sign, with a powerful digital processor and complex software to handle all the communications as well as on-going maintenance and updates. Those changes need to be propagated throughout the entire system, and maintained for decades for compatibility. 

The expense of doing all this, not to mention the vast complexity of it all, make this virtually impossible. There is no way to do comprehensive testing of the millions of devices involved. Errors will introduce a new danger to the public: death by software bug. This has already been seen in the early phases of autonomous vehicles, and will likely only get worse with time. 
Alternatively, the human brain comes pre-programmed for complexity. It already handles all of these situations, sometimes better than others. The communications of traffic control devices (lights and signs) are managed effectively now, at very low cost (compared to V2X). It is a gross mistake to supplant human cognition with a limited capability hardware and software jungle that will bankrupt both federal, state and local resources, in addition to driving still higher the cost and prices of vehicle transportation. Drivers come fully equipped with the most powerful computing tool in the known universe. Let's put that to good use. Let's encourage improvement of that "system" where there is weakness. We know that human behavior is not perfect. However, we can do better through education and creative problem solving to make our society mobile and safe. The environment will also benefit by reducing the draw on electricity that will be required to operate a V2X network nationwide.

Title: Comment from Max Kalashnikov
Comment:
The only acceptable connected communications in cars is one that can be easily turned off or removed by the cars owner and/or current operator. The negative consequences to privacy without such a provision are staggering.

Additional connected communications technology must be as unobtrusive and transparent to the vehicle operator as possible. There are already too many technological distractions for drivers that don't actually improve the driving experience (for anyone) without adding another, more complex layer of technology that benefits only special interests.

The tremendous cost to implement V2X technology and necessary infrastructure should be borne by those special interests, the providers who will profit from the system, not the car owners, renters/operators, or taxpayers.

Title: Comment from Beatrice Golomb
Comment:
I urge that you make strenuous efforts, not only to prevent requirement for V2V (vehicle to vehicle) communication, but to deny permission for it, for the health of many.  
Evidence documents that many people a very large number, though a small fraction of the population -- are already experiencing life altering symptoms and health problems from existing sources of nonionizing radiofrequency/microwave radiation  (RF/MW), from cell towers, smart meters, wifi, etc, and in some cases also from extremely low frequency radiation (power line type). Each added source of RF/MW has created a new group of impaired individuals, and further curtails the freedom of movement of those already affected.
Our data indicate that for those employed at the time they become affected, fully half have been forced to leave their job, because the impairment is not only to the new source of radiation, but individuals develop new problem s with previously tolerated sources of radiation. 
Combining different frequencies of radiation leads to synergistic toxicity, according to US government reports (like a DIA report on health effects of RFR**) citing Russian studies. Russian exposure limits are 1 ten-thousanths of what ours are  they are doing a far better job of protecting their people, and are probably laughing that we are taking out many of ours, perhaps especially the best and brightest (see below).  Adding V2V communication to existing radiation sources is thus expected to synergistically increase injury. RF/MR has also been shown, in many studies, to depresses critical antioxidants that are required for defense against chemical toxicity as well  so this will likely magnify the burden of chronic conditions with a tie to 
Just as new attitudes toward behaviors toward women are leading to repercussions decades later, so future attitudes may be adverse to persons who participated in making decisions harmful to some citizens, after being apprised of the potential repercussions.
Just as diplomats in Cuba and China experience cognitive loss, hearing loss, sleep problems, headaches, anxiety, dizziness, and irritability  most likely due to pulsed RF/MW-  so do segments of the public, from communication sources of RF/MW.
Oxidative stress (free radical injury) is a strongly documented mechanism of injury with RF/MW (and also ELF). This affects proteins, lipids, DNA and RNA, among other substances in the bodyis an irrefutably documented mechanism of toxicity for low level, nonionizing RF/MW affirmed in numerous studies.  For instance, Yakymenko et al assessed 100 studies that evaluated whether low level RF/MW caused oxidative stress: 93 showed that it did. De Luca et al assessed whether genetic variants that lead to less avid protections against oxidative stress, are tied to reported effects from RF/MW (and other electromagnetic radiation). They were. People cannot manipulate their genes by suggestibility: this is powerful evidence that the symptoms are from the oxidative-stress causing radiation. Belpomme in France showed that affected people consistently have low levels of a metabolite of melatonin. Melatonin is a critical antioxidant, shown in scores of studies to protect against free radical injury from RF/MW (and ELF, and every other kind of radiation  and also many, many chemicals). And RF/MW (and ELF) lead to depressions in melatonin and other critical antioxidants made b y the body, far more in some people than others (a phenomenon called effect modification). 
Oxidative stress promotes many secondary causes of injury  to different degrees in different people. These include damage to mitochondria, the energy producing parts of cells (damage to mitochondria also produces oxidative stress), membrane damage, blood-brain barrier impairment, inflammation, impaired bloodflow (via endothelial dysfunction), histamine elevation, cell death, and activation of coagulation, as well as modifying substances in the body in a way that makes them more vulnerable to autoimmune attack  among other mechanism.
My experience suggests the best and brightest may be selectively affected, and this mechanism provides reasons why. Among those citing problems are Gro Harlem Brundtland, former 3 time Prime Minister of Norway, and former Director General of the World Health Organization; and Matti Niemela, former Chief Technology Officer at Nokia; and Per Segerstrom, former software engineer at Eriksson. I know at least 9 affected physicians, a number of affected engineers, lawyers, scientists, etc. 
Our data indicate that persons who have experienced major electric shocks, or who have had past exposure to drugs / chemicals that cause damage through oxidative stress and toxicity to mitochondria (when damaged, these produce more oxidative stress) are disproportionately affected.

Title: Comment from Donald Sherman
Comment: Am strongly opposed to any imposition of a mandate for all new vehicles sold in the United States to be equipped with two way communications devices. As with many other items, the communications devices should be a matter of consumer choice and dealer offers, not on the dictates of unelected officials in Washington, District of Columbia!

Title: Comment from Pamela Wallace
Comment:
I am writing in opposition of the mandate for V2X Communications in all vehicles. V2X Communications is best offered as part of a tech package, giving consumers options in terms of its utilization.There is a great deal of scientific research that shows serious health impacts from RF and EMF and increased exposures. There are also many people with diagnosed medical conditions that are effected by or caused by RF and EMF exposures and some who would not be able to be in a vehicle with V2X Communication features. A mandate of this would effectively leave those effected at this level a stranded population and without an option to own or travel in vehicles with V2X features. Transportation is a necessary resource. Leaving these features optional allows everyone access to the transportation they need and the ability to decide how many safety features they want on their vehicles. It also allows those who want or need more control over their RF and EMF exposure levels to have it. Exposure levels are cumulative and given the exponential rise in exposures over the past 10 years in all of our daily environments, having higher levels of control over this is for some very helpful and for others absolutely essential. If this does end up becoming a mandate,medical accommodations will need to be made for those with a medical diagnosis and condition that would prohibit them for owning or being a passenger in a vehicle with V2X Communications and access provided them to vehicles without this feature.

I am also submitting these comments on: Docket NHTSA-2016-0126

Title: Comment from Andrew Krupp
Comment:
I am writing in opposition of a mandate of V2X communications rather than it being an option for all vehicles. There are many people with medical conditions that are effected by RF and EMF exposures that would not be able to ride in or drive a vehicle with V2X communications. This would leave them without transportation which is essential. If V2X becomes mandate you will also need to mandate provisions for medical accommodations for those with a medical diagnosis which would require them to have access to vehicles without the V2X feature and thus the right to transportation. 

These comments are also being submitted on: Docket: NHTSA-2016-0126

Title: Comment from E M
Comment:
I am writing due to my concern about the issue of connected cars. I am generally opposed to mandating such technologies, for a couple of reasons.

The first is opportunity cost and diminishing marginal gains of such technologies. Every year cars are mandated to have a number of new technologies, some good, some mediocre, and some bad. This comes at a cost. Every one of these technologies might add just $20 or $40 per car but, taken together, they have caused car prices to balloon. The ability for car-to-car communication might very well increase safety in some small way, but cars are already historically safe and for many people that money might be better spent on other things, such as keeping the car well-maintained.

The second problem is privacy. We already cannot leave the house without constant tracking through ALPR, OnStar, and such. I do not want to be tracked. I do not want the government to store a record of my movements, in ways that can be facilitated by communication technologies. Where drivers do need meaningful regulation is in the area of privacy controls around this type of technology, to restrict both governments and private parties from using our data without our explicit approval.

Title: Comment from Jason Boehk
Comment:
Regarding: DOT-OST-2018-0210-0023  V2X Communications 

Dear Sir/Madam: 

I strongly oppose V2X communications and the use of my federal taxes to promote what actually amounts to a massive boondoggle to benefit industry as well as a massive public health hazard in the form of unprecedented levels of radiofrequency (RF) radiation that will harm the health of millions of Americans. 

This docket examines whether we should use DSRC or V2X communications. As a citizen I oppose both DSRC and V2X for the two primary reasons stated above, namely, mandating either DSRC or V2X, in fact represents both an unjustifiable corporate giveaway and a severe public health threat. 

More importantly, I challenge the fundamental authority of DOT to engage in the activities pertaining to this Docket. 

By what authority does the Department of Transportation (DOT) propose, via V2X, a de facto invasion of privacy of virtually everyone involved in transportation on our public roadways? 

By what authority does DOT propose to deploy, in the various networks and technologies necessary to build V2X, massive new levels of health-harming RF radiation?

As DOT is unable to provide a legitimate answer to these questions, I strongly oppose any new rule the DOT would promulgate, and I oppose any and all forms of mandated vehicle-to-vehicle V2X communications, for the following reasons:  

Authority  DOT is exceeding its authority. Any decision to transition to V2X cars should be left to the people through a vote or its elected representatives through legislation. 

Safety  A) Software based systems are just as likely to cause errors as human drivers, therefore they are trading one problem for another. Humans may be subject to judgment errors and distractions that cause accidents, but software driven systems are subject to hardware failures, software glitches, software bugs, software viruses, malware, trojan horses, ransomware, hacking, etc. One of these events could have catastrophic effects on driver safety. B) By DOT's own admissions, safety goals will not be obtained unless all cars have them and they clearly state they have no authority to mandate after market devices. More accidents will occur with a hybrid vehicle fleet on the roads. C) Alerts will cause more distractions from the road and possibly cause more accidents.

Health  Another layer of exposure to RF emissions and potential for dangerous hot spots as placement of antennas will not be subject to regulations. It is unconscionable to mandate these radios in light of the partial release of the NTP rat study and the incompleted FCC Docket #13-84 on reassessment of emission standards. V2X must be put on hold until both are completed. 

Privacy  As stated by NHTSA,  "... the introduction of V2V [V2X] technology creates new privacy risks that cannot be fully mitigated."

Security  No computer based system working off of wireless transmissions can be adequately secured. It is one thing to have your credit card number hacked and potentially lose some money versus the V2X system hack can claim your life.

Costs   V2X is a wasteful government-mandated boondoggle. The costs of this autonomous car future far outweigh the benefits. The costs to equip and maintain these systems in every vehicle, update the countrys infrastructure to communicate effectively, manage, store and analyzed the Big Data, and secure the system, coupled with the estimated 5 million jobs lost, are not justified by the unsubstantiated benefits of reducing crashes and saved lives. One software glitch can take many more lives. 

Future Crime  Autonomous vehicles have potential to increase crime in the future. 

Economy  Autonomous cars will eliminate an estimated 5 million jobs for truck drivers, delivery drivers, bus drivers, taxi and limousine drivers, etc. 

Conflicts of interests  There have been far too many agency employees leaving for lucrative connected cars industry jobs. 

Safety Act  The proposed rule fails to meet all the elements of the Safety Act.

In closing: 

Any radio installed in a vehicle must be able to be removed or disabled by the owner of said vehicle. 

I strongly oppose mandating V2X in cars and light trucks. All roadway corridors will have significant increases in RF radiation exposure from V2X and supporting infrastructure. V2X poses increased safety hazards to drivers, passengers, people in homes who live along roadways, cyclists, and pedestrians. Increased RFR exposure from V2X threatens nature, trees, birds, bees and other insects. Vulnerable populations such as children, seniors, people with electromagnetic hypersensitivity (EHS), and people with medical implants are at greater risk of harm. 

V2X technology will not make driving safer, but will make driving more harmful to people and the environment, create mobility access barriers, and should be stopped.

Please, stop your promotion of this misguided and unconstitutional V2X project.

Jason Boehk
Sarasota, Florida 34237

Title: Comment from Brandon Poplarr
Comment: VX2 Communication would stand beneficial to the aging infrastructure of the United States' public roads. With the implementation of this technology, many fatal collisions would be near impossible. The direct communication of computers would allow for more accurate and efficient travel without the extra calculation of human instinct and skill. Many driver error-related accidents are caused by a miscalculation in what another fellow driver was going to do. With the computer set a travel speed and destination, the U.S. roads would consist of a homogenized band of cars, all with set destinations. All human errors would be considered a thing of the past.

Title: Comment from Michael  McGinnis
Comment: There is absolutely no need or reason for my car to communicate with any other vehicle. Any motor vehicle operator must be attentive to surroundings at all times. Even the current level of technology is turning people into idiots: I cannot fathom having my car tell me to stay in my lane, or to have it stop for me because I'm too stupid to not hit the car in front of me.

Title: Comment from Arthur Weiss
Comment: Please approve this proposed route between Las Vegas, NV and Haneda Airport for American Airlines.  The only way for Las Vegas travelers to fly to Tokyo now is to either drive or fly to Los Angeles, CA or fly to San Francisco, CA, which is time consuming, expensive, and extremely tiring.  Flying between Las Vegas and Haneda would be an immense boon both in terms of economics and tourism for the United States and the Las Vegas area.  McCarran Airport has an outstanding Immigration and Customs facility in a brand new terminal which could easily handle the once a day flight proposal currently under consideration.  Thank you.

Title: Comment from F Mahmud
Comment:
It is truly sad that the department has decided to give Delta all it has asked for.  The bulk of Delta's asks were for routes that have a large amount of connecting flow, which can be done over any airport, yet the Department used that same excuse to deny access to others.

Furthermore, Delta has a history of running smaller aircraft to Asia, thus reducing the total number of seats available to passengers and thus driving fares up.   United's 772s have a seating capacity of 276, American's 772s have a capacity of 273 and Delta's 332s have a seating capacity of 200.   For each route Delta flies a 332 on, that's a loss of 26,572 seats to the passengers on an annual basis when compared to an American 772.  

Through the merger with Northwest, Delta inherited one of the largest operations in Tokyo based at Narita.  But, Delta opted to abandon that jewel and somehow they are being rewarded now with this decision.

If the DoT was truly committed to the passengers and not the airlines, it would reconsider this ruling and at a least make Delta commit larger planes to these routes and revoke that route authority if Delta attempts to down-gauge it, something Delta has had a history of doing repeatedly.

Title: Comment from C Terry
Comment:
The department's rulings on the 2019 Haneda Combination Services Allocation Proceeding are commendable. For the most part, this proceeding clearly shows the department's commitment to choosing what best serves the general public interest.

On that note, it is very surprising that the department has chosen to give Delta five of its six requested slots. Delta's first four slots are reasonable requests; Seattle, Detroit and Atlanta are all large hubs for Delta, allowing significant connecting options for passengers, and Portland has a very long history with successful service to Tokyo on its own, but Delta surely does not need to operate service from Honolulu to Haneda. Delta being able to operate this route puts them at a clear advantage over the other airlines because they would be allowed to operate in the largest O&D market to Tokyo from the United States, while American and United would not. Even though, arguably, United already has service from Honolulu to Haneda through their partnership with ANA, it is still not on their own metal. If Delta's request for the right to operate this route is overturned, there would still be substantial competition on the route between ANA/United and JAL/Hawaiian. As pointed out in Hawaiian's objection to the department's rulings, Hawaiian would be able to offer passengers a lot more connecting options within Japan through their partnership with JAL, as well as benefiting Japan-originating passengers with more connecting options to the United States mainland, as well as the other Hawaiian islands. Awarding Hawaiian the right to fly another Honolulu to Haneda flight would ultimately benefit passengers much more than Delta's Honolulu to Haneda flight would.

For these reasons, Delta should not be awarded the right to fly from Honolulu to Haneda. Instead, this slot should either go to Hawaiian for the right to fly from Haneda to Honolulu, or to American for their second requested Dallas/Fort Worth to Haneda flight or to their requested Las Vegas to Haneda flight. American's Dallas/Fort Worth hub is one of the largest in the United States, and would allow for more connectivity options for passengers. Las Vegas, as pointed out in American Airlines' initial application, is one of the largest unserved markets to and from Tokyo. Delta argued within their response that if the Las Vegas market was viable, then either American or JAL would have already started service from Las Vegas to Narita. However, what Delta did not account for there, was that Haneda's closer location to Tokyo's city center will help to stimulate more traffic on that route. Note that Delta used a very similar argument in justifying their request for the right to fly from Portland to Haneda. Even though Delta only operates their Portland to Narita flight five times a week for a substantial part of the year, Haneda's closer location to Tokyo's city center will help to stimulate more traffic on that route. If Delta's Honolulu to Haneda flight is overturned, and given to either Hawaiian or American as specified above, then all of the Haneda slots will be more evenly distributed amongst the airlines, allowing for more competition as a whole throughout the entirety of the United States.

Aside from that, the department has done an excellent job accounting for the interests of the general public and it is wonderful to know that as a passenger, we will be able to have much easier access to Tokyo's city center with more available options to fly to Haneda, Tokyo's preferred airport.

Title: Comment from Travel Welfare
Comment:
I have recently had your Notice to Airlines brought to my attention regarding the proposed modernizing of payments of Denied Boarding Compensation.
Your article calls for Airlines, public and other interested institutions to comment and provide information relevant to this area of Airline activity and I would be very grateful if you would consider the following information in your studies.

Travel Welfare is an industry expert in the payment of compensation to disrupted Airline passengers and has developed a purpose-built cloud based system designed specifically for this area of Airline disruption. 
The Travel Welfare Compensation system issues MasterCard prepaid Chip and PIN cards which are instantly activated and loaded with funds at the Airport or at the 'Point of Problem' and can be immediately used by disrupted passengers at any Retail store or ATM which accepts MasterCard. The system records all passenger details and can provide a fully activated and loaded card in a matter of minutes. The Chip and PIN cards are open-loop with an expiry period of six months from the time of activation. 
Upon receipt of the card, the passenger receives a sealed carrier containing the card along with the card PIN number. Further to this, the system automatically produces an electronic letter which provides full details of the Compensation being paid along with full Terms and Conditions and fee tables and will be electronically sent to the passengers email address. 

The system also provides a full suite of reporting capabilities allowing the Airline to provide a multitude of data which includes all aspect of disruption which can be exported in various formats and exported to external systems if required.

For Airlines this greatly reduces cost and enhances the Customer experience. Airlines no longer require back-room teams to research and arrange for payments to be made through checks to passengers, the risk element of storing and handling cash is also fully removed and the cards are worthless until activated by the Travel Welfare system. Passengers instantly receive funds with no further requirement to visit banks or make calls to activate a card. The Travel Welfare system takes care of all of this.

Travel Welfare has been widely used already in certain airports in the USA by Icelandic carrier WOW Air, who received very positive feedback from disrupted passengers affected by their recent issues. 

Issuing Prepaid cards to disrupted passengers is a far more convenient method for passengers who are affected by over-sales or other disruption and has recently been used by Airlines to provide passengers with funds to make payments for hotels and taxis. Issuing prepaid cards to passengers also provides passengers with the knowledge that they will not be required to follow up any unpaid compensation as the matter is settled prior to leaving the airport. The cards also have the convenience of being reloadable should airlines have a requirement to pay additional funds and have recently been used to pay passengers during delays in receiving delayed luggage.

The Travel Welfare system, being cloud based, can be accessed and utilised globally and can be issued from laptop, desktop or from iPad utilising docu-sign to obtain passengers acceptance.

The system is now readily available and further information is attached or can be obtained from www.travelwelfare.com or email sales@travelwelfare.com

Title: Comment from Alia Haley
Comment: While the proposed rule is aimed at the ease and accessibility of electronic funds, I am concerned that a passenger who is denied boarding will not receive proper documentation of the dollar amount that is uploaded onto the card. With a check or cash the denied passenger can easily determine the entire amount owed is included in the payment without need to call and check a balance or use an ATM for the same purpose. I would ask that a printed receipt accompany the issuance of the electronic funds at time of distribution.

Title: Comment from Emma Weber
Comment: Involuntarily bumped passengers should be allowed the choice between cash, check, or electronic means as a way of compensation. This would allow passengers to receive prompt and effective payments in a manner they are comfortable with. In terms of electronic payments, in what forms would the passengers be compensated (i.e. pre-paid credit card, PayPal)? I think a 24-hour requirement between bumping and payment issuance is reasonable and adequate for the purpose of tendering electronic cash equivalent. This short period will help ensure passengers are compensated.

Title: Comment from Daniel Park
Comment: It is striking to know that airlines had to rely on cash or checks for payments to a passenger who got involuntarily "bumped." The vast majority of the public now has access to electronic payment methods and having an option to receive payment electronically makes it much easier for the passenger and possibly could reduce the risk of carrying a physical medium of money off a flight and around an airport. I can see how some might raise concerns for passengers without access to electronic payments, and for that reason, I believe the cash payment method should still be retained.

Title: Comment from Mengyi  Zhu
Comment: I think that notice in electronic form, preferably in email, would be helpful. It is easier to access, and more convenient for record-keeping. Adding cash-equivalents shows a good effort of compensating involuntarily denied customers, but I do not see it making a huge difference. Obviously some people would prefer cash-equivalents over direct checks. However, what denied passengers might care about more is the fact that they cannot take the flight that they legitimately purchased just because the carriers are gambling against full capacities. I think it would be more helpful to eliminate the maximum limit on the amount carriers should pay, and instead simply have them pay certain percentage of the ticket price, if the over-sale trick has to exist.

Title: Comment from Cindy Duan
Comment:
To Whom it May Concern,
the choice of electronic payment is considerate. However, there is risk that passengers cant confirm the transaction at once. Furthermore, a document record accompanied with the compensation (come with no matter which form of compensation) would be better for both customer and airlines to take record.

Title: Comment from Raghad Azhar
Comment:
In my opinion, the proposal of adding electronic compensation for denied boarding passengers (CFR 250.8 Denied boarding compensation) is a great step. However, it should not depend on that only, the type of compensation should be something the flyer can choose. There are many different situations where cash, checks, or electronic payment methods wont be helpful, and of course not all of them in the same exact situation. Therefore, providing and giving the flyer an option to choose the type of compensation would be greatly effective and helpful. 

In regards to the amount of denied boarding compensation (CFR 250.5). The Department of Transportation DOT should definitely impose regulations on airlines on the minimum limit of how much they would compensate a denied boarding flyer voluntarily or involuntarily to ensure the rights of the flyers. Flying from a location to another is always for a purpose and requires time and planning. Being denied boarding would change your plans as a flyer, and waste some of your time as well. Which is why there should be better compensation rules. 

Furthermore, providing an electronic written explanation of denied boarding compensation (CFR 250.9) is very important. Implementing this would ensure passengers and airlines rights are protected and violated or ignored. We are living in a time where the paper isnt depended on much, so implementing an electronic delivery method of the explanation would give flexibility in obtaining the information and saving.

Title: Comment from Samantha Perry
Comment:
Docket No. DOT-OST-2019-0118: 
Limiting page numbers in Environmental Impact Statements will result in less thorough Statements with less information and data that may be critically important. I recommend unlimited page numbers to Environmental Impact Statements, along with a summary. The summary may have a restriction on the number of pages and could meet that same intent of making Statements easier to read

Title: Comment from Anonymous
Comment: I am not sure how the DOT defines "extraneous detail and needless data." Since an environmental impact statement (EIS) is only required when the environmental assessment has determined that significant impacts are likely, then it would seem irresponsible to limit the information presented in the EIS. Any data collected should be documented and presented in the EIS. To implement a policy that could restrict the content included in the EIS would seem to undermine NEPA.

Title: Comment from Donna Buscemi
Comment:
The OFD Interim Policy mandates 75 pages for EAs.  What about FONSIs? Or is it assumed no prescription on their size as they are not usually lengthy?

	The OFD Interim Policy requires lead agencies to obtain concurrence from all cooperating agencies on each project purpose and need, range of alternatives and preferred alternative. The US DOT should, in cooperation with other affected federal agencies, lead the effort in reaching agreement in principle on participation in/acceptance of OFD and establishing a binding conflict resolution process with the agencies in order to avoid unnecessary delays. 

	The OFD Interim Policy also requires all federal agency authorizations to be made within 90 days of the Record of Decision and the establishment of a performance accountability system for tracking OFD projects. The performance accountability system and reporting process should be eliminated or be the sole responsibility of the US DOT to avoid the extra burden on State DOTs by this federal mandate.

	US DOT should note that federal resource agencies require much higher levels of detail to make decisions in the environmental review process. As such, the US DOT should take the lead in reaching agreement with the federal agencies on a consistent level of information needed for these agencies to render their decisions.

Title: Comment from David DeVeau
Comment: There is a need to define levels of disseminating information that is in the best interest of public safety so that it never becomes deceptive and puts public safety at risk.

Title: Comment from Bruce Grimm
Comment:
RE: DOT-OST-2019-0135   FRN 2019-21769

The policy and procedural guidance given to the U.S. Department of Transportation (DOT) by the Office of Fiscal Management (OFM) has always been the driver that ensures that information disseminated to the public and other federal agencies is consistent in form and manner thus helping to fulfill agent and principal purposes.

The certain administrative mechanisms currently in place allow affected persons to seek and obtain correction of information maintained and disseminated by the DOT that does not comply with guidelines.  Problems may arise when the two agencies have different interests and asymmetric information such that the OFM cannot directly ensure that the DOT is always acting in the best interest of the law.  This situation can be alleviated if there is a collective action to review the number and nature of complaints regarding accuracy of information disseminated and how complaints are handled by the DOT.

Aligning the interests of the DOT with the OFM through these and other various mechanisms with active oversight will go a long way towards verification of the of the quality, objectivity, utility and integrity of information compiled and circulated to other federal agencies and the public.

Title: Comment from Braeden Clark
Comment: The Clearing house privacy act in only beneficial to the safety on the roads of our society. Giving the government the power to keep track of individuals who have committed crimes of doing drugs whilst driving can and will keep unsafe drivers off the road. There are no negative side effects to having this act pass. Not only this but it will keep people more safe out on public roadways allowing for less crashes and being able to prevent fatal crashes. Along with this but we will be able to help those who need it most by being able to see who needs therapy or possibly go to drug rehab facilities. The passing of this act would keep those individuals in a safer place and allow for them to get better and get back out on the road only bettering our society and our economy. In conclusion the passing of this act will be very good for not only the safety of the public out on roads but it will keep those individuals who fail their drug tests safer for not crashing themselves and allowing others to get them the vital help that they need. This bill should be passed.

Title: Comment from Wanda Fund
Comment: Please do not allow these records to be removed and/or sealed to make private.  The public has a right to know when people are in violation of the welfare of animals.  Animal cruelty is at an all time high and the public has a right to know that these cruel practices are on-going so that they can make their own decisions as to whether they will continue to support such behavior by buying puppies from puppy mills and paying to watch abusive horse shows like the Tennessee Walking Horse shows.  Providing knowledge to the public so they can make informed choices is vital and will prevent so much cruelty.  The public has a right to know.

Title: Comment from Anonymous
Comment: While the Clearinghouse Act has good intentions, there are some restrictions that should be mentioned. Individuals who have violated the law by driving under the influence of alcohol or drugs should be put into a system of records. As stated in the background, this will hopefully bring more safety to the public and even to employers to ensure the honesty of employees and their own backgrounds. The act should include different consequences for the amount of violations with drugs and alcohol. For example, the first violation should be kept in the system for under two years, while the next violation should be kept in the system for 5 years, and so on. I think the period the records are kept in the system is important because it promotes positive behavior and corrective action in the future for drug and alcohol violations while operating a motor vehicle. The background states these records will have a retention period of 5 years and archived for another 6 years if the violation is resolved. Otherwise the records will remain in the system for 70 years. Again, I think there should be different periods of retaining the records for the number of times the individual has had violations with drugs and alcohol while operating a motor vehicle. I do not think this is necessary for all employers. For example, an employee working an administrative job poses a much less risk than an employee whose job is to drive a delivery truck the majority of the time. While employees seem to have the ability to consent to this act, it may be difficult for them to deny the request for this system of records and keep their job.

Title: Comment from Dylan Young
Comment: I think that this privacy act should be passed. It does not violate any amendments, although one could argue that it does violate the 4th amendment of a person. However, it should not violate the 4th amendment of a person as long as there is probable cause. This will also ensure better public safety as it can keep drunk or intoxicated drivers off the streets, keeping everyone around them safe

Title: Comment from Anonymous
Comment:
In my opinion, this new system can be effective in reducing drunk driving and drug driving, thus reducing the number of car accidents. If Federal Motor Carrier Safety Administration can maintain the drug and alcohol test results of drivers, FMCSA can make CDL or CLP holders, who committed drug and alcohol violations, inaccessible to operate a commercial motor vehicle. 

As a person who needs to drive everyday, I totally support Drug and Alcohol Clearinghouse (Clearinghouse). However, I have some questions regarding this new system of records:

1. If driver does not consent, will clearinghouse still collect and maintain records on the completion of substance abuse programs and then release the information?
2. Will the information collected be shared with insurance company? And will the insurance rate change if the driver committed drug and alcohol violations?
3. Are CDL or CLP holders who have committed drug and alcohol violations still have access to private motor vehicle?

Title: Comment from Richard Diamond
Comment:
"Wireless Roadway Charging System for Electric Vehicles" Patent Application. 
I recently applied for a Patent for a "new" technology, that I ask your council consider in advance of the finalization of the new Transportation Act. 
A major factor impeding the commercialization of electric vehicles is the relative scarcity of plug in type charging stations and the relatively long charging times.  A promising alternative to plug in charging is wireless charging using magnetic field generators embedded in a roadway to couple wirelessly with induction wires in a moving vehicle so as to charge the vehicle battery.  But there are problems with the wireless charging road systems that have been proposed to date. Currently proposed systems involve burying the magnetic field generators under the top course paving of the roadway.  These systems require re-paving of entire road networks, which is both prohibitively expensive and would take decades to implement.  Moreover, repaving an asphalt top course over magnetic field generators will subject them to the enormous pressure of compacting the asphalt, which is likely to damage them.  Locating magnetic field generators in the road base also exposes them to groundwater and road runoff.  Compacted asphalt does not readily propagate magnetic fields, and road paving may be several feet thick, thereby limiting the inductive potential of the system. Consequently, there remains the need for a wireless road charging system that enables placement of the magnetic field generators near the surface of the roadway in an environment that is protected from moisture, paving compaction forces and the weight of vehicles. This technology incorporates multiple magnetic field generators into seam gaskets which laterally support the top course and seal the seams of each paved travelled lane of a roadway.  Examples of such seam gaskets are the “Asphalt Paving Seam Gasket” as disclosed in U.S. Patent No. 9,394,650, and the “Asphalt Paving Seam Sealer System” as disclosed in U.S. Patent No. 8,439,597, both of which are incorporated herein by reference.  The seam gaskets are designed to form an edge seal for road pavement lanes and to buttress asphalt compaction.  The gasket material is a water-impermeable rigid polymer or polymer blend that withstands compressive forces. Therefore, with the magnetic field generators embedded in the gasket, they are protected from moisture and the compressive forces of asphalt paving, as well as the weight of travelling vehicles. Moreover, the magnetic field generators can be embedded near the top of the gasket’s seam wall,
so that they are close to the road surface, from which the magnetic field can readily propagate. The wireless charging occurs while the vehicle is travelling along a dedicated charging lane of a roadway.  Each charging lane has a top-course that is laterally supported by two paving seam gaskets, one along the edge of the right-side of the lane and one along the edge of the left-side of the lane (as viewed facing the direction of travel). Multiple magnetic field generators are embedded at uniform intervals along each of the paving seam gaskets.  The magnetic field generators comprise permanent magnets, electromagnets, or a combination of both.  If electro-magnets are used, they are electrically connected by wiring through the seam gaskets to one or more DC power supplies.  Optionally, each of the magnetic field generators can be enclosed in a waterproof, rigid, non-magnetic case, in order to further protect it from compressive forces and environmental elements.  Each magnetic field generator has two magnetic poles, which are designated North and South, and which are aligned in a generally vertical direction within the paving seam gasket. For each charging lane, the upper poles of the magnetic field generators embedded in the right side paving seam gasket must be opposite in polarity to the upper poles of the magnetic field generators embedded in the left-side paving seam gaskets, in order to generate a magnetic field transversely across the charging lane.   The electric powered vehicle is equipped with an “EZPass” type device  which measures and compiles data of as to the distance traveled in a charging lane for billing purposes to the vehicles owner.    The EZPass type device can be of the type commonly used for billing of highway tolls. A major advantage of this system is that it can be economically implemented in conjunction with a nation-wide roadway infrastructure program.  Since the wireless charging system is incorporated in asphalt paving seam gaskets, its installation becomes part of the top-course paving process
needed to maintain and upgrade the nation’s highway system.  The typical highway repaving cycle is about 15 years, within which time the entire U.S. highway system could incorporate wireless charging lanes with only a modest additional investment of public funds.

Title: Comment from Regina Kenner
Comment:
Weekend traffic on the I-95 corridor from Fredericksburg to Washington, DC is as heavy, if not more so, than weekday traffic, especially during the summer months and the November/December Holiday Season.

My suggestion:
Open the VRE on Weekends.  This will allow locals, traveling locally, to avoid I-95, get to the metro more efficiently and reduce traffic volume.
Thank you for allowing this comment.

Title: Comment from Mary Beth Roberts
Comment: Someone really needs to look at the traffic backups in and around the whole Fredericksburg area; when you mentione Fburg to any out of towners -their comment is, oh wow, you live in F'burg -we hate driving through there, for we always get held up in heavy traffic and delayed, on our way up or down Rt 95 in our travels thru .. I work right off of the Rt 17N/Warrenton exit, whereas we realize work is being done currently for this exit onto Rt 95S,which causes major backups for folks working at our company, as well as Geico when they get out of work - I live right off of the Exit 126 Massaponnax, as well as a majority of our employees here-total nightmare to get to work as well as getting home - last week, it took me almost an hour to go from Exit 126 to Exit 133 in the morning commute, whereas you have to avoid Rt 95N, then Rt 1 N fills up, so you have to cut through town in Fburg around Rt 3/Butler Rd which also backs up; and almost every evening after work (anywhere from 4:30-7pm) you can count on almost a 2 mile backup in the right hand lane of Rt 95S for folks getting off of this Exit 126-I've almost been rearended 3 times just in the last month, because folks come barreling down that middle lane and then try to cut over to the right lane in order to exit, because they are impatient waiting in the 2 mile backup - pls someone come sit in this during the week so that you can experience it - it is deterring folks from wanting to stay at our company due to the area traffic.. I live in one of the apartment complexes on the Spotsylvania pkwy which cuts from Rt 1 to Rt 208-there is no light to get out onto the parkway, out of Abberly Apts across from CarMax, and they are getting ready to lease out brand new apts across the street (Kingson Apts), of which there is no light for them to get on to pkwy, and even when you do, they will find terrible backups getting on Rt 1N onto the Rt95N exit, that also backs up quite a ways -there are also several new apartment complexes that opened recently that add to this (Allure at Jefferson, Station On additions, Crossroad Stations)PLEASE fix the traffic issues here -it is honestly wanting me to retire and move away from here sooner rather than later!!  thank you

Title: Comment from Richard Mills
Comment:
PA And Philly Hate @PhillyCrazyLEDS A.K.A. Philly Crazy Lights! Save PA!
http://www.Twitter.com/PhillyCrazyLEDS

Title: Comment from Anonymous
Comment:
I think the government needs to invest in research for what I will call 'smart lights'. It is amazing the number of times I will be stopped at a light when there is no traffic coming in the direction that has a green light. Another example of you might be going through town when traffic is rather light so you actually get to drive the speed limit and yet get stopped at every light??? Why aren't they timed better? If light traffic is that messed up just think how that translates when traffic is heavier!! 
   This type technology would not only help the flow of traffic, it would help drivers tempers and it would help prevent lights getting messed up because people just run the lights after sitting there for no reason, then the cycle they tripped has no one going on that cycle. It would help encourage people to be law abiding and not run red lights as often as they would know that the traffic flow was better so there was not as much reason to 'cheat'. It would also be an environmental boon to not have cars just sitting still for no reason. It would certainly make the department of transportation look much better. 
   I don't have the expertise to create such a system, but this should be far easier than self driving cars and would spread the benefit around to the entire society much quicker. Why is this not being done? If anything lights seem to be getting worse, not better. 
   This project would greatly benefit the Fredericksburg VA area that another commenter was complaining about.
