Title: Comment from Richie Dimmerling II
Comment:
1.	. Identifying Unmet Needs in Rural Transportation

A.	What infrastructure issues are contributing to high fatality rates on rural roadways and rail-highway grade crossings (e.g., roadway condition or geometry, driver behavior, wildlife collisions)?
a.	Infrastructure - substandard roadway geometry - Lack of barriers crossing guards and guardrail - narrow bridges and roadways - blind hills and curves with inadequate site distances - 
b.	Social - people behavior 

B.	What unique challenges do rural areas face related to infrastructure condition (e.g., age of infrastructure or equipment, including vehicles, bridge closures or postings, types of freight carried, weather resiliency)?
a.	Local seasonal hauling restrictions due to frost and frost law permits (substandard roadways experience determination due to frost heave and heavy loads) 
b.	Limited right of way, narrow bridges, increased flood risk in rural communities due to in adequate bridge openings
c.	Everyone has a lack of funding

C.	How does infrastructure usage (e.g., access to public transportation, technology deployment) affect the lives of rural Americans?
a.	Displacement of elderly that are not independent enough to drive or own vehicles 
b.	May reduce the access to medical services or increase the time in emergency service response

D.	What types of infrastructure projects are most needed in rural communities to meet national transportation priorities such as safety and economic competitiveness?
a.	Bridge and roadway reconstruction
b.	Increase access to separated pedestrian facilities (sidewalks and trails)

E. What types of rural transportation projects or services do rural communities find challenging to fund? 
a.  Roadway reconstruction -  Roadway upgrading to current standards because many require acquiring additional property to improve the geometry of the roadway -  Public transportation that is inherently expensive and cost prohibitive. 

F.	What additional or alternative methods can be used to identify and prioritize rural transportation projects for funding through discretionary grants?
a.	Perform a system wide review by identifying the 5 highest crash locations of each rural community (county, small town, village, etc.) based on similar criterion (ex. Fatalities, accidents per million vehicle miles) and map the information in a universal GIS system
b.	oversee and fund a national project that will review each location to determine the geometric issues or social issues at each location that are contributing to the crashes for each specific location
c.	create a preliminary plan with cost estimates to address the needed infrastructure or social solutions for each location
d.	Work with local leaders to fund the improvements with grants, 3P, private funding, etc. 

2. Addressing Unmet Needs through DOT Discretionary Grant Programs

A.	What resources or direct assistance could DOT provide to support rural transportation projects or reach communities that may not be aware of DOT discretionary programs?
a.	Funding - specifically related to ROUTES and projects selected based on the criteria and plan above 

B.	What challenges do rural communities face when applying for DOT grants and financial assistance (e.g., project prioritization, eligibility requirements, funding match)?
a.	Awareness of the programs 
b.	Funding matches are challenging for many to achieve - some options to consider may include 3P or bonds - the gas tax has recently been increased in Ohio however the long term viability of this method of funding will continue to come up short - counties may already be using conveyance fees or registration fees to help generate funding 
c.	RUMA's (road use maintenance agreements) with local business and trucking firms 

C.	What types of technical assistance would be effective for navigating the application process?
a.	Engineering assistance for plan preparation

Title: Comment from Doug  Wright
Comment:
1.	Identifying Unmet Needs in Rural Transportation
Union County Oregon Public Works Department is responsible for 600 miles of roads that consist of 150 paved and 450 gravel. The paved farmed to market roads are classified as fair to poor condition. A vast amount of land within Union County Oregon is under jurisdiction of the USFS. A stable revenue stream from the Federal Government is needed to ensure Union County can meet the needs of improving pavement condition and increase maintenance for all roads within the county.  
A.	What infrastructure issues are contributing to high fatality rates on rural roadways and rail-highway grade crossings (e.g., roadway condition or geometry, driver behavior, wildlife collisions)? Most of the paved roads are losing shoulder width due to increased farm equipment and increased truck traffic. 
B. What unique challenges do rural areas face related to infrastructure condition (e.g., age of infrastructure or equipment, including vehicles, bridge closures or postings, types of freight carried, weather resiliency)? Equipment is failing due to age and heavy use. Balancing the material needs and equipment needs is a constant battle due low revenue and uncertainty of revenue.  
C. How does infrastructure usage (e.g., access to public transportation, technology deployment) affect the lives of rural Americans? Public transportation is starting to develop, but is limited due vast amount of area to cover. Ageing population due not have adequate access to markets etc.  
D. What types of infrastructure projects are most needed in rural communities to meet national transportation priorities such as safety and economic competitiveness? Capital improvement projects that consist of paving and/or apply oil Matts. 
E. What types of rural transportation projects or services do rural communities find challenging to fund? Capital improvement projects that require match. A 6 million dollar projects requires 10.27% match. That amount could be one quarter of the budget. 
F. What additional or alternative methods can be used to identify and prioritize rural transportation projects for funding through discretionary grants? Allow the rural communities to compete for funding with same types of population and road miles. Competing with Major metropolitan areas puts rural counties in a disadvantage.    
2. Addressing Unmet Needs Through DOT Discretionary Grant Programs. Reduce the match requirements up to and including no match. 
A. What resources or direct assistance could DOT provide to support rural transportation projects or reach communities that may not be aware of DOT discretionary programs? Provide one million dollar grants with no match and remove federal requirements. Allow counties to use their own purchasing policy to hire contractors. This would create jobs and provide capital improvement projects the public wants. 
B. What challenges do rural communities face when applying for DOT grants and financial assistance (e.g., project prioritization, eligibility requirements, funding match)? Match
C. What types of technical assistance would be effective for navigating the application process? We use

Title: Comment from Anonymous
Comment:
Our entire county is part of an Metropolitan Planning Organization (MPO), but only a small portion of the county has been designated as an urbanized area.  Therefore, it is difficult to get funding for projects for our county since the MPO allocates money based on the urbanized area population only.

Federal standards for bridge projects exceed state & local standards.  This can make the projects unnecessarily expensive.

Our County dedicates significant resources to load rating bridges instead of using that time and money to repair or replace bridges.

Title: Comment from Illinois District 5 Rural County Engineer
Comment:
1A. Our largest contributor to fatalities has been driver behavior. I believe this is partially due to phones and partially due to non-obedience to traffic signage (high speeds, rolling stop signs, etc). I do believe that we have been lucky that our roadway alignments, rail grade crossings, and intersection geometry haven't caused more accidents but I believe that those would be our next largest issue.

1B. Our largest challenge was the maintenance of aging equipment. However, Illinois has passed the gas tax increase and that should help alleviate our inability to purchase new equipment moving forward. That being said, I believe our next large issue is the safety of rail grade crossings on the county, township, and small municipality roadways. Illinois has programs that replace a select few of these crossings yearly. However, townships and very small municipalities are required to front $750k to $2M dollars adjust the crossing approaches, provide gate arms and flashing lights. As many small localities are very uneasy or completely unable to front those funds, many rural crossings, which these small towns and townships were founded around, remain highly traveled and frighteningly unprotected.

1C. Rural and suburban Americans are more reliant on roadway infrastructure than urban. The majority are required a motor vehicle to obtain their basic necessities and earn an income. Furthermore, the U.S. Agricultural industry relies on these roads being able to carry increasingly large husbandry equipment to plant, harvest, and haul. Thus our roadways, culverts, and bridges must be wide enough and have the load capacity to safely serve those needs as well as accommodate the small vehicular traffic utilizing the roads.

1D. I believe the first priority should be upfront funding for grade crossing protection for local roadways due to the fiscal challenges highlighted in 1B.

1E. See concerns in 1B. I also believe rural communities have trouble funding pedestrian projects like ADA ramps.

Title: Comment from Richard McGuinness
Comment:
The largest unmet need of rural (mostly local) transportation agencies are a lack of skills in basic traffic operations and identification of hazardous conditions, particularly where traffic volumes are low enough not to generate any patterns or statistical hot spots.  Many of these conditions are simply not recognized, and could be corrected with a simple fix.

Rather than concentrating on spot improvements and shiny object, a program of improving the skill level of on the road investigators and supervisors in the area of hazard identification and basic remediation would be most beneficial.  Look for way to assist this group by providing incentives and funding for perusing associate degrees in civil/transportation at local community colleges, in person or on line. Encouragement in longer term LTAP programs, such as Roads Scholar, with appropriate certifications upon completion are a possible approach. 

Another need is simply for adequate funding to enable the rural agencies to have enough equipment and personnel to make repairs and system preservation.

One last comment:  The application for assistance should not be so complex that the local agencies cannot perform the task in house.

Title: Comment from Danny Colwell
Comment: There are major obstacles preventing poor rural communities from receiving rural transportation grants.  I have submitted a "BUILD" grant application for my county and there was no consideration given to applicant financial need when selecting grant recipients.  Furthermore, a poor rural community can not spend tens of thousands of dollars for a consultant to prepare a professional grant application with the hope of receiving funding.  Rural highway departments can barely patch pot holes and gravel roads.  We can not gamble our limited resources on the slight chance we will receive a Federal highway grant.  I also take issue with the grant evaluation process.  If I managed a more prosperous highway department I might submit a grant application to widen and existing road with 11' lanes and aggregate shoulders to make it have 13' lanes and paved shoulders.  If I wanted to make this type of improvement there is research to demonstrate the value to safety to widen lanes and pave shoulders.  However, the highway system I maintain has many miles of unpaved roads.  There have been no safety improvement factors established for converting gravel roads to paved surface.  The Federal grant applications are set up to turn good roads into great roads.  They are not designed to help the poorest highway department turn the most primitive roads into paved, all weather roads.

Title: Comment from City of Redmond, Oregon
Comment:
Redmond, Oregon is a community of 30,000 in Central Oregon.  We are among the fastest growing cities in the country.  We are focused on three primary transportation infrastructure projects which will improve safety, freight mobility and leverage industrial job growth and traded sector jobs:  

1) Improvements to US Highway 97 (and State highway which connect Central Oregon to Washington and California) ($50M - $70M);

2) The construction of an interchange across US 97 at Quarry Avenue. This project is critical for creating a safe ingress/egress freight connection to US 97 at a location that is adjacent to nearly 1,000 undeveloped acres of industrially zoned land ($20M - $30M); and 

3) An industrial arterial that connects Highway 126 to US 97 ($8M - $10M).

An adjacent rail line bordering these properties adds difficulties to each of these projects.

Projects 1 and 2 in particular are heavily used. Deschutes County in which Redmond is located has nearly 180,000 residents which travel US 97 regularly.  This is compounded given that the Central Oregon region attracts more than 4 million overnight visitors annually.  The need to keep US 97 commercially viable and a safe passage for both commercial and passenger vehicles is very important.

All of these projects require some mix of local, state, and federal funding. Oregon struggles to find adequate resources to invest in rural highways which are of statewide importance.  Many of the state's resources are directed towards large-scale highways in major metropolitan areas (Portland) where failing infrastructure effects millions of users.
  
The rural highways in Central Oregon share common characteristics.  They are critical links between the cities (particularly Madras, Prineville, Bend and Redmond) and they all face the problems of safety, capacity, and maintenance.

The Administrative requirements associated with receiving federal dollars is very onerous for cities of Redmond's size (about 30,000).  The accountability of funds being properly invested with the staff time associated with overseeing the grants needs to better balanced. It would be helpful if DOT could provide technical assistance from the application process through the project management (draw down of funds).

Title: Comment from Orie Rubalcava
Comment:
Although I have not answered all requested information, I hope that the information provided below is beneficial to the ROUTES initiative.

1. What unique challenges do rural areas face related to infrastructure condition (e.g., age of infrastructure or equipment, including vehicles, bridge closures or postings, types of freight carried, weather resiliency)?

As with most of the country, rural communities suffer from outdated and in need of repair infrastructure issues. The lack of funding from larger tax bases, like those found in urban areas, prevents rural areas from funding projects alone or from providing an adequate match for federal funding. 

2. How does infrastructure usage (e.g., access to public transportation, technology deployment) affect the lives of rural Americans?

Public transportation is a crucial part of rural area movement, whether it is for individual or commercial use. Generally, the inhabitants of rural areas have little to no disposable income and rely on public transportation to accomplish daily tasks such as obtaining supplies and going to work or school. A breakdown of public transportation can have significant ramifications. 

3. What types of infrastructure projects are most needed in rural communities to meet national transportation priorities such as safety and economic competitiveness?

The most beneficial infrastructure project is one that promotes free movement that is fast, efficient, safe, and affordable. A public transportation system would have to be capable of intricately linking rural areas to urban areas so as to provide a means of expanding one's opportunity for jobs, education, and resources. Additionally, such system would permit those living in urban areas to seek rural homes, theoretically increasing the revenue of a given rural community. 
Newer transportation technology provides an opportunity for extraordinarily fast transportation over long distances. If speeds like those claimed by the hyperloop or maglev come to fruition, such transportation could give people access to different locations and resources that would otherwise not be possible. 

4. What challenges do rural communities face when applying for DOT grants and financial assistance (e.g., project prioritization, eligibility requirements, funding match)?

Often times a rural community lacks the funding and ability to accomplish the preliminary requirements to apply for DOT grants. Take for consideration the New Starts discretionary grant that requires recipients to perform feasibility reviews and environmental reviews in advance of receipt of a construction grant agreement.

5. What resources or direct assistance could DOT provide to support rural transportation projects or reach communities that may not be aware of DOT discretionary programs?

Possibly separate funding to get past the initial studies and phases required to start large construction projects. This would better enable rural communities to compete with urban areas for discretionary grants.

Title: Comment from Anonymous
Comment:
Rural roads are frequently the critical arteries for commuter and freight access to the interstate system and urban centers.  Therefore, the census does not fully capture the importance of rural roads to the national transportation system.  In my experience, the major unmet needs are:
A.  Generally poor design and condition are responsible for the high fatality rates;
B.  Rural and the urban/rural interface areas face unique challenges in getting easy access to the interstate system or urban centers.  The arbitrary census distinction presents an artificial urban/rural overlay to most federal funding programs that discriminates against these areas that have too high of a population to be rural but an insufficient tax base to meet often higher urban cost share requirements (issues are aging infrastructure, mixed commuter, resident and freight traffic, bridge closures, and weather resiliency especially for critical evacuation routes);
D.  Rapid, safe and efficient access to/from rural areas to nearby urban centers and the interstate system is critical to maintain the quality of life and economic future of these lost urban fringe areas that are captured in an urban census block.
E.  Intermodal transportation systems that integrate, rail, freight, commuter and resident needs are a priority.  Projects should also recognize and address emergency evacuation and medical service needs for regional (rural) medical centers.
F.  Account for hard to quantify secondary benefits in public safety (evacuation routes), access to medical services (regional rural medical clinics), commuter times, and freight-also factor in the economic competitiveness of access to the interstate system on job creation/retention.

2 DOT Discretionary Grant Programs
A.  The BUILD program is very helpful but as discussed above, the cost share requirements for "urban" projects is very difficult for communities on the urban fringe to meet.
B.  Urban/Rural distinction-often a road can be a dividing line on a census block between urban/rural areas.  The construction costs may be higher in urban areas despite the majority of the project being in a rural area or serving a rural population-these "bright line" distinctions made in DC are very problematic on the ground.
C.  Recently many federal agencies have created intergovernmental or inter-agency -- "integrators" to assist local communities in integrating various programs within a department or between departments to leverage funding on projects-this can be very helpful as local "rural" sponsors attempt to secure funding from multiple financial assistance programs including state programs.  Timing can also be critical as a rural community may be proactive and start the permitting of a major proposed transportation project in anticipation of funding only to find that the funding is delayed and the permits lapse and the whole process clogs up.

Hopefully DOT will use the ROUTES initiative to make meaningful improvements in the delivery of technical and financial assistance to rural and urban fringe communities.

Thank you

Title: Comment from Anonymous
Comment:
Due to the sparcity of population in rural areas, public transportation must be viewed differently, it cannot be as volume based and it must require a minimum of a 6 month trial period to assure that people are informed about its existence; these things take more time.

Resources need to be allocated based on work schedules and determined in conjunction with employers and employees. Schedules also need to be created in conjunction with health care providers and long distance transportation options.

Title: Comment from Illinois Farm Bureau
Comment:
According to the Illinois Department of transportation, in 2018, 53.1% of fatal accidents were while traversing rural routes. Of all fatal collisions (951) in 2018, head on (126), pedestrian (158) and fixed object (273) accounted for 58%. Wildlife only accounted for 0.8% of fatal accidents in 2018. Updates to roadway condition, signalization, and increased education are needed to increase safety.

Nearly half of all Illinois county and township road miles are in deferred or suspended maintenance. That accounts for approximately 42,000 miles in need of maintenance. Illinois road jurisdictions rely heavily on funds distributed through the state motor fuel tax which was increased in 2019 for the first time in nearly 30 years. The motor fuel tax has seen a decline in purchasing power by 60% from 2000 to 2014. The lack of funds, increased backlog in maintenance, and the rising cost of construction have increased the number of road and bridge postings severely stressing rural infrastructure. Most rural routes were designed and built prior to the implementation of the 80,000-pound weight limit.  The size and weight of farm equipment and commercial vehicles that access these routes have grown and continues to show the inadequacies of current road dimensions and allowable weight. Assistance is needed to help road systems "catch up" and provide economic benefit to communities. 

Increased investment in infrastructure and supported transportation systems increases ability for rural Americans access to their communities. Increased funding in rural public transportation assists the aging rural population allowing them access to the community for their needs. Many rural community services are becoming county wide rather than community wide increasing the need for transportation assistance.

Road and bridge projects make up a large majority of rural Illinois needs. Illinois motorists lose $16.4 billion annually on road systems as a result of needed repairs, lost time, and fuel. The increase in postings for lower weight limits adds length and additional cost on to each trip. Updating and upgrading rural infrastructure will allow easier access in and out of communities. 

Road and bridge projects are the most funded but also, the most challenging to fund. The large costs associated with executing a bridge project impact the budget of a jurisdiction.  Illinois has hundreds of road jurisdictions. In many cases, these jurisdictions are operated by one full time employee. Some maintain less than 50 miles. Obtaining the funding to execute a project can be difficult to fund with limited resources and income. This also makes it difficult to apply for federal grants and compete for funding. The experience and technical knowledge needed to submit a competitive application make the process challenging. 

Additional input from local jurisdictions should be included to ensure that those unable to apply and compete for funding are properly assisted. Designing a way for these small jurisdictions to be made more aware and be provided the assistance to apply would assist in upgrading a stressed system. The design-build method should be considered and authorized for projects where the method would assist in project delivery. 

Communities and local jurisdictions need assistance in technical application writing and easy to access step by step instructions. Resources to connect local officials to DOT notices are needed.

Due to the size and staff, eligibility requirements and local funding is difficult to meet.  Local jurisdictions recognize the need for maintenance or projects but are unable to produce a competitive application. Due to the hindered budgets of local jurisdictions they are often unable to meet matching requirements.

Grant writers and specific instructions would assist in the application process. Many jurisdictions are understaffed and/or unable to dedicate resources to apply. Many times, this is hired out if the jurisdiction is able.

Title: Comment from Transportation Departments of Idaho, Montana, North Dakota, South Dakota, and Wyoming
Organization Name: DOTs of ID MT ND SD & WY
Government Agency: DOTs of ID MT ND SD & WY
Comment:
TO:       Office of the Secretary of Transportation, U.S. Department of Transportation (OST)
FROM:   DOTs of Idaho, Montana, North Dakota, South Dakota and  Wyoming
RE:       Comments in Docket No. DOT-OST-2019-0167, "ROUTES" Initiative

Attached for consideration by OST in the above-referenced docket are the comments of the transportation departments of ID, MT, ND, SD & WY.  These five State DOTs thank OST for its consideration of these comments.

Attachment: 5 pages

Title: Comment from Anonymous
Comment: Rural communities face many challenges, all of which are tied to funding and implementation.  The majority of Federal grants require that some part of the project be tied to a State Route, be within MPO boundaries, create substantial economic growth, etc.  This methodology does not apply to a significant portion of rural infrastructure.  Funding opportunities are needed for rural projects that address a local need and are also only available to Counties or Cities - not State DOT's.

Title: Comment from Anonymous
Comment:
Expansion funds for small communities that want to purchase a van for in-town service would be great. 
 We have many small communities in our service area that would love to have just in town service.

Title: Comment from Northern Nevada Development Authority
Comment:
Northern Nevada Development Authority (NNDA), the state-designated regional economic development authority for Nevada's 5-county Sierra Region, salutes USDOT for supporting rural areas in such a substantive way through the ROUTES Initiative. Local governments are generally not aware of the over 35 USDOT programs that could benefit their communities or how to match their needs with those programs. This is especially true for the ROUTES priorities: safety improvement, infrastructure enhancement, and transportation infrastructure usage. NNDA would like to leverage its role as connector, navigator and problem-solver for the region it serves, as well as statewide, on behalf of ROUTES.  

NNDA would like to see ROUTES funding available to support local government outreach regarding the program. We propose allowing economic development organizations, like us, to develop a presentation about the purpose, function and priorities of ROUTES that we could provide to our local city and county governments. This would help us to help them more effectively identify the transportation needs of their communities that can be coordinated with ROUTES and other USDOT programs. It would also help us to work with state government regarding any matching funds.

For the purposes of federal programs, Nevada's Sierra Region is small enough to be manageable and large enough to be statistically significant.  NNDA would like to propose the Sierra Region as a pilot for the ROUTES Initiative for the following reasons: 1) NNDA is leading a feasibility study, as part of the Nevada State Rail Plan update, to explore how the City of Fernley can leverage its close proximity to the state's freight rail tracks to become a multi-modal freight transportation hub for existing and growing industry sectors; 2) the region's growing economy has created the need for improving both rail and truck safety in the region; 3) the region's transportation infrastructure needs include both new structures and repairs to support the growing and diversifying economy; and 4) there is a need for infrastructure enhancements of the regional airports within the Sierra Region for greater connectivity to better support growing commerce, including logistics and business tourism. 

The U.S. government owns approximately 85% of Nevada's land mass of 110,567 square miles. Over 85% of Nevada's rural and frontier population are located over 95,431 square miles or 86.9% of the state's land mass. Most of the Silver State's nearly 12,000 miles of freight rail tracks are located in its rural areas, helping to meet the logistics needs of key industry sectors. Nevada's 5-county Sierra Region, that NNDA serves, encompasses 7,009 square miles and a population over 165,450. It is the 3rd largest metropolitan region in the state, and includes Carson City (state capital) which is a federally-designated MSA. The region is located within easy access to Nevada's multi-modal transportation system and a one-day truck transit range of key U.S. markets and deep sea ports. Key industry sectors in the region include mining, manufacturing, and agriculture, all of which continue to grow. Emerging sectors are aerospace (particularly UAS/UAV), general aviation, construction, and logistics. Please see the attached Fact Sheet for more information.

Title: Comment from Regional Transportation Workgroup, Brazos Valley Council of Governments
Comment: Funding for rural transportation should be set up similar to the block grant programs. Funding should go directly to the rural communities to be used for but not limited to projects that relate to; infrastructure, public transportation, operating costs, services, marketing, bus purchases, etc. Small rural communities need increased funding options for projects where funding does not already exist. Funding for RPO planning would also be beneficial to help assist rural communities develop plans that help them identify and reach their goals. We would like to see funding metrics based on return on investment, increased quality of life and/or access to community services (i.e. health care and food).

Title: Comment from Chad Neese
Comment:
1 (a)  	From 2015-2017 most fatal crashes within our region were the result of hitting fixed objects off the roadway per the Virginia Department of Vehicles Traffic Records Electronic Data Systems.  I would have to defer to the Virginia Department of Transportation on the matter of any specific infrastructure issues at those locations.  Generally speaking, geometric issues on rural roadways are a concern.

1 (b)	Many roads and bridges remain quite narrow and around 7% of our regions bridges are rated as "poor" based on information from the Statewide Planning System.  Several of these bridges are located on the primary east-west corridor that freight is dependent upon.  Flooding continues to be an issue, as roadways and bridges have both been negatively impacted.

1 (c)	Rural residents lack the transportation options available in more urban areas.  Dependency on family, friends, or scheduling a service limits the true mobility of those who are unable to drive.

1 (d)	Bring roadways and bridges up to current standards. 

1 (e)	Bringing roadways and bridges up to current standards.  Roundabouts can be challenging to rural areas with limited funds due to the additional right-of-way and relocation of utilities that are generally required.  Public transportation is also a challenge due to costs.  Multi-modal trails along former railways face significant funding issues when new bridges or boring under roads are required for trail connectivity.

1 (f)	Have rural areas only complete with other truly rural areas for funds.

2 (a)	Funding for projects.

2 (b)	Knowing about the programs in a timely manner and being able to afford the required match.  Is it possible to either remove the local match for rural areas or for the match to be determined based on the Distressed Communities Index or some other acceptable criteria?

2 (c)	Engineering assistance.

Title: Comment from Anonymous
Comment: Rural communities need the process to secure grant funding to be easier, due to limitations in resources. County roads and bridges are a focus of infrastructure improvements to maintain them and increase safety. Roads that carry oil field traffic are quickly destroyed, this roads are always on the list for needing maintenance.

Title: Comment from Anonymous
Comment:
The biggest need for rural counties and communities is funding and deregulation to streamline road and bridge reconstruction.  Many rural highways are in need of significant reconstruction to improve the driving surface, widen shoulders, flatten slopes, and add other safety improvements.  These projects are difficult enough to get completed and reducing red tape, mitigation, and administrative costs would allow projects to get completed in a shorter time frame and with fewer dollars.  

Bottom line, when we develop federal regulations and oversight we should look through the lens of "is what we're doing going to result in stretching our dollars to put down more money into the road versus into regulation and oversight!".

Title: Comment from Caesar Arizpe
Comment:
1. Identifying Unmet Needs in Rural Transportation 
A. What infrastructure issues are contributing to high fatality rates on rural roadways and rail-highway grade crossings (e.g., roadway condition or geometry, driver behavior, wildlife collisions)?  
B. What unique challenges do rural areas face related to infrastructure condition (e.g., age of infrastructure or equipment, including vehicles, bridge closures or postings, types of freight carried, weather resiliency)? 
C. How does infrastructure usage (e.g., access to public transportation, technology deployment) affect the lives of rural Americans?  Increases volume of traffic on the rural roads
D. What types of infrastructure projects are most needed in rural communities to meet national transportation priorities such as safety and economic competitiveness? Funds for roadway and bridge reconstruction 
E. What types of rural transportation projects or services do rural communities find challenging to fund? Low occupancy areas
F. What additional or alternative methods can be used to identify and prioritize rural transportation projects for funding through discretionary grants?  Methods need to address the cost of services to develop the design for smaller projects.  Costs of design, surveys, utility clearance, environmental surveys plus the match make smaller projects cost prohibitive.
2. Addressing Unmet Needs Through DOT Discretionary Grant Programs 
A. What resources or direct assistance could DOT provide to support rural transportation projects or reach communities that may not be aware of DOT discretionary programs? See "F" above
B. What challenges do rural communities face when applying for DOT grants and financial assistance (e.g., project prioritization, eligibility requirements, funding match)? Expertise in grant writing
C. What types of technical assistance would be effective for navigating the application process? Public Comment DOT invites comments by all those interested in the Rural Opportunities to Use Transportation for Economic Success (ROUTES) initiative. Expertise in grant writing

Title: Comment from Dave Cooper
Comment:
If the goal is to leave our children a stronger, healthier, happier country than we inherited, then we should encourage 
economic development in urban areas, not rural.   
There are several reasons for this:
*  worker commuting distances are shorter in urban areas  -  Why force people to drive to the middle of nowhere for a job?
*  freight transportation is more efficient when origins & destinations are concentrated in one place  -  Ask a UPS driver.
*  locating in urban areas with barge, ship, and train terminals often allows use of highly efficient modes of freight transportation
      -  Someday, when petroleum becomes scarce, our children will appreciate this.
*  concentrating development in cities helps keep America beautiful.   

Thank you for asking for my comments.   That doesn't happen too often.   :)

Sincerely,

Dave Cooper
Pittsburgh, PA

Title: Comment from Anonymous
Comment:
Many rural communities that thrived in a previous era now have crumbling infrastructure inside their jurisdictional boundaries on federal aid routes.  Often these projects do not qualify for existing dedicated federal funding, instead falling into a preservation/enhancement category with little local tax support to deliver on the needs.  These projects typically are smaller in scope and show up in communities struggling to maintain autonomy.

Dedicated federal funding allowing financial flexibility for these infrastructure improvements (roadway base failure, storm sewer failures, enhancements) would not only be proactive towards potentially bigger safety issues, but also add a spark to the community culture that so many suburban/urban communities continue to experience in this strong economy.

Title: Comment from Arizona Department of Transportation
Comment:
Following are general comments with some examples submitted by the Arizona Department of Transportation. This does not necessarily include 100% of the rural roadway issues in Arizona. 
		
1. Identifying Unmet Needs in Rural Transportation

A. What infrastructure issues are contributing to high fatality rates on rural roadways and rail-highway grade crossings (e.g., roadway condition or geometry, driver behavior, wildlife collisions)?

Driver behavior (e.g., inattention, DUI, speeding), extreme weather conditions causing visibility issues and slippery pavement, dust storm, inadequate shoulder width, wild animals are some of the common issues found in Arizona. 

B. What unique challenges do rural areas face related to infrastructure condition (e.g., age of infrastructure or equipment, including vehicles, bridge closures or postings, types of freight carried, weather resiliency)?

Massive delays due to crashes on rural roadways after a serious crash, longer emergency response time due to road closures are common.

C. How does infrastructure usage (e.g., access to public transportation, technology deployment) affect the lives of rural Americans?

Arizona has 22 federally recognized Indian tribes, Communities and Native Nations. Public roads in rural areas, especially through tribal lands and BIA/tribal roadways are limited. Moreover, the current road conditions are not satisfactory. Some of the bridges are rated poor or fair. Communication technology has not been implemented throughout the state, especially in rural jurisdictions. These issues pose a huge challenge in terms of people and freight movement as well as their safety. 

D. What types of infrastructure projects are most needed in rural communities to meet national transportation priorities such as safety and economic competitiveness?

Countermeasures to address rural road safety issues like lane departure, intersection improvements, collector and local road development and existing road improvement. Bridge rehabilitation or reconstruction is also critical in many rural areas. 

E. What types of rural transportation projects or services do rural communities find challenging to fund?

Medium to high cost projects that cannot justify funding using data driven analysis, such as bridge reconstruction, systemic safety improvements, intersection improvement requiring additional fund to acquire land such as roundabout construction. Population density can be another challenge for very small jurisdictions. Rural roads on tribal lands consist of tribal and BIA operated roadways which are in need of preservation and improvements but may not be eligible for FHWA funding. 

F. What additional or alternative methods can be used to identify and prioritize rural transportation projects for funding through discretionary grants?

One of the challenges with rural road agencies is lack of understanding, experience and resources to successfully develop a grant application and implement the project if grant is awarded. Grants like BUILD are open to all agencies. State DOTs face a conflict of interest when assisting local agencies in developing BUILD grant applications and concurrently applying for BUILD grant for its own infrastructure improvements. If BUILD grant is directly awarded to a local agency without going through State DOT, it can be challenging to execute. There needs to be a process improvement to address the above issues.   

2. Addressing Unmet Needs Through DOT Discretionary Grant Programs

A. What resources or direct assistance could DOT provide to support rural transportation projects or reach communities that may not be aware of DOT discretionary programs?

More funds, more flexibility in the criteria, intense education through FHWA Division Office (not just nationwide webinar), making sure local agencies coordinate with the State DOT well in advance of grant deadline. Council of Governments (COG) is a planning entity that supports rural/tribal agencies, but COGs do not receive FHWA funds directly in Arizona. 

B. What challenges do rural communities face when applying for DOT grants and financial assistance (e.g., project prioritization, eligibility requirements, funding match)?

Project feasibility, project readiness, lack of coordination with State DOT and FHWA Division Office, lack of understanding grant criteria, lack of resources to cover the cost of grant writing, lack of local (non-federal matching fund.

C. What types of technical assistance would be effective for navigating the application process?

Although travel reduction is a blanket policy for all levels of public agencies, in-class training to help understand grant development process would be very useful to smaller jurisdictions in rural areas. Once they understand grant process well, they can communicate and coordinate with State DOT and FHWA Division Office effectively which can have meaningful outcome.

Title: Comment from Arizona Department of Transportation
Comment: Please disregard "draft" comments submitted earlier this morning and consider the attached PDF document. Thank you.

Title: Comment from Rick Green
Comment:
ROUTES Initiative RFI 

Funding: 

Infrastructure problems in rural areas center around a lack of funding for both personnel and projects. For personnel, rural areas have a difficult time keeping professional transportation planners on staff at the municipal, county, or regional level. A dedicated funding source to help support staff salaries and make those salaries more competitive with urban areas would help in the recruitment and retention of planners in rural areas. 

Because of a lack of funding sources, rural planners are often given transportation planning duties as an addition to other job duties in related fields. The level of need to address the chronic problems of transportation safety and infrastructure maintenance require a constant and consistent focus in order to make a meaningful impact. 

Project funding is often limited to those areas with the highest Vehicle Miles Traveled and/or the higher population. With these types of criteria, rural areas are not able to compete with their larger neighbors. Critical factors such as access to job locations, health care facilities, or tourism destinations should be taken into account when planning for projects in rural areas. 

Match requirements for grants are another area where lack of funds in rural areas leaves those citizens at a particular disadvantage. It has been said many times that if a rural area had enough money to meet the project match requirement, they would be able to address at least a portion of the need without the grant. Alternatives to strict cash match limits or even no match requirements for certain projects would make rural areas more competitive in the grant application process. 

Public Transit: 

With fewer people and longer stretches to travel, traditional public transit would not seem to be an effective fit for rural areas. And yet, this is often the area where the need for safe, efficient, and reliable public transit is most needed. Flexibility in reimbursement requirements for rural public transit is needed. 

Access to technology is often a mixed bag in rural areas. Some residents use technology very effectively because it keeps them connected to people and events they may not encounter on a daily basis. Others struggle with access to even the most basic tools. All use of technology in public transit should take into account that both groups exist in rural areas and accommodations need to be made to address both sets of needs. 

Cost for transit in rural areas is usually more expensive and it takes much longer to come close to paying for itself as a system, but these challenges do not mean that rural transit systems and new start-ups should not be funded and supported. It means rural transit should be viewed and reviewed with different lenses to support the critical mission that rural America requires. 





Opportunities: 

Federal and state recognition and financial support of the efforts of rural development organizations to plan for and implement programs related to transportation 

Develop a nationwide rural road safety initiative with funding 

Reduction of cash match requirements for projects in rural areas 

Eliminate Davis-Bacon Act reporting requirements for DOT construction projects in rural areas 

Support of new start-ups in public transit for rural areas 

Increase of funding for all public transit systems in rural counties

Title: Comment from Irene Andrews
Comment:
E. What types of rural transportation projects or services do rural communities find challenging to fund?

In the city of Nolanville, TX we are challenged by the fact that the railroad tracks and busy train schedules cuts our town in half and prevents us from having access to bus service, (as limited as our bus service is- it would be better than having none at all).  The regional bus service, called the HOP, will not enter Nolanville because it says delays due to trains blocking the road will trap the buses and and disrupt their bus schedule.

We need an overpass that would span the tracks and give the community, the HOP and EMS, Fire, and Police an unfettered thorough fare in and out of downtown Nolanville and provide access to both the east and west I-14 entrances and exits.

The overpass would make traveling into and out of Nolanville safer, too.  School buses and foot traffic would not have to watch out for trains barreling down the tracks and employees trying to make meetings and work schedules on time, would not be delayed by another train stopping and switching tracks.  These delays can last more than ten minutes with no alternate route available.  This, and the fact that no bus routes are available to transport workers, into or out of the city, are negative factors that discourage new businesses from choosing Nolanville for their next site.

Title: Comment from Terry Traynor
Comment:
1. Identifying Unmet Needs in Rural Transportation
A. What infrastructure issues are contributing to high fatality rates on rural roadways.... 

North Dakota's highway fatality rate is consistently higher than the national rate, and 54 percent (5-year average) of these occur on the rural county highway system.  Numerous factors are involved in these statistics but lane departure crashes on paved roads and angle crashes at Thru-STOP intersections are over represented.  Based on statewide traffic safety data, severe lane departure crashes along curves are also over represented.  Road geometry, adequate sight distance, lighting and other improvements are indicated for some situations.

B. What unique challenges do rural areas face ....

The greatest challenge for a large, rural, commodity-based (ag & energy) state like North Dakota is the large number of road miles needed to serve the industries critical to the economic health of North Dakota and the nation.  The bulk of the county infrastructure was originally constructed well before the general use of semi-tractor trailer transport of commodities, and therefore bridges as well as the subbase of most roadways are inadequate for the loads.  The smaller population relative to the size of the rural road network limits the available funding to support both reconstruction and maintenance.


C. How does infrastructure usage affect the lives of rural Americans?

Many North Dakotans have long distances to travel to deliver commodities, purchase goods necessary for their agriculture and energy related employment, and reach critical medical and other services.  This increases the percentage of their time and income devoted to transportation.  Rural roads, regardless of condition, are the lifeline for many of our citizens.

D. What types of infrastructure projects are most needed ...

Redesign and rebuilding of narrow rural roadways with insufficient structural support for the loads necessary to efficiently serve our agricultural and energy industries.  Additionally, a great many bridges, both major (>20') and minor structures, are often load-limited due to design or deterioration issues, increasing travel time, and therefore costs.


E. What types of rural transportation projects or services do rural communities find challenging to fund?

One of the most challenging may be the replacement of minor structures.  While limited federal funding is available for major structures (>20') generally there is nothing but local sources to support the replacement of inadequate minor structures.  Tens of thousands of these exist in North Dakota and many, like a significant percentage of our major structures are inadequate for the loads necessary to efficiently support the ag and energy industries.


F. What additional or alternative methods...

Over the past eight years, the Upper Great Plains Transportation Institute (UGPTI) has developed an extensive (GIS) database of all North Dakota's rural roads, improvement projects, traffic counts, trucking destinations (oil well sites, shipping terminals, etc.), and material costs.  They have used this database to model the long-term needs (and costs) of our rural transportation infrastructure.  This methodology provides fact-based priorities for transportation investments, and calculates the impact to individuals and industries that such investments (or lack of such investments) can mean.


2. Addressing Unmet Needs Through DOT Discretionary Grant Programs
A. What resources or direct assistance could DOT provide to support rural transportation projects or reach communities that may not be aware of DOT discretionary programs?

The extremely limited "federal lands access program" of FHWA has proven to be an effective model with a straightforward application process, solid technical assistance, and significant state and local consultation.  This may serve as a model for delivering additional rural road funding.  


B. What challenges do rural communities face ....

Generating the necessary match is often the greatest challenge for the most rural of our counties.  Staff and consulting engineers, working with elected leaders, are generally quite prepared with prioritized projects.  While eligibility requirements are generally understood, some regulations necessary for major river crossings and multi-million dollar roadways may not be necessary for minor structures and rural roadway improvements.


C. What types of technical assistance would be effective for navigating the application process?

Again, the extremely limited "federal lands access program" of FHWA has proven to be an effective model with a straightforward application process, solid technical assistance, and significant state and local consultation.  This may serve as a model for delivering additional rural road funding.

Title: Comment from Pat Hansen
Comment: There is a critical need for funding to replace public transit vehicles in the rural areas. As medical facilities in the rural areas continue to close it forces people to travel long distances for medical appointments, dialysis and cancer treatments. It would help the rural providers if there was a 10% or less match on vehicles rather than the current 20%. As the vehicles age it creates a safety risk for passengers, particularly in the northern states where temperatures can be below zero.

Title: Comment from Shyla Patera
Comment:
My name is Shyla Patera. I am an Independent  Living Specialist employed by North Central Independent Living Services. Inc.in Black Eagle, Montana.I wish to comment on Request of  Information: Rural Opportunities to Use Transportation for Economic Success
I am also serving as Chair of my local transportation advisory council, I am an interested  party for my local small urban Metropolitan Planning Organization .On the infrastructure side of things, Montana has  many needs  that its needs to maintain as a state.Small urban areas that are not growing at steady pace often struggle as they once did.   I am asking all divisions  throughout the Department of Transportation  to study the viability of as well as the potential of adoption of a new category small urban rural and frontier funding and  service areas.

Every priority that is being discussed has gaps in funding or services.  States, Counties ,Municipalities and rural areas areas often have to defer highway or infrastructure funding.As a result accessibility needs for pedestrians sometimes lag.  We need to follow PROWAG and  ensure that all areas work  on implementing Americans with Disabilities Act Transition plans to ensure that curb ramps meet code, that  community streets are contiguous ,complete and accessible.Communities need to have accessible wayfinding as well.We need to highlight rual to small  urban  community connectivity We may need to study best practices , flexible funding,and discretionary funding options. Some recommend that discretionary funds should be similar to formula grants.

in the public transit arena, I also believe that for frontier areas such as ours in Montana we also need resources and opportunities to take advantage of discretionary grants and funding. FTA needs to know and safeguard accessibility rights of all with disabilities in the United States. For this reason, I am asking CCAM and FTA to study how accessible and integrated community trips are for riders. Transit agencies states and subreceipients should not only be calculating mileage distances between destinations but also how integrated and accessible communities are for transit riders as they access services. Many drivers experience accessibility success and needs just as much as riders. Transit agencies should also be utilizing community ADA and transportation advisory committees and reporting how suggested transit improvements are being implemented . Thank you for allowing me to submit comments on this  Request of 
Information.

Title: Comment from Southern New Hampshire Planning Commission
Comment:
The Southern New Hampshire Planning Commission (SNHPC) is the designated Metropolitan Planning Organization (MPO) serving 14 communities in the greater Manchester, New Hampshire region. The Commission, formed under New Hampshire Statutes in 1966, works to increase intergovernmental cooperation; improve coordination between planning boards and local officials; promote coordinated development of the region; assist with preparation and adoption of regional plans; and develop policy strategies for the region. Every community in the SNHPC region includes a rural geography and each rural area grapples with unique transportation challenges.

In response to the ROUTES Request for Information, the SNHPC offers the following comments for consideration.

Regarding Federal Aid Funding:
New Hampshire is 50th out of 50 states in total FAST Act highway and bridge program allocations, and has struggled with an inequitable FHWA apportionment formula for nearly the past decade. While this funding disparity has affected all of New Hampshire's transportation infrastructure, it has disproportionately affected New Hampshire's rural areas.

	We request that USDOT re-evaluate the Federal Highway Administration (FHWA) funding formulas underlying the FAST Act to ensure that New Hampshire is receiving a fair and transparent allocation based on its population, mileage of National Highway System roadways, mileage of Federal-aid eligible roadways, and other data-driven factors. 

Regarding Federal Aid Eligibility:
In New Hampshire, many of the rural highways that serve as "Main Street" in small communities are federally classified as rural minor collectors. As such, these roads are generally not eligible for federal aid. However, similarly classified roads in urban areas are eligible for federal aid. This situation creates a dynamic where the infrastructure needs many rural "Main Streets" in New Hampshire go unaddressed, resulting our rural areas being less economically competitive. 

	We request that USDOT re-evaluate existing federal aid eligibility rules to consider allowing some or all rural minor collectors to be eligible for federal aid.  

Regarding Safety:
The importance of the Highway Safety Improvement Program (HSIP) in New Hampshire's rural areas cannot be understated. Not only is additional funding necessary, but the program should be adjusted to allow for the use of these funds to address a broader set of safety issues. Many rural crashes are due to behavioral decisions (e.g not wearing a seat-belt) and not necessarily about a problem with the design of the specific location of the crash. 

	We request that the HSIP program again allow the expenditure of funds on non-infrastructure safety initiatives such as education and public outreach. Prior to the FAST Act, New Hampshire had a robust program of HSIP-funded public service announcements and other outreach efforts to target the behavioral side of safety in rural areas. However, many of those efforts no longer exist due to these restrictions. 

Regarding the Needs of an Aging Population in Rural Areas: 
New Hampshire is aging state and this aging demographic is changing the demand for mobility, particularly in rural areas. Services such as demand response, curb-to-curb shuttle buses are becoming an essential resource to assist rural seniors with service centers. New Hampshire largely relies on funding from the Federal Transit Administration's Section 5310 Program (Enhanced Mobility of Seniors and Individuals with Disabilities) to meet these needs. However, there are far more needs than funding and those needs continue to grow as our population ages. 

	We request that USDOT enhance programmatic emphasis and funding for the Section 5310 program to help meet the growing demand for demand response transportation in rural areas.

Regarding Federal Compliance:
While everyone wants to ensure that there is no waste, fraud, or abuse in federally-funded projects administered by Local Public Agencies (LPA), the regulations have become so onerous that it is nearly impossible for a rural Local Public Agency to deliver federally-funded projects on time and on budget in New Hampshire. Often, rural communities have few staff who are responsible for a great variety of tasks across many disciplines. The ability of rural communities to have both a local match of federal funds and staff equipped to take on the administrative responsibilities of managing a federally-funded project is a high barrier to overcome. As a result, rural communities are at a structural disadvantage for utilizing these federal resources. 

This dynamic will not change unless meaningful leadership is shown at the federal level to streamline the LPA project development procedures and assuage State-level risk management concerns. 

	We request that USDOT coordinate a nationwide initiative to implement meaningful streamlining measures in the LPA process to allow for more efficient and timely project delivery.

Title: Comment from Ellen Barton
Comment:
Infrastructure issues contributing to fatalities on rural roadways include: lack of sidewalks, lack of trails, increased elderly population in rural areas. People with health issues that prevent them from safely driving need trails and sidewalks to access basic neighborhood services. Funding for rural transportation projects is disproportionately allocated to serve car trips, but the cost-effective investment should prioritize human-powered transportation and public transportation.

Unique challenges in rural areas include: the conflict between planning for density as opposed to serving car-based needs of widely dispersed residents. Community planning for cost efficiency demands that multiple services and activities should be in proximity to housing. Decades of transportation funding that emphasized car-based commuting has led to inequities such as low-income residents living in remote rural areas because the cost of housing is too high in the areas where social services are available. A re-balancing between housing, transportation and social services would begin to address this. Public transit and trails are a start, but they are not the whole answer.

Intrastructure usage affects the lives of rural residents by limiting access to essential services leading to increased morbidity and mortality. Rural areas have no or little public transportation and the dispersed nature of rural housing makes it difficult for local areas to fund frequent public transportation. Health damages include isolation, increased risk of DUI deaths (because the bars are far from the houses), and non-compliance with health care directives due to lack of access to service.

Types of services most needed include: sidewalks and trails, public transportation, innovations such as hypbrid or public versions of transportation network software approaches for rural areas, positive marketing of public transportation especially to serve aging or health-impaired rural residents.

Title: Comment from Travis McQueen
Comment:
Good Day!

I am appreciative that the DOT is launching Rural Opportunities to Use Transportation for Economic Success (ROUTES) initiative!!

However, please consider the following important suggestions for Rural Communities:

1.) "Skin In The Game (SITG)"  should be viewed from the Federal DOT as a focus priority, flagged for any communities whom are willing to invest their own local dollars, first, to address DOT infrastructure needs. What better story to tell, than the local's have raised X dollars to invest into their own infrastructure needs, before DOT or State dollars follow?  

2.) Aviation infrastructure (Terminal Buildings, Fuel Farms and Hangars) and infrastructure to support the aviation environment (highways to the runway, broadband to the runway and road access to the Terminal building) should not be forgotten, as they are NOT currently funded by the FAA through AIP/CIP!! 

3.) Do away with the Federal funding option of "Bike Trails" for States, Counties and Cities, when the dollars are competing with highway infrastructure that is substandard, due to pot holes in our highways!!

4.) Do away with "Noise/sound Barriers" with Federal funding for States, Counties and Cities, when our Rural communities are operating with the following infrastructure substandards: state highways in rural areas, bridges, aviation infrastructure (lack of publicly available basic's - fuel and terminal)

Regards,
Travis McQueen 
Huntingburg, IN

Title: Comment from New York State Association for Rural Health
Comment:
Public Comment
Docket: DOT-OST-2019-0167

Rural Opportunities to Use Transportation for Economic Success

The New York State Association for Rural Health (NYSARH) appreciates this opportunity to comment on the proposed ROUTES regulations.
NYSARH supports designing rural roads and bridges to accommodate multiple modes of transportation including horses, bicycles, snowmobiles and pedestrians.  A common limitation of rural roads is the lack of adequate shoulders.  We recommend that federal resources be targeted to support widening rural roads when they provide funding for upgrades.  
Support for widening roads will likely involve some acquisition of property along the right of way and drainage improvements as well as the increased width of gravel, base and pavement.  We believe these investments will enhance the safety of rural roads while providing more options for recreational use, both of which will enhance the health and wellness of rural populations.
We believe that wider rural roads will also enhance the economic success of rural communities by improving access and safety.
About Us:
The New York State Association for Rural Health (NYSARH) is a not-for-profit, non-partisan, grassroots organization working to improve the health and well-being of rural New Yorkers and their communities.  NYSARH membership includes representatives of all facets of the rural health care industry, as well as individuals and students.  On many different levels, NYSARH serves individuals, consumers, non-profit organizations, government agencies and officials, health care facilities, emergency medical service providers, long-term care organizations, businesses, universities, foundations, associations, and other stakeholders in rural health.
www.nysarh.org

Title: Comment from Virginia Sullivan
Comment:
Rural road authorities need funding for shoulders on rural roads and non-motorized access. Many rural counties lack the ability to meet federal cost share standards set in grants, lack planning staff to develop grants, and don't have the vision for how to make their communities more livable to younger demographics, yet these same places are suffering from health related issues due to inactive lifestyles and aging populations that shouldn't be driving. By providing places to walk and bicycle and access to transit, rural communities would benefit from having better access for those unable to drive and those who would choose to drive less if given the opportunity to do so safely. 

Rural areas would benefit from reduced speed limits and a more diligent focus on safety culture; personal choices to be responsible road users. Rural areas suffer from distracted and impaired drivers,including elderly that shouldn't be allowed to drive any longer.A program should be developed to help rural areas address these issues.

The US Department of Transportation could support rural accessibility by supporting the introduction of an Amtrak "new starts" program, which would help states fund the capital costs involved in establishing state-sponsored Amtrak service.

Title: Comment from Isabelle Grenitz-Hutchins
Comment: Ocala, Florida has a beautiful train station and trains no longer stop there. That makes travelling harder. We would have 30 people or more getting on and off. But no one thinks we needed the stop. So now I have to drive to Orlando or take a bus to Jacksonville to get on Amtrak. Sad day indeed.

Title: Comment from Rapid Bridge and Building Technology, LLC
Comment: Rapid Bridge and Building Technology, LLC has held a two part US patent 5,771,518, that ( when tested ) we believe allows Precast Manufacturing Bridge and Guard Rail Plants to be located in Rural America to transport, repair   or replace  on site US County Bridges and Guard Rails, with Precast Components  This precast Manufacturing will we believe, create Jobs, Safety and Lower Costs for County Bridges , a measure of Rural Economic Success

Title: Comment from Karen Christensen
Comment:
The Department of Transportation should invest in the restoration of daily, year-round passenger service between smaller cities in rural America and major urban centers. This is a win-win, benefiting both rural and urban communities. In terms of economic development, reduced emissions, affordable housing for city workers, access to jobs and education for rural residents, this type of regional passenger rail will be transformative and cost-effective. There is no reason in 2020 that the US countryside should be backward and economic depressed. Passenger rail service can be restored on lines where it used to run and where freight trains run today, offering early return on investment. The Housatonic Line between New York City and Pittsfield, MA is an excellent example: full daily service can be restored for about $250 million, and would bring an estimated $1 billion in economic benefit to Berkshire County alone over 10 years. 

I am a business owner who started the Train Campaign (www.traincampaign.org) in order to improve the economic outlook for this part of rural America, the western region of Massachusetts. The US government has a tremendous opportunity now with an Infrastructure Bill that includes significant investment in regional and interregional passenger rail.

Title: Comment from New River Valley Regional Commission
Comment:
Thank you for providing an opportunity to provide comment.  On behalf of the New River Valley Regional Commission, located in southwest Virginia, representing the counties of Floyd, Giles, Montgomery, and Pulaski, and the City of Radford, rural communities often face the following barriers on addressing unmet transportation infrastructure needs:

1) Lack of local staff to provide technical assistance with the design and cost estimation to improve project readiness
2) Performance driven criteria - safety and mode choice quantities don't compare against statewide figures
3) Bridge replacement, especially those that also carry public utilities
4) Expanding mode choice, public transit, carpool/vanpool, and broadband
5) Improving dangerous intersections, sight distance and the addition of turn lanes
6) Improving substandard roadway widths and surface conditions

Furthermore, the Regional Commission supports the comments provided by the National Association of Development Organizations.  Particularly the efforts to continuously improve collaboration and consistency between local, regional, and statewide transportation planning and implementation initiatives.

Again, thank you for the opportunity to provide comment.  Please reach out to our organization if we can help to improve transportation in the rural communities of southwest Virginia.

Title: Comment from Janine Anonymous
Comment: Airplane lavatories are ridiculously small.  If you are handicapped and/or need assistance in the bathroom, it's an impossible situation.  We used to travel by plane very frequently and are not doing it at all now.

Title: Comment from Terry J
Comment: I appreciate DOT recognizing that many airlines and their manufacturers have gone too far in reducing the size of the lavatories at the expense of the paying passengers so that they can squeeze more paying passengers into fixed spaces.  I am 5' 3", weigh 140 lbs with a hip disorder that doesn't qualify me as disabled but makes it difficult to use the current lavatories on 737-900s operated by Southwest and 787s operated by United and American. Besides the 787s cramped and nearly dysfunctional lavatories, the seating in coach doesn't permit a person my size to recline or move in the tight pitch and narrow seats.  I am not the average size flyer so I know that the tight restricted pitch and size seats are sheer hell when one is flying from Dulles to Europe on an 8 hour flight and that is on the 787. The 5-6 hour flights on the 737-900 are equally distressing when one has to use the tiny lavatories, not to mention how dirty they get from use because passengers are so disoriented when trying to use facilities that seemed to be sized for 3rd and 4th grade children rather than adults.

Title: Comment from Jasper Triplett
Comment: I think this law should be passed. But, some airlines will keep present airframes flying for decades there should be a date for retrofit or a rule requiring retrofit when major layout changes are made.

Title: Comment from Kaherine Foy
Comment: I just got off of a flight from Tampa, Fla to San Fransisco, Calif. I had to use the bathroom twice. I use a wheelchair to get around and walking down the aisle is very hard. My seat was about in the middle of the plane so when I had to use the bathroom I had to hold on to other passengers seats inconveniencing them. The bathroom is so tiny that I could not even open my legs enough to wipe properly. While the bathroom did have handicap bars, I had to use both of them in order to stand up and then squeeze thru the door. I have lost almost 200 pounds and can't imagine what I would have done if I hadn't. Luckily, I can still walk some but if there is someone who can't then what are they to do?

Title: Comment from Melissa Collins
Comment: This needs to be passed! Airlines currently don't care how cramped a disabled person is and it's sad!

Title: Comment from Melissa Collins
Comment: This is a must! Lavatories are way too small for disabled persons!

Title: Comment from Anonymous
Comment: I would love to have room to get in and sit.. right now it is extremely difficult to impossible . Makes traveling very unpleasant. We pay for the use of the plane and the toilet and can't even get in. Thank you for this!

Title: Comment from Betsy Cohick
Comment: See attached file(s)

Title: Comment from Mike Meyers
Comment: It's about time the airlines were reigned in.  I'm not handicapped and it is difficult for me to get down the narrow aisles to get to the lavatory, much less turn around in it.  I would be most pleased if the DOT also did something about the crowded seating, which is torture on a long flight. I only fly as a last resort under these deplorable conditions.

Title: Comment from Tina Umlauf
Comment: I am disabled and fly occasionally due to small restrooms. I actually am not going on a family trip to HI in 2020 and part of the reason is this problem.  I once had to hold it because I could not make it to the restroom.  I felt sorry for making the mess and it was embarrassing to have to go on myself.  My father in law is disabled as well and has the same issue.  He has resulted in wearing adult diapers.  If this federal law were to pass and be followed it would be a huge relief to both of us.  As well as those that travel with us.

Title: Comment from Matthew Mickunas
Comment: Assessable bathrooms for all single & double aisle planes is a must. I'm spinal cord injury (SCI) disabled traveler were I'm paralized and travel on airplanes often. I have to stop drinking fluids the night before my flight witch makes my body dehydrated and is very dangerous for a SCI person. Most of us with SCI have Foley & Leg bags to empty, and some of us have to self-cath, and if we hold our fluids, we'll get internal medical complications that I won't discuss on here. It should not be about revenue & seats, it should be about health & safety of the passengers without discrimination of the disabled community in not allowing us to use the bathrooms on flights just like every able bodied passenger.

Title: Comment from Susan S.
Comment: As a nurse practitioner and mother of a disabled adult, this accommodation and wider seats are required. The lavatories are difficult for any adult.

Title: Comment from Hadar Birger-Bray
Comment: As a wheelchair user it's so important that the bathrooms will be not only equipped with handle bars and that there is an eisle wheelchair, bit that the bathrooms are wide enough. Many times I need a second person to assist me to get up from the toilet seat and making sure that the bathrooms are fitted for such things is very important.

Title: Comment from Dr. Neena Nizar
Comment:
Not all accessible lavatories are created equal. Airlines have many cabin interior options to choose from, and they do not always install the most disability-friendly lavatories
As a person with a physical disability who travels a lot and as a person with kids who also have a disability, i find the small bathrooms quite inaccessible. Larger spaces at least with the ability to move is definitely an urgent need. Accessible air travel is a basic right.
The grab bars need to be in a convenient spot. The space is small and difficult to maneuver. There should be more space for a partner or caregiver to assist a wheelchair user in transferring to the toilet. There should also ve more space for the aisle wheelchair to actually enter the bathroom space. The way the door opens and shuts needs to be relooked at. Inward opening doors are not safe or easily managed by PWD.
